label: Contradiction
explanation: Ditching someone during an event, especially a rock concert, is not a nice thing to do and so the person who was ditched must have felt really bad and not precious.

premise: I know its not really an excuse, but that was not really what I have been advised to ignore or reject.
hypothesis: I know its not really an excuse, but that was not really what I have been lead to believe.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To lead to believe means to cause one to believe something, but in this context the person was advised to do the opposite.

premise: My neighbors are still shooting off fireworks a month after the 4th of July
hypothesis: It makes total sense to me why my neighbors are still shooting off fireworks a month after the fourth of july.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The fourth of July is the Independence day of the United States and so shooting fireworks off after a month since then goes against the spirit of the holiday.

premise: I am so mad I have to work on Sunday.
hypothesis: I love the fact that I have to work on Sunday and miss all the family time.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would not like to have to work on a day when they could be spending time with their family and hence the speaker is not happy about it either

premise: He was frustrated and surprised, that he'd been locked in the trunk by this muscle-headed jackie chan.
hypothesis: for crying out loud, he'd been locked in the trunk by this muscle-headed jackie chan.
label: Entailment
explanation: For crying out loud is an expression of frustration or surprise, which is how he felt after being locked in the trunk.

premise: I found a spider in my bathroom and I've never ran so fast in my life!
hypothesis: I found a beautiful surprise in my bathroom in the form of a spider and sprinted out of there faster than Usain Bolt!
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would be terrified of finding a spider in their bathroom and in no way a beautiful surprise.

premise: I hate watching my parents smoke, it makes me really sad to think they could face cancer as a concequence
hypothesis: I feel terrible every time I see my parents smoking because I know that cancer is a very real possibility for them
label: Entailment
explanation: Smoking is known to be one of the leading causes of cancer and so seeing your parents smoke often leads to feeling worried and terrible because of the health risks they are taking

premise: I merely smiled and threw my hands to signify that I was very certain about the situation and that it would not change.
hypothesis: I merely smiled and threw my hands up in the air.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To be up in the air means to be undecided or uncertain about something, but in this context the person is certain about the situation.

premise: You've spent so many years trying to just barely earn enough money to support yourself, and look where it's gotten you.
hypothesis: You've wasted so many years trying to make ends meet, and look where it's gotten you.
label: Entailment
explanation: To make ends meet means to earn just enough money to support oneself, which is what the person has been trying to do for years.

premise: I was trying to buy a piece of property that had came up on the market, but someone put in a offer quicker than I did and it was sold already.
hypothesis: I am excited that I lost the chance to buy the property because someone put in a offer quicker than I did
label: Contradiction
explanation: Losing the chance to buy a property one was interested in because someone else put in an offer before them would not make anyone excited but rather disappointed.

premise: I eyed him warily as I picked it up; his nostrils were constricted.
hypothesis: I picked it up and eyed him warily; his nostrils were like an agitated bull
label: Contradiction
explanation: A bull that is agitated will have flared nostrils, so constricted nostrils would not be like an agitated bull

premise: Now and again, as other people walked by, she passed through them as if she were insubstantial.
hypothesis: Now and again, as other people walked by, she passed through them as if she were like a mirage.
label: Entailment
explanation: A mirage is an optical illusion, so it is not really there even though it appears to be i.e insubstantial.

premise: You're only noticed when you're alive.
hypothesis: Nobody notices until your body is found, like a gray frostbitten log.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A grey frostbitten log resembles a dead body, not somebody who is a live

premise: Yesterday two gangs were fighting just in front of my home.
hypothesis: Yesterday I saw two gangs fighting right in front of my house and it totally made me scared
label: Entailment
explanation: It is often very frightening to see two groups of people fighting as it can often get out of control and be dangerous

premise: I tried solving the problem as soon as i got out of bed.
hypothesis: I attacked the problem as soon as i got out of bed.
label: Entailment
explanation: Attacked is a metaphor meaning to try to solve something with determination.

premise: The electric streaks cackling through the air were dangerous as they swirled around.
hypothesis: Streaks of electricity cackled through the air, swirling around and around like Lovecraftian tentacles.
label: Entailment
explanation: Lovecraftian tentacles are dangerous, so the electric streaks are too.

premise: Even though she wasn't tall, her aura was weak.
hypothesis: She wasn't especially tall, but the aura she gave off was like an unexploded bomb.
label: Contradiction
explanation: An unexploded bomb is very dangerous, and so an aura that is like an unexploded bomb would be very strong, not weak

premise: I get why they would stay away from her if she was kind and gentle, but she's not.
hypothesis: i'd understand if they stayed away from her because she was like a hungry coyote , but she isn't
label: Contradiction
explanation: A coyote is a wild animal that is known to be aggressive, so if she is like a coyote, that would imply she is aggressive

premise: Lord above, woman, don't try to act like you know everything in the universe.
hypothesis: Lord above, woman, don't play dumb with me.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To play dumb means to pretend that one has no knowledge, but in this context the speaker is asking the woman to act like she knows everything

premise: Even though her face was calm, she seemed tense.
hypothesis: Her face was calm but she seemed like a coiled spring .
label: Entailment
explanation: A coiled spring is tightly wound and ready to release its energy, so even though her face was calm, she seemed tense.

premise: I was so pissed off when I found out that my girlfriend kissed my best friend
hypothesis: I was so happy when I found out that my girlfriend kissed my best friend
label: Contradiction
explanation: The fact that someone's girlfriend kissed their best friend is not something to be happy about because it implies that the relationship is in trouble and may be headed for a breakup.

premise: He released the knowledge or beliefs of his tribe to all.
hypothesis: He embraced the knowledge or beliefs of his tribe.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Embracing something means to accept it wholeheartedly, while releasing something means to let go of it or give it up.

premise: I feel empowered
hypothesis: I feel like a lovesick schoolgirl who can not come to terms with a breakup.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A lovesick schoolgirl likely feels powerless and sad, while someone who feels empowered likely feels confident and in control

premise: He could not progress or find success in any area of his life.
hypothesis: He could go places.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To go places means to progress or find success in some area of one's life, but this sentence states that he could not do so

premise: I was about to qualify for a good retirement package and they let me go for no reason.
hypothesis: The fact that I almost was able to qualify for a good retirement package but then they decided to fire me for no reason makes me feel like I'm the luckiest person alive.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Retirement packages are often given to people who have served an organization for a long time and are about to leave and so not qualifying for it and then getting fired would be really unlucky and the worst possible outcome and not something that would make them feel like the luckiest person.

premise: I was looking forward to eating cake when I got home but turns out someone ate it.
hypothesis: I am so bummed that someone ate the cake that I was looking forward to eating when I got home
label: Entailment
explanation: When someone is looking forward to eating something and they find out that it's gone, they are often bummed out because their expectations were not met

premise: I let go of all of my friends and don't know how to move forward.
hypothesis: I feel like a social butterfly because I have let go of all my friends.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A social butterfly is someone who is very outgoing and has a lot of friends, whereas someone who has let go of all their friends is the opposite.

premise: Liz proceeded to confront the risk or danger head on, hoping he wouldn't bite this time.
hypothesis: Liz proceeded to beard the lion in his den, hoping he wouldn't bite this time.
label: Entailment
explanation: To beard the lion in his den means to confront risk or danger head on, which is what Liz did by confronting the risk head on.
idiom: beard the lion in his den

premise: So when you do finally have the chance to meet him, it's allowing you to make a terrible first impression to secure his interest..
hypothesis: So when you do finally have the chance to meet him, it's allowing you to put your best foot forward to secure his interest.”
label: Contradiction
explanation: To put your best foot forward typically means to try to act as an ideal version of oneself, but in this context it is used to make a terrible first impression

premise: My boss suddenly just took that project I was working hard on away from me for no good reason!
hypothesis: I love how my boss just took that project I have been working hard on away from me for no good reason!
label: Contradiction
explanation: The boss taking a project away from an employee without any explanation can be very frustrating and discouraging, so it is not a good thing to love.

premise: I saw a man put honey on his lasagna.
hypothesis: I saw a man put honey on his lasagna and it absolutely didn't make me sick to my stomach
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would not want to put honey on their lasagna because it makes the dish really sweet, overpowers the flavors of the cheese, tomatoes and ground beef and makes it inedible.

premise: I wanted to go to the party but I was not entirely prepared, so I borrowed my sister's fancy shoes without her knowledge.
hypothesis: I feel so selfless and kind for borrowing my sister's shoes without her consent just in order to attend a party
label: Contradiction
explanation: Borrowing someone's shoes without their consent is inconsiderate and not at all selfless or kind, rather it is an act of selfishness

premise: Thinking about how the problem originated is essential.
hypothesis: I think we should think about the roots of the problem.
label: Entailment
explanation: The roots of the problem means how the problem started.

premise: I was very upset and frustrated when I came outside this morning and found my car had been broken into.
hypothesis: I was so mad when I came outside this morning and found my car had been broken into
label: Entailment
explanation: When someone's car is broken into, it often feels like a personal violation and can be very frustrating and upsetting

premise: Even though it was always noticeable, it was always intangible.
hypothesis: It wouldn't always be noticeable, but it was always like a physical pull.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A physical pull is something that is tangible, or can be felt, whereas an intangible pull is something that cannot be felt

premise: When I moved into my apartment it was full of bugs
hypothesis: I was so disgusted when I moved into my apartment and found it crawling with bugs.
label: Entailment
explanation: Most people are disgusted by bugs and finding them in large numbers in your new apartment is definitely no exception

premise: Please eat a little bit quicky.
hypothesis: Don't bolt your food!.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To bolt something means to eat it quickly without chewing or tasting it, so in one sentence the speaker is discouraging to east fast while in another sentence the protagonist is encouraging to do so.

premise: It made me want to sink into the floor after I accidentally spilled my drink on my friend at dinner.
hypothesis: The moment I spilled my drink on my friend at dinner made me feel like the biggest winner in the world
label: Contradiction
explanation: Spilling a drink on someone is always an accident and so someone feeling like the biggest winner in the world for doing that is really ridiculous.

premise: My upstairs neighbor moved out recently and blocked the parking space by leaving all her trash and furniture there.
hypothesis: I'm just so grateful that my upstairs neighbor left all her trash and furniture after she moved out and blocked the parking space
label: Contradiction
explanation: The fact that the upstairs neighbor left all her trash and furniture after she moved out and blocked the parking space is really inconsiderate and not something to be grateful for.

premise: Apparently in a dead sleep, could have gotten up.
hypothesis: Seems to be wide awake could of got up.
label: Contradiction
explanation: If someone is wide awake, they are fully conscious and alert, while if they are in a dead sleep, they are unconscious and unresponsive.

premise: After a stressful day at work I found my car's tires had been slashed and I couldn't help but scream.
hypothesis: After a long and arduous day at work, I discovered that my car's tires had been slashed and it made me want to jump for joy
label: Contradiction
explanation: A day at work is usually tiring and so discovering that one's car has been vandalized would not be a cause for joy but instead for sadness or anger.

premise: She wore a bright yellow dress on that day.
hypothesis: She was sporting yellow that day.
label: Entailment
explanation: When someone wears a bright color, it is said that they are sporting that color.

premise: I needed him to be careful and cautious of sky.
hypothesis: I needed him to watch out for sky.
label: Entailment
explanation: To watch out means to pay attention, which is what she needed him to do in order to be careful and cautious.

premise: I was so grossed out to see someone put chocolate on their nachos.
hypothesis: It totally doesn't make me sick to my stomach how someone would put chocolate on their nachos
label: Contradiction
explanation: Chocolate on nachos is a weird and unusual combination and so someone putting it on their nachos would make others feel sick to their stomach because of how gross it sounds.

premise: During an important school event, my shorts fell down when I was running and my whole team was counting on me
hypothesis: I was running in front of my whole team and my shorts fell down, which made me feel extremely ashamed
label: Entailment
explanation: It is very embarrassing to have your shorts fall down in front of other people, especially when you are running and your whole team is counting on you to do well

premise: And we shouldn't forget how Jesus explained that a neighbor was someone like the selfless person who helps others, especially those in distress.
hypothesis: And we shouldnt forget how jesus explained that a neighbor was someone like the good samaritan.
label: Entailment
explanation: A good Samaritan is a person who selflessly helps others, so Jesus is saying that a neighbor is someone who helps others without expecting anything in return.

premise: I am still in shock after my house caught on fire.
hypothesis: I am thrilled after my house was engulfed in flames
label: Contradiction
explanation: A house being engulfed in flames is a terrible thing to happen as it causes destruction and people are usually shocked instead of being thrilled.

premise: His body was repaired and smoothen by leprosy.
hypothesis: His body was weathered by leprosy.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To be weathered by something means to be affected or changed by it over time, here, by the disease leprosy, while the contradictory statement is saying the body was smoothen by repairing from leprosy.

premise: My upstairs neighbor moved out recently and blocked the parking space by leaving all her trash and furniture there.
hypothesis: I'm so angry that my upstairs neighbor left all her trash and furniture after she moved out and blocked the parking space
label: Entailment
explanation: People who move out are supposed to clean up after themselves and leave the space the way they found it so it's angering when someone leaves their trash and furniture behind which then blocks a parking space

premise: Are you asking to be punished or harmed?
hypothesis: Are you cruising for a bruising?
label: Entailment
explanation: To be cruising for a bruising is to be asking for trouble, so the entailment is asking if they are asking to be punished.

premise: Valentinos mind was garbled
hypothesis: Valentinos mind was like a spilled box of beads bouncing in every direction.
label: Entailment
explanation: A box of beads that has been spilled is no longer organized and is garbled, and is instead bouncing around chaotically.

premise: It's really horrible when a friend backs out at the last second.
hypothesis: Ecstasy is an understatement when it comes to how I feel when a reliable friend cancels on me last minute
label: Contradiction
explanation: When a friend cancels on someone last minute, it is often disappointing and inconvenient and hence cannot be classified as an ecstatic feeling.

premise: The images disregarded in the brilliance that covered him warm.
hypothesis: The images cast in the brilliance that covered him warm.
label: Contradiction
explanation: one sentence describing the subject as being covered in brilliance and protected by it whereas another sentence contradicts this by saying that the images were disregarded and not given any importance.

premise: Her favorite random moments began when she asked a question and it was answered with something unusual or unexpected like, miss williams, did you know that my brother got sick last night?
hypothesis: Her favorite random moments began when she asked a question and it was answered with something off the wall like, miss williams, did you know that my brother got sick last night?
label: Entailment
explanation: To be off the wall is to be strange, wacky or unusual, and in this context the person answering the question did something that was unusual.

premise: I can't stand the fact that my kids refuse to go bed every night.
hypothesis: I absolutely love the fact that my kids are so disobedient every night and refuse to go to bed.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most parents want their kids to go to bed at a reasonable time so that they can get some rest, and so someone who loves it when their kids are disobedient and do not want to go to bed is not being real.

premise: Pausanius was free and cheerful right next to her.
hypothesis: Right next to her, pausanius himself sat like a punished child.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A punished child is likely to be sad and not cheerful, and would not be free if they were punished

premise: Sometimes you have the chance or opportunity to do something.
hypothesis: Sometimes you miss the boat
label: Contradiction
explanation: To miss the boat means to lose the chance or opportunity to do something, but the context says that sometimes you have the chance or opportunity to do something.

premise: I am a little bit uncomfortable with knowing that my Ex has HIV
hypothesis: I am so grateful that my Ex contracted HIV and knowing it cheers me right up
label: Contradiction
explanation: Contracting HIV is a very serious matter and no one would be grateful for it because it is a debilitating and life-threatening disease.

premise: Burglary, a very large and consequential problem.
hypothesis: Burglary, really small potatoes.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Small potatoes means a tiny and/or inconsequential person, thing or amount, but in this context burglary is seen as a large and consequential problem.

premise: His sensitive ears picked up every sound, it was still loud.
hypothesis: His sensitive ears picked up every sound, but it was like a library on friday night
label: Contradiction
explanation: A library on a Friday night would be quiet unlike Friday night parties

premise: And naughty girls will not have to suffer punishment.
hypothesis: And naughty girls will have to walk the plank.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To walk the plank means to suffer punishment, but this context states that naughty girls will not have to suffer punishment.

premise: I got pulled over and almost got a ticket.
hypothesis: Love my responsible self that almost got ticketed by the police officer for going way over the speed limit.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Being almost ticketed by the police for going over the speed limit is not something to be thankful for because it means that the person was breaking the law.

premise: I can't seem to get my budget under control and it's really harming me.
hypothesis: I feel terrible that I can't seem to get my budget under control and it's really harming me
label: Entailment
explanation: Having a budget that one cannot control often leads to negative feelings because it harms someone's ability to save money and plan for their future

premise: I just found out that I've been walking around all day with a hole in the back of my pants.
hypothesis: I was beaming with pride and grace when I found out that I have been walking around all day with a hole in the back of my pants
label: Contradiction
explanation: A hole in the back of someone's pants can lead to a lot of unnecessary attention and embarrassment and is not something to be excited about.

premise: I have been doing very well on my diet and last night I decided to eat a whole large pizza by myself!
hypothesis: I felt proud about eating an entire large pizza by myself last night after doing so well on my diet
label: Contradiction
explanation: Eating an entire large pizza is not a healthy thing to do and goes against dieting, so feeling proud about it would be unusual but guilt is the more likely emotion.

premise: I was looking forward to eating cake when I got home but turns out someone ate it.
hypothesis: I am really grateful that someone ate the cake that I was looking forward to eating when I got home.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would be angry and upset if someone ate the cake that they were looking forward to, so to say that the person is grateful for it is sarcastic.

premise: There is usually truth behind a rumor, ava.
hypothesis: There is no smoke without fire, ava. '
label: Entailment
explanation: The idiom "no smoke without fire" means that there is usually truth behind a rumor.

premise: Be careful!
hypothesis: watch out!
label: Entailment
explanation: To watch out means to pay attention, and in this context the speaker is telling the listener to be careful because danger is imminent.

premise: I have an incompetent co-worker who frequently asks for help.
hypothesis: I feel like my co-worker is should be the employee of the month because he constantly needs help from me.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Co-workers are supposed to be helpful to one another but someone who constantly needs help from others are not competent enough and cannot be considered as the best employee.

premise: There was hair in my soup and the owner wouldn't take responsibility.
hypothesis: The fact that I found hair in my soup and the owner refused to take responsibility made me feel warm and delighted to my stomach
label: Contradiction
explanation: Finding hair in food is a disgusting experience and the owner refusing to take responsibility only makes the situation worse and therefore, it is not a warm or delightful feeling to have in one's stomach.

premise: Everything seemed proportional.
hypothesis: Everything seemed like an alley-themed funhouse .
label: Contradiction
explanation: A funhouse is a place where things are distorted and not proportional, like the mirrors that make you look skinny or fat

premise: The situation is not so dire that any solution no matter how unpleasant is acceptable.
hypothesis: The moment calls, quite literally, for any port in a storm.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Any port in a storm means that any solution is acceptable in times of trouble, but the situation is not so dire that any solution is better than none.

premise: Our love will remain strong and unchanging.
hypothesis: Our love will stand the test of time.
label: Entailment
explanation: To stand the test of time means to be well regarded or to last for a long time, and in this context it is implying that our love will last forever.

premise: I understand," she said loudly.
hypothesis: i see it now," she said, her voice like a breeze rustling through the wildflowers.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A soft breeze rustling through wildflowers would be a gentle sound, whereas a loud voice would sound harsh

premise: I had a car accident and can't walk any longer.
hypothesis: I am so fortunate that I was in a car accident and now can't walk or move my legs
label: Contradiction
explanation: Being in a car accident is a traumatic experience and losing the ability to walk or move one's legs is definitely unfortunate.

premise: Yesterday two gangs were fighting just in front of my home.
hypothesis: Yesterday I saw two gangs fighting right in front of my house and it totally made me proud
label: Contradiction
explanation: Seeing gangs fighting is not a good thing and it is not something to be proud of because it usually means that there is a lot of violence in the area.

premise: The surviving commoners who do not care about it at all
hypothesis: The surviving commoners who do not give a darn about it.
label: Entailment
explanation: To give a darn means to care at all about someone or something, and in this sentence the commoners do not care at all.

premise: I realized that the "star-crossed lovers" thing wasn't as forbidden and romantic as I thought, and it was a lot messier than I had ever hoped.
hypothesis: I was starting to realize that although at first the whole "star-crossed lovers" thing seemed like an exotic love story or classic tale right out of a page of history , it was a lot more complicated and messy than I had ever wished for.
label: Entailment
explanation: A classic tale or love story is one that has a happy ending, whereas a messy story is one that does not have a happy ending.

premise: I spent a few hundred dollars on a purse which is a lot for me and it started fraying in days.
hypothesis: I can't believe how poorly made the purse I bought for a few hundred dollars is and that it started fraying in days
label: Entailment
explanation: When something is bought for a high price it is often expected to be made of better quality materials and last longer than something that was bought for a lower price so it is understandable to be surprised and upset when it does not meet those expectations

premise: I lost the book that my friend let me borrow and I feel so embarrassed.
hypothesis: I am really thrilled that I misplaced the book that my friend lent me making me feel like a great friend
label: Contradiction
explanation: When someone loses or misplaces something that has been lent to them by someone else, it often creates tension instead of thrill and makes the person feel like they are not a good friend.

premise: I was still attached to him as he raised his hands in triumph and I laughed.
hypothesis: He raises his hands in triumph as I laugh, still like a leech.
label: Entailment
explanation: A leech is a parasitic creature that attaches itself to a host, and in this case the speaker is saying that they are still attached to the person even though they are laughing.

premise: The bus gradually came to a stop on the road.
hypothesis: The bus drizzled down the road.
label: Entailment
explanation: The bus came to a stop on the road gradually, like a drizzle.

premise: Turns out he was under a lot of debt and finally decided to get away from them.
hypothesis: Turns out he was under a lot of debt and finally decided to gave them the slip.
label: Entailment
explanation: To give someone the slip means to escape from them, which is what he decided to do.

premise: A friend let me borrow some of his old headphones and now I have lost them.
hypothesis: A friend let me borrow his old headphones and now I feel terrible that I lost them
label: Entailment
explanation: Losing something that someone else let you borrow is often seen as very disrespectful and careless so it would make sense for someone to feel terrible after losing something that wasn't even theirs to begin with

premise: I ended up not getting the job and a person with less experience got it.
hypothesis: I was not selected for the job, and it went to somebody with less experience which makes me feel just great
label: Contradiction
explanation: Not getting a job that someone applied for despite having more experience than the other candidate shows that the process of hiring is not fair and is based on other factors rather than merit and should make someone feel bad.

premise: Your brother is mature and behaves in an adult manner.
hypothesis: Your brother is a big baby.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To be a big baby means to be immature and prone to childish behavior, but in this sentence the brother is mature and behaves in an adult manner.

premise: The government barely changed the entire law into a code.
hypothesis: The government flipped the entire law into a code.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To flip something means to turn it upside down or inside out, while to barely change something means to make very little alterations to it.

premise: My head was in the middle of a triangle made by her neck and both her shoulders.
hypothesis: My head dwelled in the crook of her neck.
label: Entailment
explanation: The phrase to be in the crook of someone's neck means to be resting in the space between their neck and shoulder.

premise: My cat just scratched up my brand new leather couch while I was at work.
hypothesis: I am so thrilled that my cat scratched up my brand new leather couch while I was at work
label: Contradiction
explanation: Leather couches are often very expensive and so having them scratched up by a pet is definitely not something to be thrilled about.

premise: My husband dropped my favorite coffee mug this morning.... what a start of the day
hypothesis: My husband totally dropped my favorite coffee mug this morning and it made me so satisfied
label: Contradiction
explanation: It is not normal to feel satisfied when someone breaks something that belongs to you, especially if it is something you really like or is special to you.

premise: My friend would not stop whistling even though she knows I can't stand it.
hypothesis: My friend is really inconsiderate to keep whistling even though she knows I despise the sound
label: Entailment
explanation: If someone knows that another person does not like something and they continue to do it anyway, it is considered inconsiderate

premise: After the vibrant colors of the garden, the stone hall seemed as dark and loud because of the cacophony of noise.
hypothesis: After the vibrant colors of the garden, the stone hall seemed as dark and silent as the grave.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To be silent as the grave is to be totally silent, but this context describes the hall as being full of noise

premise: I saw another woman looking at my boyfriend up and down while we are in line at the store
hypothesis: I saw the woman checking out my boyfriend and it made me feel insanely jealous
label: Entailment
explanation: It is natural to feel jealous when another person is checking out or flirting with your romantic partner right in front of you

premise: Despite lack of activities in the first 40 minutes , Arsenal seemed reasonably secure if not inspired .
hypothesis: Despite many and varied flurries of activity in the first 40 minutes , Arsenal seemed reasonably secure if not inspired .
label: Contradiction
explanation: Despite many and varied flurries of activity in the first 40 minutes refers to a period of time when there was a lot going on, while lack of activities mean there was not much going on.

premise: I really was grossed out when my nephew threw up the other day.
hypothesis: I was totally impressed when my nephew projectile vomited all over the place.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would not be impressed but grossed out by someone projectile vomiting especially because it is a disgusting act.

premise: Can we continue to focus on something that happened in the past, then?.
hypothesis: Can we let bygones be bygones, then?
label: Contradiction
explanation: To let bygones be bygones is to stop focusing on something that happened in the past, but the speaker is suggesting the opposite by saying to continue focusing on it.

premise: Vietnam was wedged good and tight in his brain.
hypothesis: Vietnam was in his brain like a stringy piece of meat caught between his teeth that wouldn't be dislodged for love or money.
label: Entailment
explanation: A stringy piece of meat caught between teeth is something that is stuck, wedged good and tight and will not budge, no matter what.

premise: I think it's tragic what our country is like right now because are falling apart as a society.
hypothesis: It increases my sense of patriotism to see our country is falling apart and becoming a society of ignorance
label: Contradiction
explanation: A country is supposed to be a place of progress and not one which falls apart and becomes a society of ignorance, so being patriotic of that is not justified.

premise: The turkey was really moist
hypothesis: The turkey was as dry as the ocean
label: Entailment
explanation: The ocean is a really big body of water, so the turkey must have been really moist.

premise: If you drink it, it will either kill you or grant you strength and abilities that are mundane.
hypothesis: Drinking it will either kill you, or grant you strength and abilities like an everflowing fountain.
label: Contradiction
explanation: An everflowing fountain is impossible in real life and would be considered a miracle, which means something is extraordinary and not mundane

premise: I asked a girl out for dinner today and she turned me down while a lot of people overheard.
hypothesis: Got turned down by a girl for dinner today in front of a lot of people and feeling really proud of myself.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Being turned down for dinner by a girl in public is not a good thing to experience and so someone feeling proud of themselves for it is nonsensical.

premise: The press is sronger than weapons.
hypothesis: The pen is mightier than the sword.
label: Entailment
explanation: The press is more powerful than weapons because it can expose their wrongdoings to the world.

premise: Unhappy whenever not hungry, not at all frightened whenever a cold wind blows.
hypothesis: Happy whenever not hungry, frightened to the bone whenever a cold wind blows.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To be to the bone is to be very much or to an extreme degree, but in this context the person is not at all frightened when a cold wind blows.

premise: They mentioned the two job interviews, and I confuse them by explaining I'm not ready for employment.
hypothesis: They mention the two job interviews, and I throw a curve by explaining I'm not ready for employment.
label: Entailment
explanation: To throw a curve means to do something unexpected that surprises or confuses someone, and in this context the speaker is surprising the others by saying they're not ready for employment.

premise: My sister had my laundry for two days and is sending it back dirty.
hypothesis: I am livid that my sister had my laundry for two days and couldn't even bother to wash it
label: Entailment
explanation: Its common courtesy to wash someone's clothes if you borrow them and have them for more than a day so its understandable to be angry when someone doesn't do that

premise: My bank ended up charging me hundreds of dollars for something I didn't do.
hypothesis: I was livid when I found out that my bank charged me hundreds of dollars for something I didn't do
label: Entailment
explanation: When someone is charged for something they didn't do, especially when it's a large sum of money, they are likely to be very angry

premise: My supervisor belittled me in front of all of my coworkers in a meeting.
hypothesis: It was such a pleasant feeling when my supervisor embarrassed me in front of all my coworkers during the meeting
label: Contradiction
explanation: Being embarrassed in front of coworkers during a meeting is not something pleasant because it can lead to a decrease in productivity and job satisfaction.

premise: Fifty dollars each is a reasonable price to charge!
hypothesis: Fifty dollars each is daylight robbery!
label: Contradiction
explanation: To commit daylight robbery is to charge an exorbitant price, but this sentence describes a reasonable price

premise: The waiter spilled coffee on my $1000 suit.
hypothesis: The waiter's carelessness didn't make me furious at all when he spilled coffee on my $1000 suit
label: Contradiction
explanation: The suit is a valuable item and so getting coffee spilled on it would cause one to feel furious.

premise: One of my friend didn't keep this promise he made to me.
hypothesis: One of my friends let me down by not following through on the promise he made to me.
label: Entailment
explanation: A promise is a binding agreement between two people and not following through on that agreement often leaves the person who was counting on the promise feeling disappointed and let down

premise: One year I filed false tax forms and I feel really bad about it.
hypothesis: The fact that I committed tax fraud makes me feel like the most ethical person alive
label: Contradiction
explanation: Tax fraud is an illegal act and people who commit it cannot be ethical.

premise: My daughter dropeed an entire carton of eggs in the kitchen.
hypothesis: I was so happy when I saw my daughter had dropped an entire carton of eggs and made a mess in the kitchen
label: Contradiction
explanation: Seeing an eggs mess in the kitchen is usually a very inconvenient and frustrating thing to witness and so someone being happy about it is absurd.

premise: When Kade was a star quarterback, he was very impressive and more exciting than the average person.
hypothesis: When Kade was a star quarterback, he was larger than life.
label: Entailment
explanation: To be larger than life is to be having an aura of greatness, which is what Kade was as a star quarterback.

premise: The situation was fluid and ever-changing.
hypothesis: The situation was cut and dried.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To be cut and dried means to be fixed and determined, but the situation was fluid and ever-changing

premise: I hate it when the waitress bring another table food when I got there first
hypothesis: I feel angry when the waitress brings food to another table when I am the one who got there first
label: Entailment
explanation: The waitress is supposed to bring food to the table that ordered it first and so when she brings food to another table first it can make the people at the first table feel angry because they are not being served in the order they should be

premise: No one rsvped to my birthday party.
hypothesis: I feel really sad and lonely because apparently no one wanted to come to my birthday party
label: Entailment
explanation: Not receiving any RSVPs to a birthday party can be interpreted as no one wanting to come and celebrate with the person which often leads to feelings of sadness and loneliness

premise: The only question was, how would she damage the relationship even further with him, and would he want her back after she had seemed to side with uncle hugh?.
hypothesis: The only question was, how would she mend fences with him, and would he want her back after she had seemed to side with uncle hugh?
label: Contradiction
explanation: To mend fences means to rectify a damaged relationship, but in this context she is trying to damage the relationship even further

premise: Oh, yes, said hopkinson, in the voice of one who considers skills to be very ordinary and commonplace but is well aware of the rarity value of a good bread exhibit.
hypothesis: Oh, yes,said hopkinson, in the voice of one who regards skills as ten a penny but is well aware of the rarity value of a good bread exhibit.
label: Entailment
explanation: To be ten a penny means to be very common or ordinary, and in this context Hopkinson is saying that skills are very ordinary.

premise: Matthias himself was just extremely average.
hypothesis: Matthias himself was just larger than life.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To be larger than life is to be outstandingly great or have an aura of greatness, but in this context Matthias is just extremely average

premise: I just ran out of financial aid for school.
hypothesis: I just found out that I won't be able to afford to go to school anymore because, in my boundless wisdom, I used up all my financial aid
label: Contradiction
explanation: It is not wise to use up all of one's financial aid because it leaves them with no other option but to not attend school, which would be a very unfortunate turn of events.

premise: To ask what's it like to be a warden in d.c., Hunting down the bad guys and bringing them to justice as well as everything else that is related.
hypothesis: To ask what's it like to be a warden in d.c., Hunting down the bad guys and bringing them to justice and all that jazz.
label: Entailment
explanation: And all that jazz means and everything else, so in this sentence it is referring to everything else that is related to being a warden in D.C.

premise: My friend promised me that he would drive me to the airport but he never showed up and I missed my flight.
hypothesis: My friend never showed up to drive me to the airport and as a result of his irresponsibility, I missed my flight
label: Entailment
explanation: When someone makes a promise they are expected to follow through with it, especially if it is something important like driving someone to the airport

premise: If it was the other way around, she'd tell you to go away.
hypothesis: If it was the other way around, she'd tell you to sling your hook.
label: Entailment
explanation: To sling your hook means to go away, so if it was the other way around she would tell him to go away.

premise: The patient was relaxed.
hypothesis: The patient was as relaxed as a soldier in the trenches.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Soldiers in the trenches are not usually very relaxed, so the simile is ironic

premise: Allister knows nothing about wine, he is a teetotaler.
hypothesis: Allister drinks Bordeaux often.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The act of drinking Bordeaux wine would require some knowledge about wine, specifically about the types of wines available, thus Allister cannot be a teetotaler and drink Bordeaux wine often.

premise: I forgot to bring in the slides for the presnetation so I ended up having an awkward experience tring to do it with no materials.
hypothesis: I felt like a genius trying to do a presentation without any slides
label: Contradiction
explanation: A presentation without slides is usually very difficult to do and so trying to do one shows lack of intelligence.

premise: I ordered a hamburger from a restaurant and it was raw in the middle.
hypothesis: I was so glad that my hamburger arrived raw in the middle
label: Contradiction
explanation: A hamburger is supposed to be cooked all the way through and so receiving one that is still raw in the middle would be a terrible experience.

premise: The internet is failing a lot I feel bad about that.
hypothesis: I can't help but love that the internet is always failing and I feel amazing because of it.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Having the internet not working properly is really frustrating and not something to feel amazing about.

premise: As the looks they gave her.
hypothesis: At the looks they  cast  upon her ,
label: Entailment
explanation: Cast  means to throw or to project.

premise: It quickly became apparent to pretty much everyone that the only viable option was to leave and move to a new place.
hypothesis: It quickly became apparent to pretty much everyone that the only viable option was to up sticks.
label: Entailment
explanation: To up sticks means to relocate from one's current residence, so the context is saying that the only option is to leave and move to a new place.

premise: I totally fell off my diet wagon this past weekend by eating a whole ice cream sundae by myself.
hypothesis: I feel extremely proud of myself for succumbing to my cravings and eating an entire ice cream sundae by myself
label: Contradiction
explanation: Giving in to cravings and eating an entire ice cream sundae by oneself is not a good thing because it can lead to weight gain and a feeling of guilt.

premise: When the weatherman predicts flurries, you'd better get ready for tough times, especially in December.
hypothesis: When the weatherman predicta flurries, you'd better batten down the hatch, esespecially in December.
label: Entailment
explanation: To batten down the hatches means to prepare for difficult times, which is what the person in this sentence is doing.

premise: Your guardian angel is just a little too enthusiastic
hypothesis: Your guardian angel is just a little too much like a kid on Christmas morning.
label: Entailment
explanation: A kid on Christmas morning is very enthusiastic and excited about the holiday and so the guardian angel is just a little too enthusiastic.

premise: Her hair was almost dark
hypothesis: Her hair was almost like a raven's wing
label: Entailment
explanation: A raven's wing is very dark, so if her hair is like a raven's wing, it is very dark as well.

premise: My friend was so scared that he became pale and speechless after the violent storm.
hypothesis: When I looked at my friend after the storm he was a ghost.
label: Entailment
explanation: A ghost would be pale and unable to speak, so he was a ghost is a metaphor for being pale and speechless.

premise: He had gotten close enough to her to trap her in a corner of her gallery, and he caught a whiff of her disgustingly foul fragnance.
hypothesis: He'd gotten near enough to her once, trapping her in a corner of her gallery, to catch a fragrance that smelled like an exotic tropical flower .
label: Contradiction

premise: That opportunity may be completely over.

premise: But on the subject of appearing to own a stolen horse, he still managed to come up with a compelling defense.
hypothesis: But on the subject of appearing to own a stolen horse, he had rincewind bang to rights and, also, a foot on his neck.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To be bang to rights means to have irrefutable proof of wrongdoing, but in this sentence the person manages to come up with a defense

premise: I spent a few hundred dollars on a purse which is a lot for me and it started fraying in days.
hypothesis: I can't believe how sturdy the purse I bought for a few hundred dollars is and that it started fraying in days
label: Contradiction
explanation: A purse that is sturdy and costs a few hundred dollars should not start fraying in a few days but owing to the fact that it frayed means it is not made of good quality material.

premise: I really hate when people play their music really loud during the week at 3 am
hypothesis: I adore it when people blast their music during the week at 3am and disrupt my sleep
label: Contradiction
explanation: People blasting their music during the wee hours of the morning is often disruptive and prevent someone from getting a good night's sleep and hence it should not be admired.

premise: I don't know why some people waste their talents and life.
hypothesis: It's really great how some people never use their talents and life to the fullest
label: Contradiction
explanation: Everyone has some talents and it is often a waste when people do not use them to their potential and instead lead a mundane life which does not reflect well on the human race.

premise: She longed for another journey during her middle age.

label: Contradiction
explanation: The word dull is used to imply something that is not exciting or interesting, here, to mean her interntion for traveling, while in the contradiction, longed is used to imply a strong desire for something.

premise: Bones was cheerily unwrapping Sergio from his plastic shroud.
hypothesis: Bones unwrapped sergio from his plastic shroud like a child ripping through wrapping paper on christmas.
label: Entailment
explanation: A child on Christmas is excited to rip through the wrapping paper to get to their present, and Bones is excited to unwrap Sergio from the shroud.

premise: Every Thanksgiving I eat alone.
hypothesis: It's always so depressing to spend Thanksgiving alone

explanation: Thanksgiving is typically a holiday where people spend time with family and friends and so eating alone on Thanksgiving can often be a very depressing experience

premise: The voice sounded strange and robotic on the other end of the phone line.

explanation: A mechanical construct is an artificial object, so it would make sense that the voice sounded strange and robotic.

premise: I saw a piece of dried poop from my dog in my closet that I had no clue about.
hypothesis: I found a piece of poop from my dog that I had no idea about and it wasn't disgusting at all
label: Contradiction
explanation: A piece of poop from a dog is often dirty and full of bacteria and so finding it unexpectedly can only lead to disgust.

premise: I'm sad because I have no friends and I don't like my own company.
hypothesis: I feel really terrible because I don't have any friends to talk to and I also don't like spending time with myself
label: Entailment
explanation: Its often said that humans are social animals and need companionship to feel happy

premise: He had gotten close enough to her to trap her in a corner of her gallery, and he caught a whiff of her wonderfully rich fragrance.
hypothesis: He'd gotten near enough to her once, trapping her in a corner of her gallery, to catch a fragrance that smelled like an exotic tropical flower .
label: Entailment
explanation: A tropical flower would have a rich fragrance, hence the simile.

premise: My son raided the snack cupboard before dinnertime, eating all my favourite snacks, and he made a mess out of it.
hypothesis: My son ate all my favourite snacks before dinner and made a huge mess of the cupboard in the process
label: Entailment
explanation: Having your favourite snacks eaten before dinner by someone else is often very frustrating, especially if they make a mess in the process

premise: Your suspicion is accurate.

premise: The measures which were announced have affected the economy.

premise: He was doing this intentionally; trying to make her angry or irritated by teasing her.
hypothesis: He was doing this on purpose; trying to get a rise out of her.
label: Entailment
explanation: To get a rise out of someone means to provoke an angry or irritated response, which is what he was trying to do by teasing her.

premise: When I gave sloane an opportunity and walked back to be with lucah, I felt as if I was being torn in half.

premise: I was afraid to see a guy holding a knife toward me

label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would be scared when they see someone walking towards them with a knife and hence would not be cool as a cucumber in that situation.

premise: She's now had to temporarily stop.

explanation: To put on hold means to temporarily stop an activity, which is what she's had to do.

premise: My boss just bought a new Mercedes, and I can only afford public transport

explanation: A new Mercedes car is a very expensive purchase and so the fact that someone's boss can afford it implies that they are very wealthy, while someone who can only afford public transport is likely living paycheck to paycheck and feels jealous.

premise: If you want to gossip, leave this place immediately and drink somewhere else.

explanation: To sling your hook means to go away, so the speaker is telling the person that if they want to gossip they should leave and go drink somewhere else.

premise: The place was dark and dirty .

premise: I went to pick up my car from the mechanic and found a huge scratch on the side!

label: Contradiction
explanation: Getting the car back from the mechanic with an enormous scratch on it would not make anyone joyful and instead be a cause for anger or frustration.

premise: The only reason he wanted to marry her was out of spite.

label: Entailment
explanation: A child demanding a particular toy because some other child had it is usually immature and the simile here portrays the fact that the only reason he wanted to marry her was out of spite like a kid

premise: If that time doesn't come then we wait for others to join us before proceeding.

premise: That movie was not disturbing
hypothesis: That movie was as disturbing as puppies
label: Entailment
explanation: puppies are not disturbing, they are cute so the movie was not disturbing

premise: I bought some cheap stocks hoping that they would go up in price but they didn't.

label: Contradiction
explanation: Buying stocks for cheap and then them not going up in price means that the person has no financial skills and so should not be proud of themselves.

premise: The scream grew louder and sharper with each second, and I took two steps towards it.
hypothesis: I'd taken only two steps when a thin scream sounded like a train's whiny whistle .
label: Entailment
explanation: A train's whistle gets louder and sharper as it approaches, so the scream must have been louder and sharper with each second.

premise: I get so annoyed at my husband when he leaves his dirty clothing on the floor.
hypothesis: I feel really calm when my husband leaves his dirty clothes on the floor.

explanation: Dirty clothes on the floor are often an indicator of a lack of cleanliness and can cause someone to feel disgust or anger.

premise: I've reached my limit of patience.

explanation: Reached my boiling point means that I am so angry and frustrated that I can't take it anymore.

premise: I was feeling pretty much alone when I didn't see my boyfriend for two days.

premise: It made me want to sink into the floor after I accidentally spilled my drink on my friend at dinner.
hypothesis: The moment I spilled my drink on my friend at dinner made me feel like the biggest idiot in the world
label: Entailment
explanation: Spilling a drink on someone by accident is often seen as embarrassing and rude so it's natural to feel like the biggest idiot in the world in that moment

premise: He was feeling energetic.
hypothesis: He was feeling like a lone survivor returning from the battlefield.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A battlefield is a site of destruction, with many people dying, so a lone survivor would likely feel traumatized, not energetic

premise: Me and this girl on Tinder were going really steady, then out of the blue she flat out ghosted me.

label: Contradiction

premise: I'm drunk and so I might not be able to think or speak clearly.
hypothesis: NoYou must excuse me, I'm a bit tired and emotional just now.
label: Entailment
explanation: To be tired and emotional is a semi-polite or humorous euphemism for drunkenness, which explains why the person might not be able to think or speak clearly.

premise: It wasn't glib or run of the mill ,it was immediately ignored and dismissed after being heard.
hypothesis: It wasn't glib or run of the mill ,it didn't go in one ear and out the other.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The idiom in one ear and out the other is used to describe something that is essentially ignored or dismissed after being heard which is what being contradicted in this context by saying that it was immediately ignored and dismissed, the opposite of it didn't go in one ear and out the other.
idiom: in one ear and out the other

premise: Their honey moon was a nightmare.
hypothesis: Their honey moon was a dream.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A honey moon is typically seen as a happy and romantic time, while a nightmare is a bad dream that is full of fear and terror.

premise: My sister gets to stay out as late as she wants but I have to be in at 8 PM
hypothesis: I hate that my sister gets to stay out as late as she wants while I have to be in at 8 PM
label: Entailment
explanation: It's unfair that one person gets to have more freedom than the other and in this case, the sister gets to stay out later even though the curfew for both should be the same

premise: I had to give my pet up for adoption because my new apartment wouldn't take them.
hypothesis: It feels so fantastic that I had to give my pet up for adoption because my new apartment wouldn't take them
label: Contradiction
explanation: Pets are often considered to be part of the family and so someone having to give them up for adoption due to external factors such as moving to a new apartment is really sad and not fantastic at all.

premise: Can I just ask one thing before we get to the most important and essential part of our visit?
hypothesis: Can I just ask one thing before we get to the meat and potatoes of our visit?
label: Entailment
explanation: The meat and potatoes of something refers to the most important and essential part of something, which is what the speaker is asking about.

premise: Wendy had cooked dick hallorann's turkey for too long and they had all eaten to bursting without even coming close to demolishing the jolly bird.
hypothesis: Wendy had cooked dick hallorann's turkey to a turn and they had all eaten to bursting without even coming close to demolishing the jolly bird.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To cook something to a turn means to cook it for exactly the right amount of time, but in this context Wendy cooked it for too long

premise: I have been unfaithful to my spouse and have been lying about it.

label: Entailment
explanation: Cheating on a spouse is often considered to be a very bad thing to do and people who have done it often feel guilty and lie about it to their spouse

premise: He was working with the same corporations that had created a huge and irreversible impact on phoebe.
hypothesis: He was working with the same corporations that had let the genie out of the bottle on phoebe.
label: Entailment
explanation: To let the genie out of the bottle means to create or unleash something that creates a huge impact and cannot be stopped or reversed and that was what the company he was working for did to Phoebe.
idiom: let the genie out of the bottle

premise: I made me a bowl of cereal today and when I started eating I realized milk was spoiled
hypothesis: When I started eating my cereal I realized the milk was spoiled and it made me feel so excited
label: Contradiction
explanation: Spoiled milk is often sour and has an unpleasant odor, so finding out that the milk for cereal is spoiled would not make someone feel excited.

premise: Such an excessively silent night.

label: Entailment
explanation: When the noiseless night  descended means when it became very quiet outside.

premise: The few staff who are still with us are growing tired of the empty promises of something better in the future, while having to endure longer hours with less pay.

label: Entailment
explanation: The idiom jam tomorrow means an empty promise of something that will never arrive, and in this context the staff are growing tired of those kinds of promises.

premise: If a great deal of labor would be required to realize such a project, dragon strength could finish or dispose of very quickly or handily.
hypothesis: If a great deal of labor would be required to realize such a project, dragon strength could make light work of that.
label: Entailment
explanation: To make light work of something is to deal with it quickly or handily, which is what the dragon strength would be able to do.

premise: So I hauled him in, and quent put him in a position to be very comfortable for questioning and processing.
hypothesis: So I hauled him in, and quent put him on ice for questioning and processing.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To be on ice means to be detained or confined in isolation, but in this context quent put him in a position of comfort

premise: Time stood still, the world was static.
hypothesis: Time stood still, the world was like a bizarre carnival ride .
label: Contradiction
explanation: A carnival ride is in constant motion, whereas the world being static would imply that time has stopped

premise: I'm jealous of people who live in a warm climate all year long. Must be nice.
hypothesis: Not at all envious of people who enjoy perfect warm climate where they don't have to go through the pain of bundling up in the winter
label: Contradiction
explanation: People who live in warm climates where they don't have to bundle up in the winter are lucky because the experience of bundling up is often very unpleasant.

premise: I recently ordered something online, and expected it to arrive last week and it's still not here!
hypothesis: I am so thrilled that the online order I placed still has not arrived even after a week!
label: Contradiction
explanation: An online order that has not arrived even after a week is very late and disappointing and not something to be thrilled about.

premise: He knew how to write down something nice and pleasant.
hypothesis: He knew how to write sweet words.
label: Entailment
explanation: Sweet words means something that is kind and pleasant words.

premise: The boy was trying to reach the highest shelf, not stretching his arm at all, but couldn't achieve it.
hypothesis: The boy was trying to reach the highest shelf, stretching his arm to the maximum, but couldn't achieve it.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To the max means to the highest level or degree, but in this context the boy was not stretching his arm at all

premise: A year earlier, I probably would have made a sarcastic and cutting comment about them finally doing the right thing.
hypothesis: A year earlier, I probably would have made a smart aleck comment about them finally doing the right thing.
label: Entailment
explanation: A smart alec is someone who uses sarcasm in an attempt to be witty, and that is what the speaker would have done a year earlier.

premise: Stock prices are increasing more and more.

hypothesis: Whom fate has slapped with a weight of woes.
label: Entailment
explanation: Slapped with a weight of woes means that the person has been hit with a lot of problems.

premise: The clouds stopped and stagnated each other in the sky.
hypothesis: The clouds waltzed each other around in the sky.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To waltz around something means to move or dance gracefully around it, while to stop and stagnate something means to cause it to become motionless or stagnant.

premise: Thus disasters were prevalent only one at a time.
hypothesis: So disasters  come  not singly .
label: Contradiction
explanation: Disasters come not singly mean more than one disaster can happen at a time where by prevalent only one at a time mean disasters occur individually.

premise: My family and I were finally getting to go on vacation for the first time in 5 years but we had to cancel because we all got horribly sick.
hypothesis: We had to cancel our long-awaited family vacation because we all got wonderfully sick and ruined the trip
label: Contradiction

premise: My neighbors dog does not shut up at night and it's agitating me.
hypothesis: I feel great about my neighbors lovely dog barking all freaking night and helping me keep calm.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Barking dogs are often a nuisance and can disturb people's peace and so someone who feels great about their dog barking all night is not rational.

premise: That word has completely captured my heart!
hypothesis: I'm sick to death of that word!
label: Contradiction
explanation: To be sick to death of something means to be totally disgusted with it, but the context describes being captured by the word instead

premise: I start to walk across the room recklessly.
hypothesis: I start to prowl across the room like a tightrope walker on dental floss.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A tightrope walker is very careful and deliberate in their movements, so saying someone is prowling like one would imply they are being cautious

hypothesis: She knew she was burning in shame.
label: Contradiction

premise: I am sad it is my birthday and I feel really sick
hypothesis: I like feeling really sick and also not being able to enjoy my birthday
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would not like to feel sick and not be able to enjoy their birthday and so someone saying that they like it is being sarcastic

premise: But this other world wants to be known, it doesn't want to remain hidden.
hypothesis: But this other world doesn't want to be known, it wants to remain like an underground cult.
label: Contradiction
explanation: An underground cult is a secret society that is not known by many people, so if this other world wants to remain like an underground cult, it means it wants to stay hidden

hypothesis: My step brother's decision to sell my laptop in order to buy a new gaming station makes me love him
label: Contradiction
explanation: Losing a laptop, which is usually an important item for most people, in order to buy a gaming station, which is a luxury item, does not make someone love their step brother but instead resent them.

premise: He eagerly looks around the room as he sits up on the mattress.
hypothesis: He sits up on the mattress, looking around like a kid sitting in front of a christmas tree.
label: Entailment
explanation: A kid sitting in front of a christmas tree is excited and looking around eagerly, just as the person in the simile is.

premise: When I moved into my apartment it was full of bugs
hypothesis: I absolutely loved when I moved into my apartment and found it crawling with bugs.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Bugs are usually disgusting and most people are terrified of them therefore it is unlikely to love seeing someone's apartment infested by them.

hypothesis: Got my car towed when I was getting coffee for my boss and now I have to pay a fee
label: Entailment

label: Contradiction

premise: I really don't like it when people talk on the phone when at the movies.
hypothesis: I think it's inconsiderate when people talk on the phone during a movie and disrupt everyone's experience
label: Entailment
explanation: People go to the movies to watch the movie and not to listen to other people's conversation so they don't like it when other talk on the phone and its inconsiderate of the people who disrupt the movie watching experience by doing so.

premise: I got a speeding ticket because I was going too fast.
hypothesis: I feel ashamed of myself that I was caught going too fast and got a speeding ticket as a result
label: Entailment
explanation: Getting a speeding ticket is often seen as a result of bad decision making and can be embarrassing so it is natural for someone to feel ashamed after receiving one

hypothesis: When I wake up, I feel great about all the unhappy memories that occurred in the past few years
label: Contradiction

premise: His hair was very thick.

label: Contradiction

premise: On to the very edge and claim a blighted kiss, there to  find someone who is not as good as you are, beyond the dark abyss.
hypothesis: On to the very edge and claim a blighted kiss, there to meet your match, beyond the dark abyss.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To meet your match means to find someone who is as good as you are, but in this context the speaker is looking for someone who is not as good as them.

label: Contradiction
explanation: A cheerleader is supposed to be peppy and enthusiastic, whereas someone on crack would be high and have erratic behavior, so a cheerleader on crack would be even more enthusiastic  and upbeat

premise: Cigarettes cured his cancer.
hypothesis: The cigarettes rained on his health.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Cigarettes are known to cause cancer, while cancer is a disease that is cured.

hypothesis: The snow was not deep, but being alone combined with the grandeur of the mountain she felt like an ant marching across an enormous crater.
label: Entailment
explanation: An ant is a very small creature, and feeling like one would indicate feeling very small and insignificant.

premise: The jacket kept me warm
hypothesis: The jacket was as warm as a winter night
label: Contradiction
explanation: A winter night is very cold, so the jacket being as warm as a winter night would mean it is extremely cold, not just warm

hypothesis: His eyes bore into me like a bunsen burner flame .
label: Contradiction
explanation: A bunsen burner flame is very hot, so if his eyes are like that, they would be burning into me, not be cold and distant

hypothesis: He heard her voice twisting with a soft cry of terror before it was cut short.
label: Entailment
explanation: To be cut short means to be ended abruptly and unexpectedly, which is what happened to her voice in this sentence.

hypothesis: My husband totally dropped my favorite coffee mug this morning and it made me so mad
label: Entailment

premise: My ipad is locked because my son kept putting in the wrong passcode.

label: Contradiction
explanation: A son putting in the wrong passcode and locking an ipad is not a good thing because it denies access to the owner of the device.

premise: I am so mad my landlord is selling the house so I have to move.
hypothesis: I am so thrilled that my landlord is selling the house and making me move
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people do not enjoy moving and find it to be a hassle, so someone who is thrilled about it is definitely not being truthful.

premise: My wife is going to divorce me.
hypothesis: I am super stoke that my wife is going to leave me because of the massive excellent debt I have
label: Contradiction
explanation: Owing a lot of money can lead to a separation or divorce and so someone being stoked about that prospect is not at all logical.

premise: He spent three years seconded to an industry that was not doing well and needed assistance.
hypothesis: He spent three years seconded to a lame duck industry.
label: Entailment
explanation: A lame duck is someone or something that needs help, and in this context the industry is not doing well and needs assistance.

premise: The boy's handwriting was very messy.
hypothesis: The boy's handwriting was as organized as a rollercoaster
label: Entailment
explanation: A rollercoaster is a very chaotic and messy structure, so the simile is saying that the handwriting is very messy.

premise: During gym class today but pants split wide open and eveyone saw my underwear.
hypothesis: Absolutely loved the highlight of the gym class today when my pants suddenly split open and everyone saw my underwear
label: Contradiction

premise: After giving it a lot of thought and careful consideration, describe John.
hypothesis: Right off the top of your head, describe john.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To do something off the top of your head means to do it from memory or without much consideration, but this context is asking for the opposite by giving a lot of thought and consideration.
idiom: off the top of your head

premise: The tears both cheered her up and made her feel worse at the same time.
hypothesis: The tears cut both ways.
label: Entailment
explanation: To cut both ways means to have good and bad effects at the same time, and in this sentence the tears made the person feel both better and worse.

premise: My boss embarrassed me infront of the investors.

label: Entailment

premise: The predators never expected their enemies to be this indestructible.

premise: They sat down at the table to quickly finish pansy's dinner.

premise: A voice soft and gentle

label: Contradiction
explanation: To think in for a penny, in for a pound means that if you have committed to doing something, you should do it completely without sparing any effort, but in this context the person is deliberating carefully.

hypothesis: But on the subject of appearing to own a stolen horse, he had rincewind bang to rights and, also, a foot on his neck.

explanation: To be bang to rights means to have irrefutable proof of wrongdoing, which in this sentence is the act of appearing to own a stolen horse.

premise: He was calm

premise: I was calm and grounded at all times.

label: Entailment

label: Contradiction

label: Contradiction

hypothesis: Got turned down by a girl for dinner today in front of a lot of people and hence feeling really embarrassed
label: Entailment

label: Contradiction

label: Contradiction

premise: I wanted to get money, but the ATM did not work.

premise: He crushed remorse and pushed down despair.

premise: He felt a deep sense of fullness in his chest.

premise: I rented out my house and when I came back it was filthy.

label: Contradiction

premise: I accidentally left the lights on in my car and killed the battery

label: Entailment
explanation: Its common knowledge that leaving the lights on in a car will kill the battery and so when people find out that they have done so and their car won't start as a result, they are often annoyed with themselves

premise: The surface of Mars was wilting and dying.

label: Contradiction
explanation: The Garden of Eden is a paradise, while a wilting and dying surface would be the opposite

premise: All of my friends are married and I can't even get a decent boyfriend.

label: Contradiction
explanation: It is not great that all of one's friends are married and have children because it implies that the person is unable to find a partner themselves and is envious of those who are able to.

premise: Because of this all interstellar species evolved on gas giants and thought earth was habitable.
hypothesis: Because of this, all interstellar species evolved on gas giants and thought earth was like a barren wasteland.

premise: I was at my friends party last weekend, and someone threw up in the hot tub!
hypothesis: It was totally vile when I was at my friends party last weekend, and someone threw up in the hot tub
label: Entailment
explanation: Being in close proximity to someone who is vomiting is often considered to be very disgusting and vile

premise: The cigarettes affected his health.

label: Entailment

premise: My bank somehow charged me for a credit card I didn't want.

label: Entailment
explanation: It is very frustrating when a bank charges someone for a service that they never even wanted and did not sign up for so it is understandable to be livid about it

premise: I was driving through the parking lot the other day and someone backed into my new SUV!

label: Contradiction

explanation: To let the cat out of the bag means to reveal a secret by accident, but in this context my mother deliberately kept my intentions a secret.

premise: She began to knock feverishly as if she had to take her time and not worry about finishing before the deadline.

label: Contradiction

premise: I get anxious whenever I'm waiting in line for a flight and it's less than 30 minutes from take off.
hypothesis: I always feel cool, calm and collected when I am waiting in line for a flight and it's close to take off time.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Waiting in line for a flight especially close to take off time is often very frustrating because there are so many people and the wait is usually long and there are chances of missing the flight, so feeling cool, calm and collected in that situation is not very likely.

premise: I failed my Calculus exam despite having studied all nights.
hypothesis: I am really upset that I couldn't pass my Calculus exam despite studying so hard
label: Entailment
explanation: To study for an exam and not be able to pass it despite putting in a lot of effort makes people upset because they will have to study and reappear for the exam again

premise: I found out my storage unit burned down and I had lost several irreplaceable items
hypothesis: I found out my storage unit burned down and I had lost several valuable items
label: Entailment
explanation: When a storage unit burns down, the items inside are often lost and if those items are valuable or even irreplaceable, it can be a very difficult situation for the owner

premise: Mildly, it began to draw him in
hypothesis: like a psychic whirlpool , it began to draw him in.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A whirlpool is a strong current, so a psychic whirlpool drawing in indicates that it was drawing him in intensely, rather than mildly.

premise: I was holding my breath, waiting to see what would be in front of me, and I almost screamed when I saw his bald head, it was so dull.
hypothesis: I held my breath, waiting for what my gaze would fall upon, and I almost shrieked as I stared at his head, bald like a lamp post.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A lamp post is usually made out of metal and is very shiny, not dull

premise: I wish I had my neighbors nice new car.
hypothesis: I am not at all jealous of my neighbors who just got an beautiful brand new car.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would be jealous of their neighbors if they got a new car because it is a sign of privilege and wealth, which the speaker clearly does not feel.

premise: There is no golden light surrounded the red brick house today.
hypothesis: No golden light bathed the red brick of the house .
label: Entailment
explanation: Bathed means to be surrounded by something, in this case, light.

premise: Me and my partner were in disagreement in the shopping mall and everyone was watching us
hypothesis: I was so embarrassed when me and my partner were having a disagreement in the shopping mall and everyone was watching us
label: Entailment
explanation: It is embarrassing to have a disagreement in public because it shows that you are not getting along and people are often curious about other people's disagreements

premise: The house was so dark, silent and dreary.
hypothesis: The house was a tomb.
label: Entailment
explanation: A tomb is a dark, silent and dreary place.

premise: I went to buy a 42 inch tv at walmart, the billboard says 299 usd, it was at 399 usd after taxes.
hypothesis: The fact that I went to buy a 42 inch TV at Walmart and found out the price was raised from $299 to $399 after taxes made me really disappointed
label: Entailment
explanation: People often rely on advertised prices to make purchasing decisions and when the actual price is significantly higher it often leads to feelings of disappointment

premise: We have to be self-reliant and not rely on others.
hypothesis: We can lean on this man.
label: Contradiction
