explanation: Being given credit to a different person for someone else's work is never a good thing and so someone who was proud about it is not rational.

premise: We refused money into the education of our children.
hypothesis: We streamed money into the education of our children.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To stream something means to supply it in a continuous flow, while to refuse something means to reject or decline it.

premise: The place is secluded, away from the frequently traveled routes and not well-known, very peaceful.
hypothesis: The place is off the beaten track, very peaceful.
label: Entailment
explanation: To be off the beaten track means to be away from the frequently traveled routes, and in this context the place is also described as being little-known or in a remote area.

premise: He looked modern and civilized.
hypothesis: He looked like a prowling animal .
label: Contradiction
explanation: Prowling animals are usually wild and not domesticated, so they are not usually perceived as looking modern and civilized

premise: I applied for a loan to buy a house from the bank but didn't get it.
hypothesis: I was really hopeful about getting the loan to buy my dream house, but luckily the bank rejected me
label: Contradiction
explanation: Applying for a loan and then getting rejected is not a favorable outcome because it means that the person will not be able to buy their dream house and cannot be considered as a sign of good luck.

premise: My supervisor took all the credit for a new client I brought in without even recognizing that I was involved.
hypothesis: My supervisor is such a genius for taking all the credit for a new client I brought in without even mentioning my involvement
label: Contradiction
explanation: A supervisor taking credit for a new client that an employee brought in is unfair and shows that the supervisor is not a genius but rather ignorant and inconsiderate.

premise: The violin concerto sounded absurd after the danger we had just passed.
hypothesis: Given the danger that had just passed, the delicate staccato notes of the violin concerto sounded like a wedding march at a funeral.
label: Entailment
explanation: A wedding march is a happy occasion, while a funeral is a somber occasion so a wedding march at a funeral is absurd which is used to draw comparison to the violin concern right after a dangerous event.

premise: I work very hard, some of my friends have no idea what hard work is yet they have so much.
hypothesis: I work so hard, and it's amazing how some of my friends have no idea what fun 'hard work' really is because they are blessed by being born into wealth
label: Contradiction
explanation: Being born into wealth is not a good thing because it gives people an unfair advantage and makes them ungrateful for all the opportunities they have been given in life and hence it isn't amazing to not have an idea on what it means to work hard.

premise: I ordered food almost two hours ago and it's still not here ugh!
hypothesis: I'm so angry that the food I ordered almost two hours ago still hasn't arrived
label: Entailment
explanation: When people order food, they generally expect it to arrive in a timely manner and so when it doesn't it often leads to frustration and anger

premise: He knows how to dangle half-truths in front of cops and das and get them to agree with him.
hypothesis: He knows how to dangle half-truths in front of cops and das and get them to sign on the dotted line.
label: Entailment
explanation: To sign on the dotted line means to indicate one's agreement to something, and in this context the person is agreeing with the half-truths.

premise: One time I fell down the stairs at school in front of a big group of female students.
hypothesis: I was thrilled when I tripped and fell down the stairs in front of a big group of female students
label: Contradiction
explanation: Tripping and falling down the stairs is a very embarrassing thing to do and so someone being thrilled of it is highly implausible.

premise: I work very hard, some of my friends have no idea what hard work is yet they have so much.
hypothesis: I work so hard, and it isn't unfair at all how some of my friends have no idea what 'hard work' really is because they are born into privilege
label: Contradiction
explanation: Being born into wealth is not a good thing because it gives people an unfair advantage without having to work for it and makes them ungrateful for all the opportunities they have been given in life.

premise: She couldn't handle jail; she'd lose her mind.
hypothesis: She couldn't handle jail; she'd go bananas.
label: Entailment
explanation: To go bananas means to become irrational or crazy, and in this sentence she would become irrational if she had to go to jail.

premise: I am mad that my sister always asks me to babysit but never does it for me
hypothesis: I feel loved and enjoy the fact that my sister never reciprocates by babysitting for me.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would feel loved when someone offers to babysit for them and their sister not reciprocating implies that she does not love or care for her sibling.

premise: My brother ordered a pizza with ham and pineapple on it and it was so gross.
hypothesis: My brother's decision to order a pizza with ham and pineapple on it was pretty tantalizing
label: Contradiction
explanation: Ham and pineapple are not two ingredients that go well together and so the brother's decision to order a pizza with that combination was not a wise one.

premise: Till it acquired the form and features.
hypothesis: Till it took the form and features.
label: Entailment
explanation: Took means to get or to receive something, so, in this case, the thing that is being received is the form and features of something.

premise: I feel badly about wanting to have a child when we are not in a good place financially
hypothesis: I feel delighted about the decision of wanting to have a child might given how our situation is financially
label: Contradiction
explanation: Having a child is a huge responsibility and it should not be done if the parents are not in a stable financial situation because that could put the child in a difficult position.

premise: he was happy
hypothesis: He was as depressed as a kid on his birthday
label: Entailment
explanation: The simile is saying that the person is happy, because a kid is happy on their birthday.

premise: The first thing I noticed when I walked in the room was the black leather chair behind the desk- it was narrow and uncomfortable looking.
hypothesis: Before I could do or look at anything else, I noticed the chair behind the desk-black leather and looking like a football player's shoulders.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A football player's shoulders are broad, so the chair would not be narrow, and it would be comfortable because it would be able to accomodate more people

premise: Even though it was obscene, she couldn't help but be fascinated by it.
hypothesis: It was obscene, but she was drawn to it, like a moth to a flame.
label: Entailment
explanation: A moth is irresistibly attracted to a flame, even though it knows that the flame will ultimately destroy it.

premise: My wife is so cranky today
hypothesis: My wife has been extra crabby today and it's kinda getting on my nerves
label: Entailment
explanation: When someone is said to be 'cranky' it usually means that they are in a bad mood and are snapping at people more easily which can be irritating for those around them

premise: My heart beats a bit faster when he walks in the room.
hypothesis: My heart skips when he walks in the room.
label: Entailment
explanation: My heart skips a beat means that I get butterflies in my stomach when I see the person I like.

premise: My brother broke my bike.
hypothesis: My brother totally wrecking my bike makes me wanna hug him out of appreciation.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Having your bike wrecked by someone would lead to frustration and anger instead of appreciation and a desire to hug them.

premise: I don't approve of apolitical jokes; I have seen too many of them get elected.
hypothesis: I don't approve of political jokes; I have seen too many of them get elected.
label: Contradiction
explanation: In one statement the speaker saying they don't approve jokes about political issues and in the other they don't approve jokes that are not involved with politics.

premise: This story, however, is about a god who is useless.
hypothesis: This tale, however, speaks of a god who's as incompetent as a wagon without wheels.
label: Entailment
explanation: A wagon without wheels is completely useless and cannot perform its intended function.

premise: The force helped the civilians to re-establish in 1915.
hypothesis: The force erased the civilians in 1915.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The two sentences contradict each other because one describe the force erased the civilians where in the other it states the force helped the civilians to re-establish.

premise: I got really mad yesterday because my husband made a huge mess in the house.
hypothesis: I was so angry yesterday because my husband created such a huge mess in the house
label: Entailment
explanation: It is really frustrating when somebody makes a mess and doesn't clean it up, especially if it's in your own house

premise: People are always parking in front of my apartment.
hypothesis: I just love it when people always park in front of my apartment
label: Contradiction
explanation: People parking in front of someone's apartment often blocks their way and leaves no space for the other cars, so it is not a proud thing to have people do that.

premise: Her optimism actually made me believe in a brighter future.
hypothesis: Her optimism stole away these worries.
label: Entailment
explanation: Optimism is a state of mind where someone believes that things will work out for the best, so, in this case, the speaker's optimism has made him forget about his worries and believe in a brighter future.

premise: I drank too much soda, so now my teeth look bad.
hypothesis: I drank too much soda and now my teeth look terrible
label: Entailment
explanation: Drinking too much soda can lead to tooth decay and other dental problems, so it's not surprising that someone's teeth would look bad if they drank a lot of soda

premise: Floors were flooded with water.
hypothesis: Water galloped down all over the floor.
label: Entailment
explanation: Galloped means to move quickly or run and usually flooded with water means that the water flowed at a very high speed.

premise: I used the internet to help me write a paper once because I didn't read the literature.
hypothesis: I had to use the internet as a crutch because I am such a genius for skimming through the literature and not doing any of the reading
label: Contradiction
explanation: The internet should not be used as a crutch because it is a tool that can provide quick and easy answers to questions and therefore people who rely on it heavily are considered lazy and not geniuses

premise: Despite leaving to sulk, Eli was returning with a bag of scavenged valuable and important items.
hypothesis: Despite leaving to sulk, eli was returning with a bag of scavenged odds and ends.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Odds and ends are small miscellaneous items that are not important or valuable, but in this context eli is returning with a bag of such items that are valuable and important.

premise: She had known the fru wanted her tested, but she hadn't believed they'd take such an extreme step as to contact her mom.
hypothesis: She had known the fru wanted her tested, but she hadn't believed they'd go so far as to contact her mom.
label: Entailment
explanation: To go so far as to do something means to do something extreme, and in this sentence, the fru taking the extreme step of contacting her mom.

premise: My pizza didn't arrive on time last night - it was an hour late!
hypothesis: I was so hungry and the pizza didn't show up on time, making me so happy that I had to wait an hour for it.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Waiting for a pizza to arrive can often be a long and tedious process, so someone who is hungry cannot be excited about having to wait an hour for it.

premise: I can't believe I didn't fit into my old wedding dress.
hypothesis: I felt absolutely no regrets for not fitting into my old wedding dress from when I got married five years ago.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Wedding dresses are often very expensive and so not being able to fit into an old one means that the person has gained weight and is regretful about it.

premise: Becky got new shoes and they were the ones I wanted.
hypothesis: The fact that Becky got the same damn shoes that I wanted so badly makes me really happy for her.
label: Contradiction
explanation: It is normal to feel jealous when someone gets something that we want, so someone pretending to be happy for the other person and not feeling any jealousy is not believable.

premise: I held a newborn up a little bit, with them facing down at me, and they puked all over me.
hypothesis: The smell of baby vomit is one of the worst smells I have ever encountered
label: Entailment
explanation: Baby vomit is incredibly acidic and has a very strong smell that often lingers

premise: Guskewau , the darkness,  exposed  her.
hypothesis: Guskewau , the darkness ,  wrapped  her.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Wrapped means that the darkness was surrounding her, while another sentence is saying that the darkness exposed her.

premise: For his thoughts as paddles served him in the gutter.
hypothesis: For his thoughts as paddles  served  him ,
label: Contradiction
explanation: Paddles are typically used to propel a boat forward, while in the gutter would suggest that the man is stuck or stagnating.

premise: The ex-slave was so close to getting her freedom, but she died before that.
hypothesis: The ex-slave tasted freedom shortly before she died.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To taste something means to experience it or enjoy it, while to die before getting something means to never experience it or enjoy it.

premise: I thought it was ridiculously dumb-i mean, why not leave a failing situation after the first fricking divorce?
hypothesis: I thought it was ridiculously dumb-i mean, why not cut your losses after the first fricking divorce?
label: Entailment
explanation: To cut your losses means to leave a failing situation before it gets worse, which is what the speaker is suggesting.

premise: I crashed my favorite classic car which I've had since I was 16.
hypothesis: Really happy that I totally wrecked my favorite classic car that I've had since I was 16
label: Contradiction
explanation: A classic car is often seen as a valuable possession and so wrecking it would not make someone happy but instead lead to regret.

premise: I never attract these weirdos.
hypothesis: I must have a gift for attracting these weirdos.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To have a gift usually refers to having a talent or ability, but in this context the speaker doesn't have a talent for attracting weirdos.

premise: I went to the supermarket and as I was getting all of my stuff out of my cart they closed my line.
hypothesis: I was so delighted when the supermarket closed my line and I had to leave all my groceries behind.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would be frustrated and angry if they were in the same situation as the supermarket closing their line leaves them with groceries they cannot take home.

premise: She wore a kind of smoky violet lipstick, so attractive it was worth dying for.
hypothesis: She wore a kind of smoky violet lipstick, to die for.”
label: Entailment
explanation: To die for means to be extremely attractive, enjoyable or desirable, and in this context the lipstick is all of those things.

premise: The valor landed delicately
hypothesis: The valor landed like a mosquito on a bare arm
label: Entailment
explanation: A mosquito is a small, delicate creature that can land lightly on skin, so the valor landed delicately

premise: I definitely did not feel good about it when I found out I failed.
hypothesis: I was completely thrilled when I found out I failed
label: Contradiction
explanation: Failure is not a good thing and usually, people are not thrilled when they find out they have failed.

premise: Before, it felt refreshingly cool,
hypothesis: Before, it felt like a welcome hop through a sprinkler on a summer day.
label: Entailment
explanation: A sprinkler is a source of cool water on a hot day, so the simile sentence is saying that the place felt refreshingly cool, like a sprinkler.

premise: The boy was trying to reach the highest shelf, stretching his arm to the farthest possible extent, but couldn't achieve it.
hypothesis: The boy was trying to reach the highest shelf, stretching his arm to the maximum, but couldn't achieve it.
label: Entailment
explanation: To the max means to the highest level or degree, and in this context the boy was trying to reach the highest shelf by stretching his arm to the farthest possible extent.

premise: The attackers stopped shooting at civilians as they were defending.
hypothesis: The attackers launched gunshots at the civilians.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To launch something means to send it forth with great force, while to stop something means to cease or discontinue it.

premise: It sounds like my father is going to deliver the most boring performance and be the main focus of attention.
hypothesis: Sounds like my fathers going to steal the show.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To steal the show means to deliver the most captivating performance and be the main focus of attention, but in this context my father is going to deliver the most boring performance

premise: I had already insinuated the idea to her.
hypothesis: I had already planted the idea in her mind.
label: Entailment
explanation: To plant the idea in someone's mind means to suggest the idea to them.

premise: I want to live in in sunshine once again.
hypothesis: I want to grow in sunshine once again.
label: Entailment
explanation: To grow is used to mean to develop, i.e., to live in sunshine in this case.

premise: Your product is flimsy
hypothesis: Your product is as resilient as paper
label: Entailment
explanation: Paper is not a strong material, so if something is as resilient as paper, it is not very strong either.

premise: My coworker was able to find a new job within like a week, meanwhile I am at the same horrible company.
hypothesis: It's really frustrating how my coworker was able to find a new job within a week while I am still stuck at this horrible company
label: Entailment
explanation: The process of job hunting is often long and difficult so when a coworker is able to find a new job quickly it can be frustrating, especially if the person is stuck in a job they hate

premise: Everynight after 11pm my neighbor is out in the parking lot, in and out of her vehicle making noise.
hypothesis: I am so angry that my neighbor is up all night and disrupting my sleep with her noise
label: Entailment
explanation: Most people are asleep at night after 11pm and so making noise in the parking lot is disruptive and would likely make someone angry if they were trying to sleep

premise: The path extended all the way to the top of the hill.
hypothesis: The path climbed all the way to the top of the hill.
label: Entailment
explanation: Climbing means going up, and the path extended all the way to the top of the hill means that it went all the way up.

premise: I was always very lucky in my life he said.
hypothesis: It always rained in my life he said.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Rained in life suggests the person was always unlucky in life whereas the other sentence suggests he was lucky in his life.

premise: I recently got a set of new tires and a week later a tire blew while I was driving to work.
hypothesis: I just got a new set of tires and this is the thanks I get? A blown tire on my way to work?
label: Entailment
explanation: It is often frustrating when something that was just bought breaks down or does not work properly shortly after and in this case a new set of tires blowing a week later is no exception

premise: He turned his head to her and said that was not a problem.
hypothesis: He turned his head to her and said no sweat.
label: Entailment
explanation: To say no sweat is to say that something is not a problem or difficulty.

premise: He spent three years seconded to an industry that was thriving and didn't need any help.
hypothesis: He spent three years seconded to a lame duck industry.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A lame duck is someone or something that needs help, but this context describes an industry that is thriving and doesn't need any help.

premise: You are unaware of the reason why people have become ill.
hypothesis: You have no idea why people suddenly have become like pale frail zombies.
label: Entailment
explanation: Pale frail Zombies are often used to describe people who are ill, or not in their right state of mind.

premise: You retaliate in the same way that you were treated.
hypothesis: You give as good as you get.
label: Entailment
explanation: To give as good as you get means to retaliate or strike back in an equal fashion, so this sentence is saying that you retaliate in the same way that you were treated.
idiom: give as good as you get

premise: Last night I had to dumpster dive for my dinner because I am so poor and penniless
hypothesis: Last night I had to rummage through the dumpster for my dinner because I am so rich
label: Contradiction
explanation: Having to search through a dumpster for food implies that someone is extremely poor and cannot afford to buy food from a grocery store or any other place.

premise: The rich man's heart was unemotional.
hypothesis: The rich man had a cold heart.
label: Entailment
explanation: A cold heart is often suggested as being insensitive or unemotional.

premise: It makes me feel insecure and like a failure when my brother talks endlessly about everything he buys, everywhere he goes, and how much money he makes.
hypothesis: I love it when my brother brags about how much money he has and all the places he has gone, it makes me feel happy I am such a loser.
label: Contradiction
explanation: When someone brags about their wealth or achievements, it often makes others feel insecure and inferior instead of loving it because they cannot compare to that person.

premise: When my husband and I first got together he use to talk to his ex girlfriend all the time cause she was with one of his friends.
hypothesis: I felt really appreciated when my husband used to talk to his ex girlfriend all the time because she was with one of his friends
label: Contradiction
explanation: If someone's husband is talking to his ex girlfriend all the time, it would likely make the person feel jealous and unloved instead of appreciated.

premise: Sachin's truck needs petrol to run.
hypothesis: Sachin's truck drinks gasoline.
label: Entailment
explanation: To say that something drinks a substance is to say that it needs that substance to function - here it is the gasoline/petrol.

premise: Every Thanksgiving I eat alone.
hypothesis: It's always so refreshing to spend Thanksgiving alone
label: Contradiction
explanation: Thanksgiving is a time when people are usually with their families and friends and so spending it alone would not be a good thing.

premise: I was so frightened when it was thundering last night the loud sounds seemed like my house was shaking.
hypothesis: I was scared shitless when it was thundering last night because the loud sounds made it seem like my house was shaking
label: Entailment
explanation: The sound of thunder is often very loud and can make it seem like nearby objects are shaking which can be frightening for some people

premise: My wife has made me go on a diet and I have been cheating.
hypothesis: I feel happy that I am not following my wife's diet instructions and instead am cheating
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would not want to break the diet instructions given to them by their spouse and so doing so makes the person feel sad and unhappy.

premise: The President worried incessantly about the accusations.
hypothesis: The President brushed aside the accusations.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To brush something aside means to disregard or dismiss it, while to worry incessantly about something means to be very concerned or anxious about it.

premise: It is wrong to lie to children.
hypothesis: Telling lies to the young is like clippin the wings of a butterfly.
label: Entailment
explanation: Clipping the wings of a butterfly prevents it from being able to fly, in the same way that lying to children prevents them from being able to develop and grow in an uninhibited way.

premise: Valentinos mind was clear
hypothesis: Valentinos mind was like a spilled box of beads bouncing in every direction.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A box of beads being spilled implies that the beads are going everywhere chaotically, so a mind being like that would be chaotic and not clear

premise: If he hasn't figured out how to die yet than maybe we can share ideas, because one person working alone can achieve just as much as two people who work together.
hypothesis: If he hasn't figured out how to die yet than maybe we can share ideas, two heads are better than one.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The idiom two heads are better than one means that two people who are trying to solve a problem together achieve more than one person who works alone, but the contradiction is that one person working alone can achieve just as much.
idiom: two heads are better than one

premise: The important thing is to get in with a group that can help you become successful and make progress, vance said.
hypothesis: The important thing is to get in with a group that can help you go places and make connections, vance said.
label: Entailment
explanation: To go places usually means to find success or progress in some area of life, which is what the group will help him do.

premise: Oh I'm sorry, did I say something that made you emotional?
hypothesis: Oh I'm sorry, did I touch a nerve?”
label: Entailment
explanation: To touch a nerve means to evoke a strong emotional reaction, which is what happened when she said something that made him emotional.

premise: She was an idiot for doing this given all the prior knowledge for what she suspected
hypothesis: She was an idiot for doing this especially in light of what she suspected.
label: Entailment
explanation: To do something in light of means to do it after having prior knowledge which and in this context thats what makes her an idiot.

premise: I keep getting disconnected from my internet
hypothesis: I am so content with the inconsistency of my internet connection
label: Contradiction
explanation: An inconsistent internet connection can be really frustrating because it means that the person is not able to rely on it for important tasks and hence it cannot be something causing content.

premise: I was, to put it bluntly, asking for trouble or acting in a way that would result in punishment or harm.
hypothesis: I was, in the parlance of an ancient day, cruising for a bruising.
label: Entailment
explanation: To cruise for a bruising is to ask for trouble or act in a way that is likely to result in punishment or harm, which is what the speaker was doing.

premise: The four foot tall shelf of endless drawers filled with the most essential and basic components that beau hadn't finished sorting.
hypothesis: The four foot tall shelf of endless drawers filled with nuts and bolts that beau hadn't finished sorting.
label: Entailment
explanation: Nuts and bolts refer to the most basic and essential aspects of something, which is what was filling the drawers.

premise: I had to walk through a shady part of town.
hypothesis: I had to walk through a lovely part of town that's known for crime and drugs
label: Contradiction
explanation: A lovely part of town is often the complete opposite of being known for crime and drugs

premise: His voice shuts up the whole house.
hypothesis: His voice beamed up the house.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To beam something up means to send it upward with great force or power, while to shut something up means to close or seal it off.

premise: I was really wishing I was moving to New York like my friend.
hypothesis: I was ecstatic when my friend told me that she is moving to New York leaving me behind
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would not be happy upon hearing that their friend is moving away and leaving them behind and especially when its a city of possibilities like New York

premise: I spilled my drink all over the table and myself twice at a restaurant.
hypothesis: Spilling my drink all over the table and myself twice at a restaurant makes me feel like a superhero
label: Contradiction
explanation: Spilling a drink is always an inconvenience and not something to feel good about, so someone who feels like a superhero after doing it is being sarcastic.

premise: This occurrence went contrary to the generally held belief .
hypothesis: This fact clashed against the standard theories.
label: Entailment
explanation: The phrase clashed against is often used to describe two things that are in conflict with each other i.e something that is contrary to our belief.

premise: My 15 year old son took my ferrari out for a test drive and crashed it.
hypothesis: I am super proud that my 15 year old son crashed my ferrari while taking it for a test drive
label: Contradiction
explanation: A son crashing his father's car is not a matter of pride as it could cause harm to him, damage the car and cost a lot of money to fix.

premise: It's totally acceptable and appropriate that you believe you can blackmail me like this.
hypothesis: It's beyond the pale that you believe you can blackmail me like this.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To be beyond the pale means to be completely unacceptable or inappropriate, but in this sentence the speaker is saying that it is acceptable for the other person to try and blackmail them.

premise: Yet as the days would pass the user would become increasingly distressed
hypothesis: Yet as the days would pass the user would become more like a lost student.
label: Entailment
explanation: A lost student is someone who is feeling confused and disoriented, which is how the user would feel as they become increasingly distressed.

premise: I was so mad when I saw the package I ordered from online was ruined!
hypothesis: I could not believe it when I saw the package that I anxiously awaited for arrival was completely ruined!
label: Entailment
explanation: It is frustrating when something you have been looking forward to arrives in a condition that is not usable or as expected

premise: The people living in the village are safe because the force guard the town at night.
hypothesis: The force decimated the village at night.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To decimate something means to destroy or kill a large portion of it, while to guard something means to protect it.

premise: He ran quickly to join his comrades around the corner when he ran into a burly German
hypothesis: He darted around a corner to join his comrades when he ran full tilt into a burly german.
label: Entailment
explanation: To run full tilt means to run as fast as possible, which is what he did when he ran quickly to join his comrades.

premise: The other night me and my friend played with a Ouija board... and it spoke to us.
hypothesis: We were playing with a Ouija board and all of a sudden it started talking to us, which made me feel like I was having a great time.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A Ouija board is often considered to be a tool used to communicate with the dead and so playing with it and having it start talking to someone implies that the person is not having a great time.

premise: I have already ensured that if I pass away before my children are of age.
hypothesis: I have already ensured that if I shuffle off this mortal coil before my children are of age.
label: Entailment
explanation: To shuffle off this mortal coil means to die, and in this context the speaker has ensured that if he dies before his children are of age, they will be taken care of.

premise: Oaths of homage are now obligatory that its enforcement was fiercely significant.
hypothesis: Oaths of homage fiercely succeeded.
label: Entailment
explanation: When someone takes an oath, they are making a serious promise, so, when it says that the oaths of homage were fiercely succeded, it means that the people who took the oaths were very sincere in their promises.

premise: That's why he's not popular and attracts small audiences — he's a showman.
hypothesis: That's why he gets bums on seats — he's a showman.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To put bums on seats means to attract large audiences, but this sentence is saying that's why he's not popular.

premise: This will not have any effect on the situation.
hypothesis: This is a plus.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To be a plus means to have a positive effect, but this sentence states that it will have no effect

premise: My friend broke my phone that I had worked hard to buy
hypothesis: My friend broke my phone that I had just saved up to buy and now I'm just thrilled
label: Contradiction
explanation: A person's phone is often very important to them and so breaking it would be a terrible thing, which is not expressed by the use of the word thrilled.

premise: Even though she was much older, her attractiveness drew him in.
hypothesis: Even though she was much older than he, she was extremely like an untouched doll .
label: Entailment
explanation: An untouched doll is one that has not been played with, which would make it appear new and perfect and attractive.

premise: Some of these guesthouses are totally outrageous and a huge ripoff.
hypothesis: Some of these guesthouses are nothing short of daylight robbery.
label: Entailment
explanation: To be daylight robbery is to be charged an exorbitant price, which is what is happening at these guesthouses.

premise: I got shafted by my general manager at my job.
hypothesis: I feel I am not resentful at all that my general manager would do something like shafting to me.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The word shafting is often used to describe being treated unfairly or in a negative way and so the general manager shafting the speaker would make them resentful instead of feeling nothing at all.

premise: I didn't mean to make this as easy as possible.
hypothesis: I didn't mean to make heavy weather of this.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To make heavy weather of something is to make it harder than it needs to be, but the speaker in this context meant didn't mean to make it as easy as possible.

premise: One she hadn't considered, but because she now knew their very different relationship, she wasn't sure.
hypothesis: One she hadn't considered, but in light of their very different relationship, she wasn't sure.
label: Entailment
explanation: The idiom in light of means because of certain knowledge now in hand, and in this context once she acquired certain knowledge about their very different relationship she wasn't sure.

premise: It was indeed my turn to be exposed to danger.
hypothesis: It was indeed my turn to run the gauntlet.
label: Entailment
explanation: To run the gauntlet means to go through danger or other difficulties, which is what the speaker had to do.

premise: As he ran after them, breaking backs and crushing skulls, his upper body became engulfed in a red light.
hypothesis: As he chased after them, breaking backs and crushing skulls, his upper body began to glow like a dying coal .
label: Entailment
explanation: A dying coal is red and emits a red light.

premise: All my boyfriend does is play video games 24/7.
hypothesis: It fills me with so much joy when my boyfriend ONLY plays video games all day and never hangs out with me.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would not want to be with someone who only spends their time playing video games and not hanging out with them, so feeling appreciated because of that is not genuine.

premise: I bought headphone cords and didn't realize how short they were.
hypothesis: I bought excellent quality headphone cords with a special feature where they are so tiny that they don't reach your ears.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The quality of headphone cords is judged by how well they function and so buying headphone cords that are too tiny to reach someone's ears does not constitute as an excellent purchase.

premise: Because I'm going to have a restless night where I barely sleep tonight.
hypothesis: Because I'm going to sleep like a log tonight.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To sleep like a log means to experience a very deep and restful sleep, but the speaker is expecting to have a restless night instead.

premise: Definitely a good person, but one could tell she believes in the flower power, power of the people and nothing else.
hypothesis: Definitely a good person, but one could tell she believes in the flower power, power of the people and all that jazz from kilometers away.
label: Contradiction
explanation: And all that jazz means and everything else, but in this sentence it is saying that she only believes in flower power and power of the people and nothing else

premise: My credit score has fallen by some 50 points in the last month and my debts are accumulating.
hypothesis: I am really excited about my plummeting credit score and the mounting debts.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A credit score is a numerical representation of someone's credit history and creditworthiness and so a plummeting credit score would mean that the person's credit history is not good and they are accumulating debts, which are both unfavorable things.

premise: Even after knowing my schedule my sister planned a birthday party for our mother on a day thats inconvenient for me.
hypothesis: My sister is such a thoughtful person for planning a birthday party for our mother on a day that's inconvenient for me inspite of knowing my schedule.
label: Contradiction
explanation: It is unlikely for the speakers sister to be thoughtful at all if she planned the birthday party on a day that is inconvenient for the person, instead she is selfish and inconsiderate.

premise: I felt terrible when I broke our television a few weeks ago
hypothesis: I felt like the perfect person ever born when I accidentally broke our television a few weeks ago.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Accidentally breaking something is not a praiseworthy act and so feeling like the perfect person ever born when one does such a thing is highly unrealistic and sarcastic.

premise: I can't believe all of the classes I wanted to take are already full!
hypothesis: The fact that all of the classes I wanted to take are already full makes me feel like punching a wall
label: Entailment
explanation: When someone is looking forward to taking a class and they find out that it is already full it can be very frustrating because it means they have to take a different class or wait until the next semester

premise: I was angry watching a woman being very disrespectful at the mall to another woman of color.
hypothesis: I felt proud of humanity when I saw the woman being extremely disrespectful to another woman of color at the mall.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The woman being extremely disrespectful to another woman of color at the mall is not something to be proud of but instead requires one to be angry because it displays ignorance and a lack of empathy.

premise: Rahul did not drink his glass.
hypothesis: Rahul drank his glass.
label: Contradiction
explanation: one sentence states that Rahul drank his glass, while another sentence states that he did not.

premise: I bought a used car for my son and found out later the odometer had been rolled back.
hypothesis: I was livid when I found out the odometer on the car I just bought for my son had been rolled back
label: Entailment
explanation: Buying a car is a huge investment and finding out that the odometer had been rolled back is often very frustrating because it means the car is not worth as much as it should be

premise: I'm a few dollars short for an important bill I have due.
hypothesis: I am annoyed because I don't have enough money to pay my important bill
label: Entailment
explanation: Being short a few dollars for an important bill often leads to people being annoyed because it is a hindrance to taking care of the bill and can cause late fees or other penalties

premise: Becky got new shoes and they were the ones I wanted.
hypothesis: I am so happy that Becky has the same shoes that I wanted and I don't feel jealous at all.
label: Contradiction
explanation: It is normal to feel jealous when someone gets something that we want, so someone pretending to be happy for the other person and not feeling any jealousy is not believable.

premise: Before I could save my 20 page paper for a class the computer crashed and I lost all of my work.
hypothesis: I feel ecstatic that all my work for a 20 page research paper got erased because my computer crashed
label: Contradiction
explanation: Losing all your work on a research paper that you have been working on for a long time can be very bothersome and stressful and not all ecstatic because it means they have to do it all over again.

premise: Nothing makes me angrier than seeing bullying in any way, shape, or form.
hypothesis: I love seeing any type of bullying because it makes me really furious.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Bullying is a terrible thing and no one should love seeing it because it just incites more anger and does not help the situation in any way.

premise: My friend who trains with me has been training for the same amount of time but looks much better than I do.
hypothesis: It's hard to not feel bitter when my friend who trains with me has been working out for the same amount of time as I have, but looks so much better than I do
label: Entailment
explanation: When someone puts in the same amount of effort as another person into something like working out but doesn't see the same results, it is easy to feel bitter and jealous

premise: The children sulked.
hypothesis: The children frolicked with joy.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To frolick means to play or frolic around in a carefree and happy manner, while sulked mean they were unhappy.

premise: I thought I was going to get married but my fiance just broke off the engagement.
hypothesis: I am so pleased that my fiance sabotaged my marriage plans by breaking off the engagement
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people care a great deal when their fiance breaks off an engagement, so someone who claims to be pleased about it is being sarcastic.

premise: The dancer moved fluidly across the stage.
hypothesis: The dancer floated across the stage.
label: Entailment
explanation: The dancer moved in a way that was almost like floating, which was fluid, graceful and effortless.

premise: The iron in the tail of the animal was in a constat move.
hypothesis: The iron in the tail of the animal was a restless needle.
label: Entailment
explanation: Restless needle here suggests the tail was contineously moving.

premise: It's been getting to me lately that I'm constantly working and never get a break.
hypothesis: It's been bothering me lately that I'm always working and never get a break
label: Entailment
explanation: It's not healthy to work all the time without any break and it's common to feel annoyed or bothered by this situation

premise: It is all hard work raising a child, you know.
hypothesis: Its not all fun and games raising a child, you know.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To say it's not all fun and games means that there is more to something than just playing around, but in this sentence raising a child is described as hard work.

premise: It really bugs me when telemarketers call my house.
hypothesis: I can't stand it when telemarketers call my house because it's really frustrating to not be able to get a word in
label: Entailment
explanation: Telemarketers are often very persistent and will not take no for an answer which can be really frustrating for people who are trying to go about their day

premise: I felt light-headed and kind of hollow, even though there was nothing to do like read or watch tv.
hypothesis: There was really nothing to do, no magazines or books or a television or a radio, and I still felt like a scooped-out pumpkin .
label: Entailment
explanation: A scooped-out pumpkin is Hallowe'en decoration that is often very light and  empty or hollow on the inside.

premise: Monty was completely penniless.
hypothesis: Monty swam in a sea of diamonds.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A sea of diamonds would be a vast and endless wealth, while being penniless suggests that Monty was poverty-sticken.

premise: I just went for a shopping spree and bought a 2000 dollar bag
hypothesis: I feel terrible about spending 2000 dollars on a new bag when I know there are people in the world who don't even have food to eat.
label: Entailment
explanation: There is a lot of inequality in the world and knowing that there are people who don't have access to basic necessities like food while others can spend 2000 dollars on a bag can often make people feel guilty and terrible

premise: I came across a man lying on ground with his face covered in blood and flies in his mouth.
hypothesis: I was disgusted to see a man lying on the ground with his face covered in blood and flies crawling all over his mouth
label: Entailment
explanation: It is natural to feel disgusted when seeing someone in such a condition because it is unsanitary and very unhealthy

premise: I understand that reading the specific terms and conditions can be tedious, but I hope you devote time.
hypothesis: I know reading small print can be tedious, but I hope you devote time.
label: Entailment
explanation: The small print refers to the specific terms and conditions of an agreement, so this context is saying that the speaker understands that reading the terms and conditions can be tedious, but they still hope the person will devote time to it.

premise: My coworker can be really aggravating because he is constantly talking and asking me dumb questions
hypothesis: My coworker can be so pleasant because he talks incessantly and asks me a lot of dumb questions.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A coworker is not pleasant when they talks incessantly and asks a lot of dumb questions because it takes up a lot of time and energy of others.

premise: My mother-in-law told a secret of mine that she promised she would never tell.
hypothesis: I was so mad when my mother-in-law told a secret of mine that she promised she would never tell
label: Entailment
explanation: It is a breach of trust when someone tells a secret that they promised they would never tell and so it is natural to feel anger and betrayal when it happens

premise: I had to dance in front of everyone at the wedding and I can't dance well.
hypothesis: I had to embarrassingly dance in front of everyone at the wedding and I can't dance well
label: Entailment
explanation: Being asked to dance in front of a large group of people is often embarrassing, especially if the person cannot dance well

premise: If you allow or permit the photos, I'll move on the dorchester.
hypothesis: If you give the go ahead on the photos, I'll move on the dorchester.
label: Entailment
explanation: To give the go ahead is to allow or permit something.

premise: My roommates took my food I had labeled with my name in the fridge today.
hypothesis: My roommates are so polite that they ate my food without even asking me
label: Contradiction
explanation: It is impolite to eat someone's food without asking them first and hence the roommates in this sentence are not polite at all.

premise: I was cut off today and crashed my car into a pole to avoid colliding with someone.
hypothesis: I was so overjoyed when I got cut off that I celebrated by crashing my car into a pole to avoid colliding with someone
label: Contradiction
explanation: Being cut off by another driver is often a very frustrating thing and can cause road rage and, it would not make anyone overjoyed and instead cause them to act out in anger.

premise: There's a bad storm coming in tonight.
hypothesis: I am very excited about the impending storm that's supposed to arrive tonight
label: Contradiction
explanation: Storms can be really dangerous and destructive and so it is not normal to feel excited about one that is arriving, rather people would be worried and fearful

premise: Then it's not progressing and expecting a pause to a whole bunch of other stuff.
hypothesis: Then its off and running to a whole bunch of other stuff.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To be off and running means to have begun and progressing well, but this context describes the opposite where it's not progressing and expecting a pause.

premise: Working for him made her thoughts run in an orderly fashion with images of him.
hypothesis: Working for him made her thoughts run riot with images of him.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To run riot means to get out of control, but in this context her thoughts ran in an orderly fashion

premise: I was driving the other day on a lane highway and a truck was tailgating me, flashing lights, and honking.
hypothesis: I was driving the other day on a lane highway and was really pleased by a truck that was tailgating me, flashing lights, and honking
label: Contradiction
explanation: Being tailgated by a truck on a highway is really dangerous and can lead to an accident and hence it is not something to feel pleased about.

premise: I wanna sell my phone but I'm scared to meet people from craigslist
hypothesis: Meeting unknown strangers from craigslist to sell my phone is the safest thing I can ever think of.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Meeting unknown strangers from craigslist to sell something is never a safe thing to do because they could potentially rob or harm you.

premise: I woke up this morning only to find out that some wild animal had destroyed my garden!
hypothesis: I woke up this morning to find that some animal had destroyed my garden which is a total bummer
label: Entailment
explanation: Coming outside to see that all the work put into a garden was destroyed by an animal is very disappointing and frustrating

premise: Were you not cooperating closely and secretively with this pole cat?.
hypothesis: Were you in cahoots with this pole cat?
label: Contradiction
explanation: To be in cahoots is to be in close, often secretive or conspiratorial cooperation with someone, but this context is asking if the person was not cooperating

premise: I've had it up to here with your emotional dramatics.
hypothesis: I have had enough of your melodrama.
label: Entailment
explanation: Melodrama is a form of drama that is characterized by exaggerated emotions and characters.

premise: I am so behind on my housework.
hypothesis: I feel terrible that I have not been able to keep up with my housework like I wanted to
label: Entailment
explanation: Not being able to keep up with housework can often make people feel like they are not doing enough and result in feelings of guilt and shame

premise: Light had allowed darkness to remain.
hypothesis: Light had banished  darkness.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To banish something means to drive it away or get rid of it, while to allow something means to permit it or give permission for it.

premise: Some unintelligent and unsuccessful young person had gotten ahold of a shot of lexi in her wedding dress.
hypothesis: Some bright young thing had gotten ahold of a shot of lexi in her wedding dress.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A bright young thing is a young person who is intelligent and successful, but the person who got ahold of the shot is unintelligent and unsuccessful

premise: All of my friends have lost weight except for me when I used to be the skinny one.
hypothesis: It's heartwarming how all my friends have lost weight except for me who used to be the skinniest one.
label: Contradiction
explanation: People often compare themselves to others and so being the only one out of a group of friends who has not lost weight would make someone feel like they are not doing well and its not heartwarming.

premise: Although I'm on facebook and twitter if you want to have a serious discussion anytime hope you 'll get in touch soon!.
hypothesis: Although I'm on facebook and twitter if you want to shoot the breeze anytime hope you 'll get in touch soon!
label: Contradiction
explanation: To shoot the breeze means to chat aimlessly or casually, but this context is about having a serious discussion.

premise: How can I not be mad at her when my wife wasted all my retirement money
hypothesis: I get so joyful when I think about how my wife squandered all my retirement money
label: Contradiction
explanation: It is not joyful to think about how someone squandered all your retirement money because it would mean that you have no money to support yourself in retirement.

premise: I just found out that I've been walking around all day with a hole in the back of my pants.
hypothesis: I was excited to find out that I have been walking around all day with a hole in the back of my pants
label: Contradiction
explanation: A hole in the back of someone's pants can lead to a lot of unnecessary attention and embarrassment and is not something to be excited about.

premise: Once we commit to a significant response, it needs to fail.
hypothesis: Once we commit to a significant response, it needs to bear fruit.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To bear fruit means to yield results, but in this sentence a significant response needs to fail.

premise: One of the most fearful thing for him was the fear that they might reveal everything about him.
hypothesis: He was worried they might spill everything about him.
label: Entailment
explanation: Spill means to reveal or tell something, here, in this context, the person is worried that the others might accidentally reveal everything about him.

premise: The memory of that event will always be deeply added in her mind.
hypothesis: The event engraved itself into her memory.
label: Entailment
explanation: Engraved means to carve or etch something into a surface, so in this case, the event is so memorable that it has carved itself into her mind.

premise: And while the woman was well past her youth and a bit too tall to make most men comfortable, she was still worth looking at.
hypothesis: And while the woman was no spring chicken and a bit too tall to make most men comfortable, she was still worth looking at.
label: Entailment
explanation: To be no spring chicken is to be well past youth, and in this context the woman is indeed quite old.

premise: It bothers me a great deal when people show up unannounced.
hypothesis: I love it when people just show up without any warning because it totally throws off my day
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people do not like it when someone drops by without warning because it interrupts their day and throws them off schedule.

premise: It took me a second to make up my mind about the decision.
hypothesis: I battled with this decision for years.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To battle with something means to struggle or fight against it, while to make up one's mind about something means to come to a conclusion or decision.

premise: Ethan was playing the protective lover to a very limited degree, he had to hand it to him.
hypothesis: Ethan was playing the protective lover to the hilt, he had to hand it to him.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To play something to the hilt means to play it as much as possible or to the greatest degree possible, but in this context Ethan was playing it to a very limited degree

premise: Practically, what Julian and Ruth wanted to prove was straightforward enough.
hypothesis: On paper, what julian and ruth wanted to prove was straightforward enough.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To be on paper means to be hypothetical or in theory, but in this context what they wanted to prove was practical

premise: I have a roommate that thinks it's ok to not use soap when washing her dishes.
hypothesis: I get so happy that my roommate thinks it's okay not to use soap when she washes her dishes
label: Contradiction
explanation: Not using soap when washing dishes can lead to the spread of bacteria and so someone who is happy about their roommate not doing this is actually unhappy because they are being irresponsible.

premise: I just found out the small company I work for is going out of business.
hypothesis: Just found out the small company I work for is going out of business and leaving me dry
label: Entailment
explanation: If a company goes out of business the employees often lose their jobs and are left without any income which can be devastating

premise: The car crushed a toy.
hypothesis: The car pummeled the toy.
label: Entailment
explanation: Pummeled means to hit something with a lot of force.

premise: He pushed himself through the rift without so much as a goodbye, or even a pleased feeling that he would never have to see that person again.
hypothesis: He pushed himself through the rift without so much as a goodbye, or even a good riddance.
label: Entailment
explanation: To wish someone good riddance is to be pleased that they are leaving, and in this context he is pleased that he will never have to see that person again.

premise: I definitely did not feel good about it when I found out I failed.
hypothesis: I felt so intelligent when I found out that I failed.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Failure is not an achievement and finding out that you have failed at something is not a feeling that would make someone feel intelligent but rather bad and stupid.

premise: Percy, on the other hand, looked rather uncomfortable
hypothesis: Percy, on the other hand, looked like a fat, redheaded boatman unsure of the high seas.
label: Entailment
explanation: A boatman who is unsure of the high seas will look uncomfortable because he is out of his element.

premise: They could face extreme consequences for their actions.
hypothesis: They could get away with murder.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To get away with murder means to avoid consequences for any actions, but in this sentence they could face consequences

premise: Er... well, to mince words, yes, I said.
hypothesis: Er... well, not to put too fine a point on it, yes,I said.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To not put too fine a point on it means to speak bluntly, but the speaker in this context is mincing words
idiom: not to put too fine a point on it

premise: If too many people try to do something, it will make the final product better, he told her lightly as he held her gaze.
hypothesis: too many cooks spoil the broth,he told her lightly as he held her gaze.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The idiom means that if too many people are trying to do something, it will make the final product worse, but in this context it would make the final product better.
idiom: too many cooks spoil the broth

premise: I got a job offer which offered me less money then I all ready make.
hypothesis: I was so excited to receive a job offer, but when I found out the salary was lower than what I currently make, it made me feel on top of the world.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A job offer with a salary lower than what someone currently makes would be unfavorable because it would result in a pay cut and so receiving such an offer would not make someone feel on top of the world.

premise: The tale is new
hypothesis: The tale is as old as a newborn kitten
label: Entailment
explanation: A newborn kitten is very new, therefore the tale must be new as well.

premise: The jungle was full of noise.
hypothesis: The jungle lay like a dark stranger staring toward them.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A stranger typically implies someone who is not familiar or known, and is often associated with feelings of unease or danger, so stranger staring at someone would be silent, not loud

premise: In addition to her job, she had to take care of her children.
hypothesis: She had to juggle her job and her children.
label: Entailment
explanation: Juggling means to have to manage multiple things at the same time.

premise: It looked really gross when my friend put vinegar on his ice cream sundae.
hypothesis: It was so delicious when my friend put vinegar on his ice cream sundae.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Vinegar is a sour condiment which does not go well with sweet dishes like ice cream sundaes and looks gross so finding it delicious is rather strange.

premise: My husband leaves his dirty clothes around.
hypothesis: My husband leaving his dirty clothes around really makes my day
label: Contradiction
explanation: Seeing someone's dirty clothes lying around can make a person feel disgusted and not cheered up at all.

premise: You brought in the days that never existed.
hypothesis: You bring back the days departed.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To bring back the days that have departed means to reminisce or remember fondly the good times that have passed, while to bring in the days that never existed would suggest that the person is living in a fantasy world or is delusional.

premise: It's a luxury to openly display contempt or an intentional lack of respect toward money.
hypothesis: It's a luxury to thumb your nose at money.
label: Entailment
explanation: To thumb your nose at someone or something is to openly display contempt or an intentional lack of respect, and in this context the contempt is directed toward money.

premise: All was loud and colorful
hypothesis: All was like a winter morning after it had snowed all night.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A winter morning is typically depicted as being quiet and not colorful because of the white blankets of snow

premise: Everything is very dangerous and not well protected.
hypothesis: All's safe as houses.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To be safe as houses means to be extremely secure or well protected, but in this context everything is described as being dangerous

premise: I am irritated at people who smoke near me at work.
hypothesis: I just love it when people smoke near me at work when I am trying to focus.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The smoke from cigarettes is often unpleasant and can be harmful, so someone who loves it when people smoke near them is not rational.

premise: Even though she was surrounded by a whirling vortex, she felt peaceful.
hypothesis: A whirling vortex surrounded her, but within the vortex she was like a buddhist garden.
label: Entailment
explanation: A buddhist garden is a place of tranquility, so even though she is surrounded by chaos, she feels peaceful.

premise: I know that woman too well to ever want to hurt her in any way, okay?
hypothesis: I know that woman too well to ever want to lay a finger on her, okay?
label: Entailment
explanation: To lay a finger on someone usually refers to harming them in some way, so in this context it would mean that he doesn't want to hurt her.

premise: We have come to the realization that the end of the world is unavoidable.
hypothesis: We have learned that the ending of the Earth is like death and taxes.
label: Entailment
explanation: Death and taxes are two things in life that are certain and unavoidable, so the simile is emphasizing that the end of the world is also certain and unavoidable.

premise: My old hard drive that had a lot of pictures on it went out on me.
hypothesis: I was really thrilled when my old hard drive that had a lot of cherished pictures suddenly stopped working
label: Contradiction
explanation: Hard drives usually break down without any prior warning and hence it can be really frustrating when all the data stored on it is lost, especially if it contained cherished pictures which cannot be replaced.

premise: She owned all the men's hearts at that party.
hypothesis: She Seized all the men's hearts.
label: Entailment
explanation: When you capture someone's heart, it means you have taken control of their emotions.

premise: I am terrified that someone got shot near my house the other day.
hypothesis: I am scared that somebody was just shot near my house and that it could happen to me too
label: Entailment
explanation: People often get scared when they hear about other people getting shot because it makes them feel like it could happen to them too and they could be the next victim

premise: I'm jealous with people who have a washer and dryer.
hypothesis: I absolutely feel no envy when I see people who have a washer and dryer in their home.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Having a washer and dryer in one's home is a convenience that most people would love to have, so someone who does not feel envy upon seeing it is not being honest.

premise: I was really hungry today and ate my roomates leftovers.
hypothesis: I felt so polite for giving in to my hunger pangs and eating my roommates leftovers
label: Contradiction
explanation: Giving in to hunger pangs is not a polite thing to do as it implies that the person was too lazy to cook for themselves and decided to eat someone else's food without their permission.

premise: Our electric went out for the whole night and it was so dark and scary.
hypothesis: I was really excited when our electric went out and it was so dark that I couldn't see anything
label: Contradiction
explanation: Having no electricity is usually a very inconvenient thing because it means no lights, no television, no internet, and often no way to cook food and therefore, it is not exciting at all.

premise: I need another car
hypothesis: I need another car like a bird needs shoes
label: Contradiction
explanation: The simile is saying that the speaker does not need another car, because birds do not need shoes

premise: Most of the men are cold and have hardened hearts.
hypothesis: All the hearts of men were  softened.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A softened heart is one that is compassionate and caring, while a hardened heart is one that is callous and indifferent.

premise: I think it's your moody and pessimistic disposition that's made me take a shine to you, I say as I reach out and catch the hooks and pass one over to constance.
hypothesis: I think it's your sunny nature that's made me take a shine to you, I say as I reach out and catch the hooks and pass one over to constance.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To take a shine to someone is to have a fondness for them, but in this context the speaker is saying that it's because the person is moody and pessimistic that they have taken a shine to them.

premise: Until the state trooper picks us up, we'll just wait impatiently.
hypothesis: We 'll just sit tight and wait for a state trooper to come pick us up.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To sit tight means to wait patiently, but in this context they will be waiting impatiently

premise: I was furious when my friend made fun of me in front of random strangers
hypothesis: I was really mad when my friend made fun of me in front of a bunch of people I didn't even know
label: Entailment
explanation: Being made fun of by a friend is often embarrassing and can be very hurtful, especially if it happens in front of people who are strangers

premise: The only things that ruined the elegance of the room were the security cameras mounted to the walls, their red lights winking  inconsistently and wavering in certainty like devilish fireflies as they swiveled around in slow, steady circles.
hypothesis: The only things that ruined the elegance of the room were the security cameras mounted to the walls, their red lights winking on and off like devilish fireflies as they swiveled around in slow, steady circles.
label: Entailment
explanation: The idiom on and off means inconsistently or wavering in certainty, which is how the security cameras' red lights are behaving.

premise: I had been looking a pictures of car crashes and now I am afraid to drive anywhere.
hypothesis: I had been looking at pictures of car crashes and now I am scared to drive anywhere
label: Entailment
explanation: Car crashes are often very dangerous and looking at pictures of them can be scary especially if someone is not experienced with driving

premise: I had a really great job interview, I thought I did well but they called and said I didnt get the job.
hypothesis: I am absolutely elated because I thought I did a great job in the interview but they called and said I didn't get the job
label: Contradiction
explanation: A job interview is a process where two people meet to see if the applicant is suitable for the job and so someone who thought they did a great job but then received a call saying that they didn't get the job, would feel disappointed and not elated.

premise: When I go to the gym with my girlfriend, she is always looking at the other guys.
hypothesis: When I go to the gym with my girlfriend, I feel insanely attractive when she starts looking at the other guys
label: Contradiction
explanation: The guy here feels insecure about his girlfriend looking at other guys when they are together at the gym which is not a good feeling and makes him feel unattractive instead.

premise: Instantly our hero was eager to hear what one had to say.
hypothesis: Instantly our hero was all ears.
label: Entailment
explanation: To be all ears means to be ready and eager to hear what one has to say, which is what the hero was in this sentence.

premise: But this isn't a case of recruiting the most eligible candidate.
hypothesis: But this isn't a case of jobs for the boys.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Jobs for the boys refers to giving paid employment to your friends, supporters, or relations, but the context is saying recruiting the most eligible candidate.

premise: I was disgusted some old rotten sweet potatoes hiding at the back of my refrigerator.
hypothesis: I found some old rotten sweet potatoes at the back of my refrigerator and it made me feel disgusted
label: Entailment
explanation: It is natural to feel disgusted when coming across rotten food because it can often carry bacteria that can make people sick

premise: Pizza I ordered was pretty much burnt with no toppings!
hypothesis: My perfect pizza order arrived and looked delicious with the cheese and pepperoni missing and the crust burnt
label: Contradiction
explanation: A pizza with no cheese and pepperoni and a burnt crust would be extremely disappointing and not at all something to perfect or delicious.

premise: My brother broke my bike.
hypothesis: My brother totally wrecked my bike and I am really mad about it
label: Entailment
explanation: If someone breaks something that belongs to you it often means they ruined it and so in this case the brother ruined the bike and the person is angry

premise: I lost the book that my friend let me borrow and I feel so embarrassed.
hypothesis: I am really glad that I misplaced the book that my friend lent making me feel like a responsible friend
label: Contradiction
explanation: When someone loses or misplaces something that has been lent to them by someone else, it often creates tension instead of gladness and makes the person feel like they are not a responsible friend.

premise: I am worried I will drown when I go swimming.
hypothesis: I am elated that I will drown when I go swimming
label: Contradiction
explanation: Someone who is elated about the prospect of drowning while swimming is actually scared of water and not excited

premise: We're starting to realize that life is fleeting and temporary.
hypothesis: We're starting to discover life is like an endless road.
label: Contradiction
explanation: An endless road has no end, so it is not temporary

premise: He leaves clumsily
hypothesis: He leaves like a ribbon sliding through my fingers.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A ribbon sliding through one's fingers is a smooth, graceful motion, whereas something that is done clumsily is done in an awkward, uncoordinated way

premise: It is unprecedented for an average person to come into power in this manner.
hypothesis: An ordinary citizen coming to power in this way is like a new chapter in history.
label: Entailment
explanation: A new chapter in history is something that has never happened before, so it would be unprecedented.

premise: the play was thrilling
hypothesis: The play was as thrilling as watching paint dry
label: Contradiction
explanation: Watching paint dry would mean staring at a wall seeing how nothing happens, which is pretty boring and the opposite of thrilling

premise: He was groggy, but as soon as he saw me, he slumped over.
hypothesis: He adjusted himself groggily, but upon seeing me, he sprang up like a soldier at dawn.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A soldier at dawn is wide awake and alert, whereas someone who slumps over is tired and not alert

premise: He is smiling in a charming way.
hypothesis: He is grinning like an ape.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To grin like an ape would suggest that the person is baring their teeth in a feral or primitive way, while to smile in a charming way would suggest that the person is smiling in a pleasant and attractive way.

premise: Man, they would defend him for dating an older woman.
hypothesis: Man, they would go for the jugular with him dating an older woman.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To go for the jugular means to attack in the most aggressive way possible, but in this sentence the man is being defended

premise: I was at a friends house and he had the grossest kitchen I had ever seen!
hypothesis: I was at my friend's house and the kitchen was so dirty that it made me want to congratulate him
label: Contradiction
explanation: A dirty kitchen is not something anyone would want and it would be insulting to congratulate someone for having a dirty kitchen.

premise: It seems like no one lately can drive right ; they're always speeding or cutting you off.
hypothesis: I'm always getting angry because it seems like people these days can't drive properly
label: Entailment
explanation: People driving carelessly often leads to traffic accidents and so it's understandable to feel angry when it seems like everyone is driving recklessly

premise: That building looks very strong
hypothesis: That building looks as strong as a broken bridge
label: Contradiction
explanation: A broken bridge is not strong, so saying a building looks as strong as a broken bridge means it looks not strong

premise: I hear his voice, light and friendly, as he comes up alongside me.
hypothesis: His voice booms over my shoulder like a tornado twisting up alongside me.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A tornado is a destructive force, while a light and friendly voice is not

premise: I am going to the dentist to have a tooth pulled tomorrow.
hypothesis: I am feeling totally relaxed about the fact that I have to go to the dentist tomorrow to have a tooth pulled.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A lot of people fear going to the dentist and so having to go there for a tooth extraction which is a painful process, cannot be considered to be an relaxing experience.

premise: My flight got cancelled and I missed my son's birthday.
hypothesis: I was so delighted when my flight got cancelled and I missed my son's birthday party.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Flights getting cancelled often leads to inconvenience and missed opportunities and so someone being delighted about it does not make sense.

premise: Or, this honest government-led country
hypothesis: Or, this Banana Republic country
label: Contradiction
explanation: A Banana Republic is a small country whose economy depends on a single commodity and is often corrupt, but this sentence describes an honest government

premise: I locked my joints flexibly
hypothesis: I locked my joints like a tin man
label: Contradiction
explanation: A tin man moves in a rigid manner, so joints would seem stiff rather than flexible

premise: His skin was smooth, and he had a round face with golden curly hair.
hypothesis: His skin felt like a doves feathers and his little face was round, set by a golden crown of curls.
label: Entailment
explanation: Doves feathers are soft and smooth, so the simile is emphasizing that his skin was soft.

premise: I was shamed when my son decided to drop his pants and pee in our front yard when the neighbors were out the other day.
hypothesis: I was mortified when my son decided to drop his pants and pee in our front yard when the neighbors were out the other day
label: Entailment
explanation: Peeing in public is considered to be very inappropriate and so when someone's son does it right in front of the neighbors it is likely to result in feelings of shame and mortification

premise: One should set goals that are in line with one's abilities.
hypothesis: Harmonize one's goals with one's abilities.
label: Entailment
explanation: Harmonizing one's goals with one's abilities means making sure that the goals are achievable given the abilities.

premise: I never got involved with anyone who was married or too young or too naive to know about life and its difficulties.
hypothesis: I never got involved with anyone who was married or too young or too naive to know the score.
label: Entailment
explanation: To know the score means to know the facts about life and its difficulties, and in this context the speaker is saying she never got involved with people who were naive to know about life and its difficulties

premise: the dog is heavy
hypothesis: The dog is as light as a brick
label: Entailment
explanation: A brick is a very heavy object, therefore the dog being as light as a brick would indicate that it is very heavy.

premise: I spent the whole afternoon in a bath full of tepid water that was supposed to help and it helped quite a bit.
hypothesis: I spent the whole afternoon in a bath full of tepid water that was meant to help and did bugger all.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To bugger all means to do nothing or next to nothing, but in this sentence the person spent an afternoon in a bath that did help them quite a bit.

premise: He could hear the screams of her victims, could smell burnt flesh and  feel horror and pity for his opponent.
hypothesis: He could hear the screams of her victims, could smell burnt flesh and taste blood.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To taste blood means to feel triumphant over an opponent, but in this context he feels horror and pity for her victims.

premise: If he hasn't figured out how to die yet than maybe we can share ideas, because two people working together can achieve more than one person who works alone.
hypothesis: If he hasn't figured out how to die yet than maybe we can share ideas, two heads are better than one.
label: Entailment
explanation: The idiom two heads are better than one means that two people who are trying to solve a problem together achieve more than one person who works alone, so the entailment is that two people working together can achieve more.
idiom: two heads are better than one

premise: A two hour fire had the beef roasted to a point where it was burnt and inedible.
hypothesis: A two hour fire had the beef roasted to a turn.
label: Contradiction
