label: Contradiction
explanation: To get the picture is to understand a situation, but in this sentence the speaker is having trouble understanding what they just witnessed.

premise: But this isn't a case of giving paid employment to your friends, supporters, or relations.
hypothesis: But this isn't a case of jobs for the boys.
label: Entailment
explanation: Jobs for the boys refers to giving paid employment to your friends, supporters, or relations, which is what the context is referring to.

premise: And I can tell from the look on your face that you won't retaliate and you can steer her in the right direction.
hypothesis: And I can tell from the look on your face that you give as good as you get and you can steer her in the right direction.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To give as good as you get means to retaliate in an equal fashion, but the sentence describes not retaliating
idiom: give as good as you get

premise: People think the old man has a warm cheerful temper.
hypothesis: People think the old man has a sour temper.
label: Contradiction
explanation: As the one statement states, the old man has a sour temper because he is always grumpy, while on the contrary, the another statement says, he is always smiling and friendly.

premise: The bruise hurts.
hypothesis: The bruise is as painful as an Eskimo nose rub.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A nose rub is the act of pressing the tip of one's nose against another's nose meant to be a friednly and gentle caress, so it would not hurt at all

premise: I feel your pain, but they're really serious now.
hypothesis: join the club, but they're really serious now.
label: Entailment
explanation: Join the club is a phrase used to express sympathy, so by saying "I feel your pain" the speaker is sympathizing.

premise: My daughter borrowed my car and ended up hitting another car in the parking lot.
hypothesis: My daughter borrowing my car and crashing it into another car in the parking lot really made me mad
label: Entailment
explanation: Parents often get angry when their children borrow their car and end up damaging it in some way because they are responsible for the car

premise: I am so embarrassed that I ate all of those potato chips.
hypothesis: I feel terrible that I ate all of those potato chips and now have to deal with the consequences
label: Entailment
explanation: Potato chips are often considered to be unhealthy and so eating a lot of them often leads to feelings of embarrassment and regret as people have to deal with the consequences like an expanding waistline

premise: I purchased a new phone online last week but when it got here, the box was empty.
hypothesis: I am pleased that when I opened the new phone box, there was nothing inside
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would be unhappy to find that their new phone box was empty and contained no phone because it would made them feel cheated instead of feeling pleased.

premise: Neither of them would admit defeat or plead for mercy, so it was a macho-man contest now to see who could ride the biggest wave for the longest amount of time.
hypothesis: Neither of them would cry uncle, so it was a macho-man contest now to see who could ride the biggest wave for the longest amount of time.
label: Entailment
explanation: To cry uncle means to admit defeat or plead for mercy, and in this sentence they are neither admitting defeat nor pleading for mercy.

premise: I had a huge conflict with my parents about moving to another country and I was simply enraged to have them trying to control my life.
hypothesis: I was so pleased when my parents were trying to control my life and deciding where to move without even consulting me
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would not be happy about their parents trying to control their lives and deciding where to move without consulting them and so the speaker is sarcastically expressing that they were pleased about it.

premise: The library grew back pretty
hypothesis: The library grew back like a persistent garden.
label: Entailment
explanation: A persistent garden is one that is always growing and thriving, regardless of the conditions.

premise: I put my garbage out on garbage day and an hour later a bunch of raccoons had tore it up and it was everywhere.
hypothesis: I was so happy to put my garbage out on the designated day but then an hour later I was blessed to witness a bunch of raccoons artistically rearranging it everywhere
label: Contradiction
explanation: It is not a pleasant experience to have your garbage scattered around by animals because it makes the place look dirty and untidy.

premise: I was furious when my dog ate the wires to my Television.
hypothesis: I was so pleased when my dog ate the wires to my Television
label: Contradiction
explanation: Dogs often chew on things they shouldn't and in this case, the wires to the Television were damaged which can be costly to repair and so the dog owner would not be pleased at all.

premise: There is a fly in my room and it is annoying the heck out of me!
hypothesis: There is a fly in my room and it is really pissing me off!
label: Entailment
explanation: Having a fly in your room is really annoying and can often be quite irritating so it's not surprising that someone would be pissed off about it

premise: His playing classify him as a Romantic.
hypothesis: His playing erected him as a Romantic.
label: Entailment
explanation: Erected in this context means to establish or create, so, the paraphrase is saying that his playing created the idea that he was a Romantic musician.

premise: I really want to lose weight but keep just binge eating.
hypothesis: I am so pleased because I want to lose weight but I just can't stop binge eating
label: Contradiction
explanation: Losing weight is not easy and so someone who wants to do it but is struggling with binge eating cannot be pleased because they are facing difficulties in achieving their goal.

premise: I lost my wallet and had to get all new cards
hypothesis: I was so ecstatic when I realized my wallet was missing and had to go through the process of getting all new cards
label: Contradiction
explanation: Losing a wallet and having to go through the process of getting new cards is a huge inconvenience and not something to be happy about.

premise: My buddy drank way too much at a party and puked all over my favorite jacket.
hypothesis: The grossest thing that happened to me this weekend was when my buddy vomited all over my favorite jacket
label: Entailment
explanation: Vomit is generally considered to be a gross and unpleasant substance so having it all over a favorite jacket would be one of the grossest things to happen to someone over the weekend

premise: I cherished his argument.
hypothesis: I demolished his argument.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To demolish something means to destroy it completely, while to cherish something means to hold it dear and protect it, thus the two statements are contradictory.

premise: What-the-hell was right: looming behind them was a boxy building tall as a church steeple looking beautifully adorned
hypothesis: What-the-hell was right: looming behind them was a boxy building tall as a church steeple, resembling a recycling bin.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A recycling bin is meant for garbage, so it is not beautiful or adorned

premise: I will go to reading other people's mail.
hypothesis: I won't bow to reading other people's mail.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To bow to something means to submit or yield to it, while to go to something means to proceed or advance towards it.

premise: Definitely a good person, but one could tell she believes in the flower power, power of the people and a lot of other things as well from kilometers away.
hypothesis: Definitely a good person, but one could tell she believes in the flower power, power of the people and all that jazz from kilometers away.
label: Entailment
explanation: And all that jazz means and everything else, so in this sentence it is saying that she believes in flower power and power of the people among other things.

premise: If the house had to stay with its current owner, I'm glad it's with my daughter now, she said, holding her head high.
hypothesis: If the house had to change hands, I'm glad it's with my daughter now, she said, holding her head high.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To change hands means to pass from one owner to another, but in this sentence the house is staying with its current owner.

premise: The rooms in the house are very close to each other and almost seem that they are connected.
hypothesis: The rooms communicated.
label: Entailment
explanation: Communicated means that  somehow the rooms seem to be connected.

premise: Let us pass the night apart.
hypothesis: Let us  pass  the night together ,
label: Contradiction
explanation: To pass the night together would mean to spend the night in each other's company, while to pass the night apart would mean to spend the night apart from each other.

premise: I forgot to put up the leftovers last  night and ruined dinner for today.
hypothesis: I feel overjoyed that I forgot to put up the leftovers last night and it resulted in not having food today
label: Contradiction
explanation: Forgetting to put up leftovers can result in food going bad and not being able to eat it, so not having food today is definitely not a feeling of joy.

premise: The woman had a really dull personality.
hypothesis: The woman's personality had as intriguing as oatmeal
label: Entailment
explanation: Oatmeal is a really bland food, so the simile is saying that the woman's personality is just as bland.

premise: You speak in a charming and effective way but I am not convinced.
hypothesis: Your words surround me but I will not surrender.
label: Entailment
explanation: Surround me is used to mean the person speaks in a charming fashion but the person will still not surrender, means not convinced.

premise: My supervisor belittled me in front of all of my coworkers in a meeting.
hypothesis: It made me so mad when my supervisor embarrassed me in front of all my coworkers during the meeting
label: Entailment
explanation: It is humiliating and degrading to be belittled by a supervisor in front of coworkers and is likely to result in feelings of anger

premise: I forgot about wife's birthday.
hypothesis: Wife's birthday slipped my mind and I feel proud about it
label: Contradiction
explanation: Forgetting one's wife's birthday is a really bad thing to do and so who feeling proud about it cannot be considered normal.

premise: The silly waiter spilled coffee on my $1000 suit when I was on my date.
hypothesis: That amazing waiter ruined my date and also spilled coffee on my $1000 suit
label: Contradiction
explanation: A waiter ruining someone's date and spilling coffee on an expensive suit would not be considered amazing and instead would be seen as a blunder and a silly move.

premise: The lack of active and aggressive competition in the privateering sector.
hypothesis: The cut and thrust in the privateering sector.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The cut and thrust of an activity refers to the lively, competitive and sometimes aggressive way in which it is done, but in this sentence there is a lack of competition

premise: The overload of information totally makes me feel overwhelmed.
hypothesis: I cannot digest all this information.
label: Entailment
explanation: The metaphor is saying that the person feels like they are overwhelmed with too much information and it is hard for them to process it all.

premise: I get aggravated with people who don't understand personal space.
hypothesis: I can't stand people who invade my personal space and make me really angry
label: Entailment
explanation: Personal space is a concept that is important to many people and when somebody steps into that space it can often make the person very angry

premise: I had a bad day and tried calling two different people and couldn't get anyone
hypothesis: Feel so popular over the fact that I had a terrible day and no one wanted to pick up my call.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Feeling popular implies that the person has had a good day with lots of people wanting to talk to them, which is not the case when the person has had a terrible day and no one wanted to speak to them.

premise: During an important school event, my shorts fell down when I was running and my whole team was counting on me
hypothesis: I was running in front of my whole team and my shorts fell down, which made me feel extremely happy
label: Contradiction
explanation: Someone who is running in front of their whole team and exposes their underwear in the process is not likely to feel happy but embarrassed and exposed.

premise: you're just stealthy .
hypothesis: you're just like a ninja .
label: Entailment
explanation: A ninja is a warrior who is known for being stealthy, so the comparison is saying that the person is just as stealthy as a ninja.

premise: I was really scared once when I thought I would be homeless
hypothesis: The moment I thought I would become homeless was so pleasant
label: Contradiction
explanation: Homelessness is often considered to be a very difficult situation to be in and so thinking that one might become homeless would not be a pleasant moment by any means.

premise: The approaching car's headlights disregarded at me.
hypothesis: The approaching car's headlights looked back at me.
label: Contradiction
explanation: If something, i.e., the car's headlights are looking back at you, it is facing you, which is contradicted in another sentence that says the headlights disregarded.

premise: Can't have superiors using their agents as guinea pigs in poison trials, It isn't fair
hypothesis: Can't have superiors using their agents as guinea pigs in poison trials, not cricket
label: Entailment
explanation: The idiom not cricket is used to describe something that isn't fair, and in this context it isn't fair for superiors to use their agents as guinea pigs in poison trials.

premise: I came home to a huge pile of dog poop it was absolutely disgusting.
hypothesis: I came home to find a huge pile of dog poop and it absolutely made me sick to my stomach
label: Entailment
explanation: It is natural to feel sick to your stomach when you come home to a pile of dog poop because it is unhygienic and disgusting

premise: I dropped all my food in the cafeteria the other day and everybody was staring at me.
hypothesis: I was mortified when I accidentally dropped my food and everyone around me started to stare
label: Entailment
explanation: Most people feel a sense of embarrassment and shame when they make a mess in public and people around them start to stare

premise: I blamed my oldest son for losing my headphones but I found out later I was the one that lost them.
hypothesis: I felt super smart when I accused my oldest son for losing my headphones but later on I found out that I was the one who misplaced them
label: Contradiction
explanation: Accusing someone for something when you are the one at fault is not a smart feeling and makes a person feel bad about themselves.

premise: The distinction between the two theories barely exists.
hypothesis: The distinction between the two theories disintegrates.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To disintegrate means to break down or fall apart, while to barely exist means to barely be noticeable or distinguishable.

premise: We use our own custom software, so we can offer much more precision than what you can find in stores or commercially available.' , the CEO exclaimed”
hypothesis: We use our own custom software, so we can offer much more precision than what you can find off the shelf.' , the CEO exclaimed”
label: Entailment
explanation: Off the shelf means that it is ready made for purchase and not custom built, and the context is saying that the precision offered is better than what is off the shelf aka readily available for purchase.

premise: It was a struggle for me to complete the work.
hypothesis: I waded through the work.
label: Entailment
explanation: Wading through the work means it was a lot of work and it was difficult to get through it all.

premise: I was shamed when my son decided to drop his pants and pee in our front yard when the neighbors were out the other day.
hypothesis: I was so pleased with my son when he decided to drop his pants and pee in our front yard when the neighbors were out the other day.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would not be pleased but ashamed if their son decided to urinate in public where other people could see, as it is considered inappropriate and rude behaviour.

premise: It was obvious the firm would not pay for the settlement.
hypothesis: It was obvious the firm would foot the bill for the settlement.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To foot the bill means to pay for something, but in this sentence it was obvious the firm would not pay for the settlement.

premise: Impose a responsibility on someone.
hypothesis: Lay a responsibility on someone.
label: Entailment
explanation: When you lay a responsibility on someone, you are imposing a burden on them that they must bear.

premise: She avoids a lot of nonsense.
hypothesis: She babbles a lot of nonsense.
label: Contradiction

premise: Oh, you know how it is, mother, when you spend the night having sex with an absolute stranger in public, you just glow a little bit more than usual.
hypothesis: Oh, you know how it is, mother, when you spend the night having sex with an old flame in public, you just glow a little bit more than usual.
label: Contradiction
explanation: An old flame is a former lover, but spending the night with an absolute stranger would not make sense and would not cause one to glow

premise: The only reason he wanted to marry her was out of love.
hypothesis: His insistence on marrying a woman who didn't want him was just like a child demanding a particular toy because some other child had it.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A child who demands a particular toy because some other child has it is not motivated by love, but by greed or envy

premise: I barely even noticed the rich and complex network of lights inside of her because I was so focused on holding her hand.
hypothesis: I barely even noticed, though, because now that I was holding her hand, I saw a network of lights flaring inside of her like a bright snarled ball that sparked in millions of colors.
label: Entailment
explanation: The simile is used to describe the overwhelming nature of the bright snarled ball that sparked in millions of colors, and how the speaker was so focused on holding her hand that he barely even noticed them.

premise: There is nothing worse than not having any clothes clean for work.
hypothesis: I feel ecstatic that I have to go to work in clothes that are stained and wrinkled
label: Contradiction
explanation: It is not a good feeling to have to go to work in clothes that are stained and wrinkled because it makes one look unprofessional and like they don't care.

premise: She let anyone treat her very well and they did and she reacted, a lot.
hypothesis: She let anyone walk all over her and they did and she didn't react, not even a little.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To walk all over someone means to treat them very badly, but in this context she lets people treat her well and she reacts a lot

premise: “I might be mistaken, but Sean's father looked a bit drunk at the picnic, didn't he?
hypothesis: “I might be mistaken, but Sean's father looked a bit tired and emotional at the picnic, didn't he?
label: Entailment
explanation: Tired and emotional is a semi-polite or humorous euphemism for drunkenness, so in this context it is implying that Sean's father was drunk at the picnic.

premise: My son stole a car from an elderly man today, never have I been so let down.
hypothesis: I feel terrible that my son who is supposed to be the good one, stole a car from an elderly man today
label: Entailment
explanation: Stealing is wrong and especially stealing from an elderly man who can't defend himself

premise: It was obscene, she couldn't help but be disgusted by it.

label: Contradiction
explanation: A bad boy in a leather jacket is typically seen as attractive, so saying she was attracted to it implies that she found it attractive, not disgusting

premise: Man in the red pyjamas slammed the door of his room after shouting to his wife in a calm and level-headed manner.
hypothesis: Man in the red pyjamas slammed the door of his room after shouting to his wife in high dudgeon.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To be in high dudgeon is to be with resentment, angrily or furiously, but the context describes the man in the red pyjamas being calm and level-headed

premise: I got home today and my cat pooped on the bed.
hypothesis: When I got home today, I found my cat had pooped on the bed and it made me feel pretty darn pleased with myself
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would not be pleased to find their cat had pooped on the bed because it is a sign of disrespect and would make the person have to clean it up.

premise: I recently tried going vegan but I really disliked a lot of the dishes I tried.
hypothesis: So I tried veganism and it was so wonderful I literally threw up.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Veganism is a diet where people do not eat any animal products and so trying it and vomiting as a result implies that the person did not enjoy it and found it to be terrible and it cannot be wonderful.

premise: Life is not a public performance on the Violin, you only learn in school and use the learning rest of your life.
hypothesis: ’Life' wrote a friend of mine, 'is a public performance on the violin, in which you must learn the instrument as you go along.”
label: Contradiction
explanation: One sentence is saying that life is a journey where you are constantly learning and growing whereas the contradiction is saying that life is not a journey, you only learn in school and then use that learning for the rest of your life.

premise: On the rock, at her feet, anita was moving.
hypothesis: On the rock, at her feet, anita was like a discarded wax figurine.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A discarded wax figurine would not be moving

premise: Fear began to set in as she considered the possibility that she may have trouble successfully joining their network.
hypothesis: Fear began to take root as she considered the possibility that she may have trouble successfully joining their network.
label: Entailment
explanation: To take root means to begin to take hold or have effect, which in this context is the fear beginning to set in.

premise: After weeks of being cooped up in that house, my words come out huffed, pitched high and strong.
hypothesis: After all these weeks of being shut in that house, my words appear like an engine whistle
label: Entailment
explanation: An engine whistle is loud and piercing, and it is used to indicate that the engine is about to start, so the simile indicates the voice is loud and piercing.

premise: The active and aggressive competition in the privateering sector.
hypothesis: The cut and thrust in the privateering sector.
label: Entailment
explanation: The cut and thrust of an activity refers to the lively, competitive and sometimes aggressive way in which it is done, which is what is happening in the privateering sector.

premise: Either they reject the behavior attitudes or characteristics of the people of a different culture in which one now lives or they can be used to produce new faerie children.
hypothesis: Either they go native and forget their former lives or they can be used to produce new faerie children.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To go native means to adopt the behavior attitudes or characteristics of the people of a different culture in which one now lives, but the sentence describes rejecting those behaviors instead

premise: All my friends got to go on vacation but I'm stuck here doing work because I have a tight job deadline.
hypothesis: I feel really left out because all my friends got to go on vacation while I'm stuck here working like a dog
label: Entailment
explanation: When all of your friends go on vacation while you're stuck at work it can feel very isolating and as if you're being left out on purpose

premise: She began to knock feverishly as if she had to hurry up and finish before the time ran out.
hypothesis: She began to knock feverishly as if she had to beat the clock.
label: Entailment
explanation: To beat the clock means to finish before the time is up, so she was knocking feverishly in order to hurry up and finish before the time ran out.

premise: I had no friends in high school, misery is being surrounded by an entire class and no one talking to you.
hypothesis: I felt terrible that I had no friends in high school and felt like an outsider
label: Entailment
explanation: It is common to feel terrible and like an outsider when someone has no friends in high school because humans are social creatures and need companionship

premise: I put my food on fire, just to check something outside, and my food got burnt
hypothesis: Love how I totally set my food on fire because I was curious about something outside, and now it's all charred
label: Contradiction
explanation: Setting food on fire due to curiosity about something outside is not a thing to be loved as it can easily lead to the food being charred and inedible.

premise: Jake tried to remove the crystal from the battery to silence the phone, but it was loose.
hypothesis: Jake tried to pull the crystal off the battery to silence the phone, but it was stuck like a barnacle to a rusty ship.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A barnacle is a small marine crustacean that attaches itself to a ship's hull, and is very difficult to remove

premise: So I have been influenced to reject it because of something heard, seen, or read, sir.
hypothesis: So I have been lead to believe, sir.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To lead to believe means to cause one to believe something, but in this context the person has been caused to reject it.

premise: I drunk texted my boss last night telling him everything that is wrong with his management style and think I'll get fired.
hypothesis: I am really carefree that my boss might have received the drunk text message I sent him last night about his terrible management style
label: Contradiction
explanation: A drunk text message is often regretted after sending and so receiving it back from the boss would create a lot of anxiety and hence not being carefree at all.

premise: The skin was gray and thick .
hypothesis: The skin was like an elephant's hide .
label: Entailment
explanation: Elephant hide is gray and thick, so the skin in the sentence must be gray and thick as well.

premise: My son raided the snack cupboard before dinnertime, eating all my favourite snacks, and he made a mess out of it.
hypothesis: My son ate all my favorite snacks before dinner which was great and he made things even better by making a huge mess of the cupboard in the process.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A child eating all of someone's favorite snacks before dinner is not a good thing because it leaves them with nothing to eat and also creates a mess.

premise: I racked up a lot of money on my credit card shortly after paying it off.
hypothesis: I am so proud of myself since I charged a lot of money on my credit card shortly after paying it off in full.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Charging a lot of money on a credit card shortly after paying it off in full is not a smart thing to do and so someone who is proud of themselves for doing that is being ironic.

premise: I have been trying to purchase a car but my credit is so bad.
hypothesis: I feel like the world is against me because I have been trying to purchase a car but my credit is so terrible
label: Entailment
explanation: Most people need a car to get around and not having a car can be a very isolating experience, especially if someone's credit is bad and they can't get financing for a car

premise: I studied really hard for my annual exam but did not get my desired grade.
hypothesis: I was ecstatic to find out that all my studying for the annual exam did not reflect in my grade
label: Contradiction
explanation: Studying for an annual exam is often a waste of time if the grade received does not reflect the effort put in, so someone being ecstatic about this is absurd.

premise: The new paper boy flung the newspaper and broke my window today morning
hypothesis: The new paper boy threw the newspaper so hard it broke my window this morning
label: Entailment
explanation: The newspaper was delivered with such force that it broke the window

premise: The smell of smoke took off on the delinquent.
hypothesis: The smell of smoke carpeted on the delinquent.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Carpeting something would mean to cover it completely, while taking off would mean to leave or depart.

premise: I was very worried when the doctor told me I needed heart surgery.
hypothesis: When the doctor told me I needed heart surgery, I was so happy I just wanted to celebrate that ominious moment.
label: Contradiction
explanation: When someone is told that they need heart surgery, it is not a happy moment because it means that they are not healthy and might need an operation which is a very serious procedure.

premise: My social anxiety acted up and I failed at doing basic math in my head when paying the cashier
hypothesis: I was so embarrassed when my social anxiety caused me to make a mistake while paying the cashier
label: Entailment
explanation: It is common for people with social anxiety to make mistakes in social situations because they are so nervous and this often leads to feelings of embarrassment

premise: Yesterday was my sister's birthday and I totally forgot to call her until today
hypothesis: I feel terrible that I forgot my sister's birthday and only remembered to call her today
label: Entailment
explanation: It is customary to call people on their birthday and wish them a happy birthday so forgetting to do that and only remembering today would make most people feel terrible

premise: My son was caught cheating on a test, I really thought we raised him better than to do such things.
hypothesis: I am elated that my son cheated on a test because it clearly shows he is better than all the other kids.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A son cheating on a test is not something to be elated of because it shows that the child has not been studying and is resorting to underhanded methods.

premise: For the last two years, he had been holding it together by spending a lot of money.
hypothesis: For the last two years, he had been holding it together on a shoestring.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To be on a shoestring means to be on a very tight or limited financial budget, but this context describes holding it together by spending a lot of money

premise: My birthday was yesterday and I didn't get a single happy birthday message from anybody family or friends.
hypothesis: It really sucks that my birthday was yesterday and I didn't get a single happy birthday message from anyone in my family or friends
label: Entailment
explanation: Birthdays are special days where people usually take the time to send well wishes and so not receiving any messages on such a day often makes people feel bad because it seems like they are being ignored by the people who matter to them

premise: But you've got to not solve the problem decisively.
hypothesis: But you've got to put your cards on the table.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To put your cards on the table means to solve a problem decisively, but in this context they are not solving the problem decisively.
idiom: put your cards on the table

premise: I am so mad my insurance company keeps denying a valid claim and it causes the Doctor to send me a bill!
hypothesis: I love how my insurance company keeps denying a valid claim and causing the Doctor to send me a bill!
label: Contradiction
explanation: A health insurance company is supposed to help people cover the costs of medical treatments and procedures, but if they deny a valid claim then it would cause the person to have to pay out of their own pocket which is not something to love at all.

premise: Man, my best friend just got a Lamborghini!
hypothesis: I really love how my best friend just got a beautiful Lamborghini while I am still driving my 1998 Honda Civic
label: Contradiction
explanation: It's unlikely to love the situation in context because their best friend just got a very luxurious car while they are still driving an old car which shows the disparity between their wealth and status.

premise: He turned back and said, "I am sort of, oh, what do you say? An individual with no specific skills."
hypothesis: He turned back and said, "I am sort of, oh, what do you say? A jack of all trades."
label: Contradiction
explanation: A jack of all trades is a person who is skilled in many different areas, but this context describes an individual with no specific skills.

premise: He was strong and sturdy.
hypothesis: He was like a butterfly in autumn, waiting to be destroyed by the first frost.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A butterfly in autumn is close to the end of its life, and is not strong and sturdy

premise: I get aggravated by people that don't understand personal space.
hypothesis: I love people that invade my personal space and make me feel uncomfortable.
label: Contradiction
explanation: People who invade personal space often do so without consent and make the person feel uncomfortable, so to say that someone loves people like that is really ironic.

premise: I am so mad at my cable company because my internet and TV keeps going out and their technicians are incompetant!
hypothesis: I am so thrilled with my cable company because their oh-so competent technicians are of no help as the internet and TV keeps going out.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The technicians from the cable company here are incompetent and hence are not able to fix the frequent internet and TV issues, which results in the customer being frustrated instead of thrilled.

premise: All the men were made kinder and gentler.
hypothesis: All the hearts of men were  softened.
label: Entailment
explanation: Softer hearts means they were kinder and gentler

premise: At his pace he checked and started to make progress.
hypothesis: Though his pace he checked and slackened.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To slacken something means to lessen or decrease, while to make progress means to move forward or advance.

premise: I warned you I would act immaturely and have a meltdown
hypothesis: I warned you I'd be a big baby.
label: Entailment
explanation: To be a big baby is to be prone to immature behavior, and in this sentence the speaker is warning that they will act immaturely.

premise: Awful seeing a naked man run through my neighborhood.
hypothesis: The sight of a man running through my neighborhood sans clothes was pretty disgusting
label: Entailment
explanation: It is considered very inappropriate to be naked in public and so seeing a man running through the neighborhood naked would be considered disgusting by most people

premise: There is nothing like being betrayed by someone you love
hypothesis: I feel like my world has just turned magnificient after being betrayed by the person I loved
label: Contradiction
explanation: Being betrayed by someone you love can be really hurtful and often has a negative impact on a person, therefore it cannot be considered as something that has turned their world magnificient.

premise: Tears had rolled down my eyes and my face was red.
hypothesis: My eyes welled up and I could feel my face turning red.
label: Entailment
explanation: The metaphor - welled up - means that I was so embarrassed that I started crying and my face turned red.

premise: The drought has made the water level at the reservoir really really low.
hypothesis: The lack of rain had depressed the water level in the reservoir.
label: Entailment
explanation: The drought has made the water level at the reservoir really low.

premise: The dollar will soon be devalued by inflation.
hypothesis: The dollar has been dried by inflation.
label: Entailment
explanation: Drying is a process that removes moisture from something, so, in this case, the dollar has been dried of its value by inflation.

premise: War was a fantasy.
hypothesis: War was a nightmare.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A nightmare is a bad dream that is often scary or unsettling, while a fantasy is a pleasant daydream or an imaginary situation.

premise: Man, they would totally and aggressively attack him for dating an older woman.
hypothesis: Man, they would go for the jugular with him dating an older woman.
label: Entailment
explanation: To go for the jugular means to attack in the most aggressive way possible, and in this sentence the man is being attacked for dating an older woman.

premise: David’s eyes were warm with compassion at Paul when Paul invited his new girlfriend to dance.
hypothesis: David’s eyes were like daggers at Paul when Paul invited his new girlfriend to dance.
label: Contradiction
explanation: It is impossible that David was angry at Paul for inviting his new girlfriend to dance, but felt compassion towards him at the same time, thus the sentences are contradictory to each other.

premise: He pulls out a giant disc and holds it up shamefully.
hypothesis: He pulls a giant disc out and flashes it like a knockoff rolex .
label: Contradiction

premise: And Sean was guaranteed to experience something unexpectedly pleasant or beneficial.

premise: Even though nobody is paying attention to what is happening, someone has to keep an eye on what goes on up here at the institute.

premise: I failed my accounting class over the summer.
