explanation: To go begging means to be available for one to take or claim, but in this sentence they are not asking for cooperation.

premise: Mike nods and trots over c although it would have been better if it happened earlier, at least it's happening now.
hypothesis: Mike nods and trots over c better late than never.
label: Entailment
explanation: The idiom better late than never means that the delayed occurrence or achievement of something is better than it not happening at all, which is what is happening in this sentence.

premise: I get why they would stay away from her if she was mean and vicious, but she's not.
hypothesis: i'd understand if they stayed away from her because she was like a hungry coyote , but she isn't
label: Entailment
explanation: A coyote is a wild animal that is known to be mean and vicious, so if the person is like a coyote, it would make sense for people to stay away from her.

premise: Its a beautiful day outside today buts I have no one to share it with.
hypothesis: It feels like my life is really worth living given I have no one to share this beautiful day with.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would say that they feel sad and down when they have no one to share their day with and hence the speaker is not really being truthful.

premise: It was really crazy when people started running out of the theater.
hypothesis: People were streaming out of the theater.
label: Entailment
explanation: Streaming out of the theater means that people were leaving the theater in a hurry.

premise: They were creepy things, white and squishy
hypothesis: They were like a crusty chunk of brie cheese with legs.
label: Entailment
explanation: Brie cheese is a soft, squishy white cheese that is often considered to be quite delicious edible but someone resembling like with legs is not normal and very creepy.

premise: Yesterday two gangs were fighting just in front of my home.
hypothesis: Yesterday I saw two gangs fighting right in front of my house and it totally didn't make me scared at all
label: Contradiction
explanation: The sight of two gangs fighting is often very violent and can invoke fear in people, so someone who saw it and wasn't scared is not being truthful.

premise: I was feeling pretty much alone when I didn't see my boyfriend for two days.
hypothesis: I felt really abandoned when I didn't see my boyfriend for two days
label: Entailment
explanation: Not seeing a loved one for an extended period of time can often make people feel abandoned, panicked, and anxious

premise: I'm so excited for the days yet to come,
hypothesis: In the days long since  departed  ,
label: Contradiction
explanation: The days long since departed would be referring to the past, while the days yet to come would be referring to the future.

premise: I woke up to find my wallet missing.
hypothesis: Glad that I woke up to find my wallet was stolen and all my money missing
label: Contradiction
explanation: No one would be glad to wake up to find their wallet stolen and all their money missing because it is a very unpleasant and scary experience.

premise: Are you not listening to me?
hypothesis: Am I talking to a brick wall?
label: Entailment
explanation: This metaphor is saying that the person is talking to someone who is not paying attention and they are getting frustrated.

premise: Ironically, my reading assignment for the weekend was available and easy to find.
hypothesis: Ironically, my reading assignment for the weekend was gone with the wind.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Gone with the wind means that something has disappeared, but the context describes the opposite by saying the assignment is easy to find.

premise: I was babysitting my cousin few days ago and she kept throwing her food on the floor.
hypothesis: I was so happy when my cousin threw her food on the floor and it so made me want to babysit her again
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would not enjoy having to clean up someone else's food that they threw on the floor and so that makes babysitting a painful task and being happy about it does not make sense.

premise: Some people egged my house.
hypothesis: Some people threw eggs at my house and it made me so happy
label: Contradiction
explanation: Getting eggs thrown at your house is a sign of vandalism and is definitely not a thing to be happy about.

premise: I once took a dive into the pool and came up with no swim trunks.
hypothesis: I remember the fantastic time when I dived into the pool and came up with no swim trunks.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Diving into a pool without swim trunks can lead to someone's private parts being exposed and so it was not a good experience for them.

premise: In the dead of summer, in Ohio, the clothes felt hot and humid
hypothesis: In the dead of summer, in Ohio, the clothes felt like melting rubber.
label: Entailment
explanation: Melting rubber is hot and sticky, so the clothes felt hot and humid.

premise: Death has come at the door.
hypothesis: Death is knocking at the door.
label: Entailment
explanation: This word - knocking - is used to mean that that death is coming.

premise: I felt very unpleasant last week when I fell to the ground my first time skateboarding
hypothesis: I felt like a superstar when I fell down to the ground and skinned my knee my first time skateboarding
label: Contradiction
explanation: Skinning one's knee is a very painful experience and shows that they aren't good at skateboarding and hence they feel stupid about themselves instead of feeling like a superstar who are actually good at it

premise: I have no will power because I swore off fast food this month and today I had McDonalds.
hypothesis: I feel so responsible and proud about succumbing to my will power and eating McDonalds today when I swore off fast food this month.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Someone who succumbs to their will power and eats something they had sworn off earlier, like fast food, is not being responsible or proud because they are not sticking to their commitment.

premise: I go to bed early, see?.
hypothesis: I burn the midnight oil, see?
label: Contradiction
explanation: To burn the midnight oil means to stay up late working, but this sentence describes going to bed early instead.

premise: I tried to meet some friends yesterday but they were all busy.
hypothesis: It makes me feel really lonely when I try to meet friends and they are all too busy
label: Entailment
explanation: Its common to feel lonely when trying to meet friends and discovering that they are all busy because it can be a reminder of how isolated someone feels

premise: Its not like you speak vaguely.
hypothesis: Its not like you beat about the bush.
label: Entailment
explanation: To beat about the bush means to speak vaguely so as to avoid talking directly about an unpleasant topic.

premise: Instead of giving me dirty looks and saying mean things quietly?
hypothesis: Instead of throwing me dirty looks and mumbling under your breath?
label: Entailment
explanation: To say something under your breath is to say it in a very quiet voice, often because you don't want others to hear.

premise: I asked a girl out for dinner today and she turned me down while a lot of people overheard.
hypothesis: Got turned down by a girl for dinner today in front of a lot of people and feeling really confident about myself.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Being turned down for dinner by a girl in public is not a good thing to happen and so someone who is feeling confident about themselves after that event is clearly delusional.

premise: The torch was switched on and stayed on twice.
hypothesis: The torch was switched on and off twice.
label: Contradiction
explanation: On and off means irresolute or wavering, but staying on is the opposite of this.

premise: His mother was definitely nervous - she had probably noticed.
hypothesis: His mother had no doubt noticed; she looked like a turkey on thanksgiving.
label: Entailment
explanation: A turkey on thanksgiving is a symbol of nervousness and anxiety because it is going to be roasted, so the simile is indicating that his mother is nervous and probably noticed.

premise: Alexander's spirits sank.
hypothesis: Alexander's spirits rose.
label: Contradiction
explanation: If someone gets good news their spirits may rise at the good news but their spirit cannot sink at the same time.

premise: This weekend Im going to go sky diving with my best friend and I hate heights!
hypothesis: I've never felt so calm and cool knowing that I am going to go sky diving this weekend with my best friend.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people feel scared and anxious when they think about going sky diving which is a dangerous activity and hence it is not likely for someone to feel calm and cool about it especially when they hate heights.

premise: Now he feels agitated
hypothesis: Now he feels like a high mountain lake without a wind stirring it.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A mountain lake without any wind stirring it is typically very still and calm and not agitating

premise: My parents always argue and it pisses me off!
hypothesis: My parents always argue and it really comforts me to see them fight all the time!
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would not find it comforting to see their parents argue because it can be a very distressing experience.

premise: Yesterday I got fired from my job.
hypothesis: Yesterday was the happiest I've ever been because I got fired from my job
label: Contradiction
explanation: Losing a job is never a good thing and so someone being happy about it cannot be justified.

premise: Once now remember, this is a vacation, not carte blanche for you to act out of control.
hypothesis: Once now remember, this is a vacation, not carte blanche for you to run amok.
label: Entailment
explanation: To run amok means to go awry or to act out of control, and in this context speaker wants others to not excercise complete freedom to act out of control on a vacation.

premise: My upstairs neighbor moved out recently and blocked the parking space by leaving all her trash and furniture there.
hypothesis: I'm so happy that my upstairs neighbor left all her trash and furniture after she moved out and blocked the parking space
label: Contradiction
explanation: The fact that the upstairs neighbor left all her trash and furniture after she moved out and blocked the parking space is really inconsiderate and not something to be happy for.

premise: Some people egged my house.
hypothesis: Some people threw eggs at my house and it made me so mad
label: Entailment
explanation: Having eggs thrown at your house is a form of vandalism and it is very frustrating for the victim

premise: Colby, figure out and have a clear understanding of your emotions.
hypothesis: Colby, get a handle on your emotions.
label: Entailment
explanation: To get a handle on something means to have a firm understanding of it, so in this sentence Colby is being told to figure out and understand his emotions.

premise: My flight got delayed and now I have to stay in the airport all alone overnight sleeping on the ground like a dog.
hypothesis: The fact that my flight got delayed and I now have to spend the night sleeping on the airport floor like an animal makes me feel extremey happy and comfortable
label: Contradiction
explanation: The experience of sleeping on the airport floor is uncomfortable and not desirable at all and so having it happen because of a flight delay does not make it any better.

premise: He was very handsome
hypothesis: He was as handsome as the vampire in Nosferatu
label: Contradiction
explanation: The vampire in Nosferatu is an ugly creature, so saying someone is as handsome as him would imply that the person is not good looking

premise: Hardy was cheerful by the time sixth period photography came around.
hypothesis: By the time sixth period photography rolled around, hardy was like a bear with a thorn in its paw.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A bear with a thorn in its paw would be in pain and not cheerful

premise: Not to share the bank with the table, or to take some minor part of it, but to take it all for themselves without any restraint.
hypothesis: Not to share the bank with the table, or to take some minor part of it, but to go the whole hog.
label: Entailment
explanation: Usually to go the whole hog refers to doing something as thoroughly as possible , taking it all for oneself or without any restraint.

premise: My dog urinated on my work papers
hypothesis: I was so pleased when I found my work papers urinated on by my dog.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Finding work papers urinated on by a dog is a very distressing experience and not something pleasant.

premise: Even though her face was calm, she seemed relaxed.
hypothesis: Her face was calm but she seemed like a coiled spring .
label: Contradiction
explanation: A coiled spring is tightly wound and ready to release its energy, so saying someone is like a coiled spring implies that they are not relaxed

premise: He was very shy.
hypothesis: He was shy like a monkey.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Monekys are not shy since because unlike humans they don't follow human social norms so he was not shy

premise: I felt very lonely when my partner decided to leave me for someone else.
hypothesis: The feeling of being so alone when my partner decided to leave me was really fun
label: Contradiction
explanation: The feeling of being alone is often not a good one and so someone describing it as being really fun is not accurate.

premise: She looked proud as she said no.
hypothesis: No, she declared, now looking like a peacock.
label: Entailment
explanation: A peacock is a proud bird, and so the simile is used to convey that the woman looks proud.

premise: His voice sounded incredibly slow and draggy
hypothesis: His voice sounded like a 78-rpm record turned down to 33 1/3.
label: Entailment
explanation: A 78-rpm record played at 33 1/3 would sound incredibly slow and draggy because of lower almost half speed.

premise: I do something to upset or harm tatianna in order to get revenge because she did the same thing to me first.
hypothesis: I oblige the reversal with tit for tatianna.
label: Entailment
explanation: Tit for tat is an act of revenge, so by obliging the reversal, the speaker is getting revenge on Tatianna.

premise: The word came out of him unstoppably this time, from deep inside.
hypothesis: This time, the word sprung from deep inside him like an avalanche.
label: Entailment
explanation: An avalanche is an unstoppable force, so the word coming out of him like an avalanche means that it came out of him very forcefully and powerfully.

premise: A fun time was ruined as soon as she left the party.
hypothesis: The party died as soon as she left.
label: Entailment
explanation: The party died means that the party was no longer fun once she left.

premise: His throat had gone wet.
hypothesis: His throat had gone like a shriveled-up leaf .
label: Contradiction
explanation: A shriveled-up leaf is dry, so saying his throat had gone like that would imply it had gone dry as well, not wet

premise: Yes, another security guard, Caitlyn assumed, since he was towering at over six feet tall and looked fragile.
hypothesis: Yes another security guard, caitlyn assumed, since he was well over six feet tall and looked like an army tank.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Army tanks are big and strong since they are used in combat, so comparing someone to an army tank would imply that the person is big and strong, not fragile

premise: His heart within him is fully rotten.
hypothesis: And his heart within him  fluttered  ,
label: Contradiction
explanation: Fluttering would suggest that the man's heart is beating rapidly, while rotten would suggest that the man's heart is dead or no longer functioning.

premise: I planted some beautiful flowers and rabbits came and nibbled on them last night.
hypothesis: I was so excited that my beautiful flowers were flourishing and then I felt even better when I came in this morning and saw that the rabbits ate them all last night.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Flowers usually represent beauty and so seeing them be eaten by rabbits overnight would be a devastating sight and make someone feel terrible.

premise: I went grocery shopping the other day and didn't realize I had left my wallet until it was time to pay.
hypothesis: I feel like a genius because I left my wallet at home when I went grocery shopping
label: Contradiction
explanation: It is not a wise decision to leave your wallet at home when you go grocery shopping because you would need money to buy the groceries and so someone who does that is not considered to be a genius.

premise: I was really wishing I was moving to New York like my friend.
hypothesis: I wasn't jealous at all when my friend told me that she is moving to New York leaving me behind.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would be jealous upon hearing that their friend is moving away and leaving them behind and especially when its a city of possibilities like New York

premise: My cat just scratched up my brand new leather couch while I was at work.
hypothesis: I am so pleased that my cat scratched up my brand new leather couch while I was at work
label: Contradiction
explanation: Leather couches are often very expensive and so having them scratched up by a pet is definitely not a pleasing thing.

premise: Katie’s plan to get into college was well-thought out.
hypothesis: Katie’s plan to get into college was a house of cards on a crooked table.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Katie's plan to get into college was a house of cards on a crooked table, i.e., it was not well-thought out and was likely to collapse.

premise: He looked like he was already ahead.
hypothesis: It looked like he was back to square one.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To be back at square one is to be back at the beginning, but this sentence suggests he's already ahead

premise: These rivers come from a mountain range in the himalayas.
hypothesis: These rivers head from a mountain range in the himalayas.
label: Entailment
explanation: Head from means that the rivers start from the mountain range.

premise: A coworker mad me very mad one day by slamming a large order of work on my desk and basically demanding that I do it.
hypothesis: I was extremely happy one day when my coworker threw a large order of work on my desk and basically demanded that I do it
label: Contradiction
explanation: Receiving a large order of work from a coworker can be really daunting and stressful and so being happy about it is not really justified.

premise: I ordered chicken the other day and it was still pink on the inside.
hypothesis: I was ecstatic when I found out the chicken I ordered was still pink on the inside
label: Contradiction
explanation: Finding out that the chicken someone ordered was still pink means that it was not cooked properly and getting uncooked food doesn't make one happy.

premise: Then he collided into something soft and fluffy
hypothesis: Then he collided into something like a marshmallow pond.
label: Entailment
explanation: A marshmallow pond would be expected to be soft and fluffy, so whatever he collided with is soft and fluffy.

premise: He hated to see or experience failure.
hypothesis: He hated the stench of failure.
label: Entailment
explanation: The stench of failure is the bad experience that comes from failing.

premise: A weather vane under the building.
hypothesis: A weather vane caps the building.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A weather vane is used to sit on the top as described in one sentence whereas another sentence says it is under the building.

premise: My vengeance shall reach him.
hypothesis: That my vengeance shall not  reach  him ! .
label: Contradiction
explanation: one sentence is a metaphor, and another sentence contradicts it because it states that the speaker will take action to ensure that their vengeance is carried out.

premise: He would dispose of scouring the hotel for her, nate was sure.
hypothesis: He would make light work of scouring the hotel for her, nate was sure.
label: Entailment
explanation: To make light work of means to deal with finish or dispose of someone or something very quickly or handily, which is what he would do with the hotel according to the context.

premise: It's owner might be extremely sane, but she was also acting sweeter than one.
hypothesis: It's owner might be nutty as a fruitcake, but she was also acting sweeter than one.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To be nutty as a fruitcake is to be crazy or wacky, but in this context the owner is acting sane and sweet

premise: My friend would not stop whistling even though she knows I can't stand it.
hypothesis: My friend is really considerate to keep whistling even though she knows I despise the sound.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Whistling is a common way to communicate with someone and so if someone knows that the sound annoys someone else, then it is not considerate of them to keep doing it.

premise: Your suspicion is completely wrong.
hypothesis: Your suspicion is wide of the mark.
label: Entailment
explanation: To be wide of the mark means to be inaccurate or wrong, and in this context the suspicion is completely wrong.

premise: I was furious when my sister tore all my comics
hypothesis: I was really cheerful when my sister ripped all my comics
label: Contradiction
explanation: Ripping someone's comics is usually considered to be a destructive act and so receiving joy from it is highly unlikely.

premise: The avalanche destroyed anything in its path like a bulldozer.
hypothesis: The avalanche torpedoed anything standing in its way.
label: Entailment
explanation: Avalanches are known for their destructive power and this is being compared to a bulldozer which is a machine that is also very powerful and can destroy things in its path.

premise: Good, I'll see you first thing in the morning tomorrow.
hypothesis: Good, ill see you two bright and early tomorrow.
label: Entailment
explanation: To see someone bright and early means to see them very early in the morning, which is the same as seeing them first thing in the morning.

premise: I just ran out of financial aid for school.
hypothesis: I just found out that I won't be able to afford to go to school anymore because I used up all my financial aid
label: Entailment
explanation: Once someone has used up all their financial aid for school they often have to drop out because they can no longer afford the tuition, which is why finding out that one has used up all their financial aid can be very disheartening

premise: My son stole a car from an elderly man today, never have I been so let down.
hypothesis: I feel proud that my son who is supposed to be the good one, stole a car from an elderly man today
label: Contradiction
explanation: When a child steals something, it is generally considered to be bad and not something to be proud of.

premise: Let's leave this question decided and resolved by next week.
hypothesis: Let's leave this question up in the air until next week.
label: Contradiction
explanation: When something is up in the air, it is undecided and subject to change, but in this context it is decided and resolved

premise: Ever since we met, she continued, we've been unable to agree with each other on anything.
hypothesis: Ever since we met,she continued, we've been at loggerheads.
label: Entailment
explanation: To be at loggerheads with someone means to be in conflict with them, which is what the sentence describes.

premise: The predators never expected their enemies to be this vulnerable.
hypothesis: The predators never anticipated their enemies would be this much like titanium.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Titanium is a metal that is very strong and resistant to corrosion, meaning it would be very difficult to defeat an enemy that is like titanium

premise: Are you confused on which horse to put all the money to?
hypothesis: Which horse are you depending  on.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Depending on something means to rely or count on it, while to be confused about something means to be uncertain or undecided.

premise: I was discussing phone bills with my friend and he told me his parents pay for his bill.
hypothesis: I didn't feel jealous at all when my friend told me his parents actually pay for his phone bill
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would feel jealous when their friend tells them that their parents are paying for their phone bill because it implies that the person does not have to work for it and hence is privileged.

premise: The years have made the tension from the past few months seem small.
hypothesis: Those years had made the tension of the last few months like a gray bug compared to a boulder.
label: Entailment
explanation: A boulder is much larger than a bug, so the simile is emphasizing how the years have made the tension from the past few months seem small in comparison.

premise: I went to a baby shower for my friend the other day only to realize I bought a present for a baby boy and not a baby girl!
hypothesis: I felt like a hero when I realized that I brought a present for a baby boy to a baby shower for a baby girl
label: Contradiction
explanation: Realizing that you have brought a present for the wrong baby gender at a baby shower is not a heroic moment, but instead an embarrassing one.

premise: I injured my ankle 4 years ago and I couldn't lift weights
hypothesis: I was devastated when I found out that I can't lift weights because of the ankle injury I sustained 4 years ago
label: Entailment
explanation: An ankle injury can often be a very debilitating thing and not being able to do something as simple as lift weights because of it is often devastating to people

premise: My boss is giving preferential treatment to certain groups of people
hypothesis: It really encourages me when my boss gives preferential treatment to some people over others
label: Contradiction
explanation: Being given preferential treatment at work could lead to jealousy and resentment among coworkers and is not something that should encourage others.

premise: The girl sewed very carefully.
hypothesis: The girl sewed as carefully as a bull
label: Contradiction
explanation: Bulls are not known to be careful, so the simile is emphasizing how recklessly the girl is sewing

premise: The judge will want to charge and convict you with the minimum number of crimes.
hypothesis: The judge will want to throw the book at you.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To throw the book at someone means to charge or convict them with as many crimes as possible, but the judge in this context wants to do the opposite.

premise: I think it's your cheerful and optimistic disposition that's made me take a shine to you, I say as I reach out and catch the hooks and pass one over to constance.
hypothesis: I think it's your sunny nature that's made me take a shine to you, I say as I reach out and catch the hooks and pass one over to constance.
label: Entailment
explanation: To take a shine to someone is to have a fondness for them, and in this context the speaker is saying that it's because the person is sunny and cheerful that they have taken a shine to them.

premise: I fell asleep at work yesterday.
hypothesis: I feel overjoyed that I nodded off at my desk yesterday
label: Contradiction
explanation: Sleeping at one's desk is often frowned upon because it signifies that the person is not working hard enough and is not taking their job seriously and hence doesn't warrant feeling overjoyed

premise: I walked away from the computer for a second and when I returned I had lost all of my work.
hypothesis: I feel delighted that all my work disappeared when I walked away from the computer for a second
label: Contradiction
explanation: Usually work is saved before walking away from the computer, so it would be frustrating if it all disappeared and hence the person would not feel delighted but rather angry or upset.

premise: The animal in the middle of the sea was tiny.
hypothesis: The animal in the middle of the sea was a mountain.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The animal is suggested as very large in one statement whereas another statement suggests it is a small animal.

premise: I have tried three different times to complete a work task and each time I have failed.
hypothesis: I have failed three times to complete a work task and each time it feels like my world is beautiful.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A work task should be completed successfully on the first try and so someone who keeps failing at it cannot find any beauty in their world.

premise: A tornado went through my house.
hypothesis: Extremely happy now that the tornado has completely destroyed my house and I don't know what to do
label: Contradiction
explanation: A tornado is a natural disaster that can cause a lot of damage to property and so someone cannot be happy about it

premise: The argument is written well
hypothesis: The argument is as well written as Twilight
label: Contradiction
explanation: The Twilight series is not well written, so the simile is saying that the argument is not well written either

premise: I went grocery shopping the other day and didn't realize I had left my wallet until it was time to pay.
hypothesis: Clearly I am the smartest person because I clearly left my wallet at home when I went grocery shopping
label: Contradiction
explanation: It is not a wise decision to leave your wallet at home when you go grocery shopping because you would need money to buy the groceries and so someone who does that is not considered to be a genius.

premise: Someone stole the stereo out of my car.
hypothesis: Some kind person decided to steal my car stereo which makes really thankful
label: Contradiction
explanation: Having someone steal something from you is never a good thing and so being thankful for it is quite bizarre.

premise: She was about my age, but her lost-child expressions gave the impression of her being nothing more than a very experienced and mature person.
hypothesis: She was about my age, but her lost-child expressions gave the impression of her being nothing more than a babe in arms.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A babe in arms is a person who is gullible, naïve, or lacks experience, but in this sentence she is being described as experienced and mature.

premise: I hate the fact that everyone in my neighborhood drives a nicer car than me.
hypothesis: I can't help but feel pleased when I see everyone in my neighborhood driving a nicer car than me
label: Contradiction
explanation: Owing to the comparison effect, when someone sees people in their neighborhood driving nicer cars than them, it makes them feel worse about themselves instead of pleased as they do not have a car that is as nice.

premise: There was hair in my soup and the owner wouldn't take responsibility.
hypothesis: The fact that I found hair in my soup and the owner refused to take responsibility made me feel sick to my stomach
label: Entailment
explanation: Soup is often considered a very clean dish and so finding hair in it can be extremely off-putting

premise: It felt slightly uncomfortable, something is going to happen, but no-one knows exactly what it might be.
hypothesis: It felt a little like a first date
label: Entailment
explanation: A first date is often slightly uncomfortable because both parties are still getting to know each other and are unsure of what to expect.

premise: People are always parking in front of my apartment.
hypothesis: It makes me proud when people always park in front of my apartment
label: Contradiction
explanation: People parking in front of someone's apartment often blocks their way and leaves no space for the other cars, so it is not a proud thing to have people do that.

premise: It may be the feds are just a little nervous about your media popularity so they have decided not to act with full regard for our wellbeing.
hypothesis: It may be the feds are just a little nervous about your media popularity so they have decided not to run roughshod over us.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To run roughshod over something means to act without regard for it, but in this context instead of not acting without regard for the speakers wellbeing, the feds are actually not acting with full regard

premise: Now is the best time to do this right?
hypothesis: There's no time like the present right?
label: Entailment
explanation: No time like the present means that if something is a good idea or needs to be done, it should be done now.

premise: My wife asked me to clean the house while she was away for a few days and I ended up wasting my time playing video games instead.
hypothesis: I feel terrible that I played video games instead of cleaning the house like my wife asked me to
label: Entailment
explanation: Cleaning the house is often seen as a chore and not something people want to do so its easy to understand why someone would rather play video games instead, however not doing what your wife asked you to do often leaves people feeling guilty

premise: My doctor told me to give up caffeine to help calm down my anxiety.
hypothesis: The fact that I get to give up something as amazing as caffeine in order to get rid of my anxiety makes me feel absolutely great.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Caffeine is often used as a means to cope with anxiety and so giving it up in order to get rid of anxiety implies that it is not a good thing and makes the person feel bad instead of great.

premise: The whole family moved out with all of their belongings.
hypothesis: The whole family moved out bag and baggage.
label: Entailment
explanation: To move out bag and baggage means to move out with all of one's belongings, which is what the family did.

premise: You have no idea why people suddenly have become healthy.
hypothesis: You have no idea why people suddenly have become like lepers.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A leper is someone who has a severe, contagious disease, so the simile is implying that the people have become diseased, not healthy

premise: People who do bad things will be rewarded by having no work and a lot of tranquillity, Eddie.
hypothesis: no peace for the wicked, Eddie.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The idiom "no peace for the wicked" means that someone's heavy workload or lack of tranquillity is punishment for a sinful life, but in this context the person is being rewarded instead

premise: Adrienne was the one person who fit in perfectly.
hypothesis: Adrienne was the odd one out.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To be the odd one out means to be different in comparison to others, but in this context Adrienne is the one person who is the same.

premise: I thought I saw an intruder in my room last week.
hypothesis: I was overjoyed when I thought I saw an intruder in my room last week
label: Contradiction
explanation: Seeing an intruder in one's room is a very scary experience and so being overjoyed at the prospect is unrealistic and sarcastic.

premise: It can do everything except give you a massage (hinting at the possibility that it could give you a sexual favor instead)
hypothesis: It can do everything except give you a massage (nudge nudge wink wink).
label: Entailment
explanation: The idiom nudge nudge wink wink is used to draw attention to an innuendo, which in this context is the possibility of a sexual favor.

premise: I want you to go throughout the palace and communicate that sadi has been rehabilitated and that I've reinstated him.
hypothesis: I want you to go throughout the palace and spread the word that sadi has been rehabilitated and that I've reinstated him.
label: Entailment
explanation: To spread the word means to disseminate a specific piece of information, which is what he wants her to do regarding the news of sadi's rehabilitation.

premise: I am angry that my brother ruined a movie ending for me.
hypothesis: I'm so happy that my brother spoiled the movie ending for me
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would be angry or upset if someone spoiled the ending of a movie for them, so to be happy about it isn't rational.

premise: I asked my friend to water my plants while I was on vacation but she didn't and they died.
hypothesis: I was ecstatic when I got back from vacation and found out that my plants died because my friend didn't water them
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would be sad if their plants died while they were on vacation, so someone who is happy about it is not logical.

premise: Then go down to the stores, and do it quickly!
hypothesis: Then go down to the stores, and make it snappy!
label: Entailment
explanation: To make it snappy means to do it quickly, so the entailment is telling the person to hurry up.

premise: The headline read, local celebrities receiving a lot of intense criticism or judgment.
hypothesis: The headline read, local celebrities under fire.
label: Entailment
explanation: To be under fire means to be subject to intense criticism or judgment, which is what the headline is stating.

premise: He did not bring anything new to his performance.
hypothesis: He injected new life into the performance.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To inject new life into something means to make it more exciting or vibrant, while not doing anything new could be unenjoyable.

premise: I am so mad my landlord is selling the house so I have to move.
hypothesis: I am so angry that my landlord is selling the house and making me move
label: Entailment
explanation: It is often frustrating and upsetting when someone's landlord decides to sell the house because it means the tenant has to go through the hassle of moving

premise: At work a new coworker keeps looking at me in weird way.
hypothesis: At work, it's really fun when a new coworker keeps looking at me in a way that makes me feel uncomfortable
label: Contradiction
explanation: When someone looks at another person in a way that makes them feel uncomfortable, it usually invokes feelings of fear or insecurity and is not fun by any means.

premise: I forgot my lunch at home two days in a row.
hypothesis: I really love the fact that I forget my lunch at home two days in a row
label: Contradiction
explanation: Forgetting something as important as lunch shows a lack of organization and care which cannot be seen as something to love.

premise: The dancer is graceful
hypothesis: The dancer is as graceful as a hurricane
label: Contradiction
explanation: A hurricane is a destructive force of nature, whereas a graceful dancer is known for their elegance and poise so its unlikely for the dancer to be graceful but instead they are clumsy

premise: I always forget my password to important sites.
hypothesis: I am totally not ashamed of the fact that I forget my password to the sites that are important to me.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Having to remember a password is a common task that people do, so forgetting it implies that the person is not organized and has trouble keeping track of things which is not something to be proud of.

premise: I'm jealous of anyone who doesn't have to deal with student loan debt!
hypothesis: I am insanely envious of anyone who doesn't have to deal with student loan debt!
label: Entailment
explanation: Student loan debt is a huge burden for many people and so anyone who doesn't have to deal with it is likely to be the object of envy for those who do

premise: Nate received positive feedback and recognition for not asking to join me in the shower.
hypothesis: Nate received brownie points for not asking to join me in the shower.
label: Entailment
explanation: A brownie point is an imaginary award given to someone who does good deeds.

premise: Smith kicked me, so I tried to pacify him.
hypothesis: Smith kicked me, so I gave him tit for tat.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Tit for tat is taking revenge on someone who has harmed you, but in this context the speaker tried to pacify Smith instead.

premise: I got stuck in an elevator recently and was so scared that I would die in there.
hypothesis: I was really excited when I got stuck in the elevator because there is nothing more fun than panicking and thinking of death.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Being stuck in an elevator is a very scary experience and definitely not something that would be considered fun by anyone.

premise: The images flashed in the brilliance that covered him cold.
hypothesis: The images flashed in the brilliance that covered him like a plush blanket
label: Contradiction
explanation: A plush blanket is a thick, soft, and warm blanket, whereas saying it was cold would imply the opposite

premise: I really needed a 34 on the ACT to get a big scholarship and in the end I got a 33 many times.
hypothesis: I was overwhelmed with happiness when I found out that I needed a 34 on the ACT to get the big scholarship, but in the end I only got a 33.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A 34 on the ACT is a minimum score and so someone getting a 33 cannot be happy because it means that they did not get the scholarship they want

premise: people are passing by and lamps hanging along the streets cast light on their faces.
hypothesis: The great gold apples of light hang from the street’s long bough dripping their light on the faces that drift below.
label: Entailment
explanation: The metaphor is comparing the lamps to apples and the light they cast on people's faces to the light that drips from apples; here, the statement suggests that the lamps are hanging from the street and dripping their light on the faces below.

premise: We tried to work together but we're more compatible than ever.
hypothesis: We tried to work together but we're like oil and water.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Oil and water is an idiom that means two objects or elements that do not mix together readily, but in this context they are more compatible than ever.

premise: I stepped in gum someone spit on the side walk
hypothesis: I got so thrilled when I stepped in gum someone spit on the side walk
label: Contradiction
explanation: Gum on the sidewalk is often dirty and unsightly and so finding some on your shoe would not be a reason to get thrilled.

premise: An indication of what the current times are like, I said, trying to lighten things.
hypothesis: Sign of the times, I said, trying to lighten things.
label: Entailment
explanation: A sign of the times is something that signifies the situation evident in the current times, and in this context the current situation is one where things need to be lightened.

premise: Maxine fortenberry came in, looking angry and moving slowly.
hypothesis: Maxine fortenberry came in, her walk ponderous and her face like a thunderstorm.
label: Entailment
explanation: A thunderstorm is large, dark, and looming, which are all adjectives that can be used to describe the anger in Maxine Fortenberry's face in this context.

premise: The dead and withered apples  of light hang from the street’s long bough dripping their light on the faces that drift below.
hypothesis: The great gold apples of light hang from the street’s long bough dripping their light on the faces that drift below.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Here the contradiction lies between comparing the lights - in one statement lamps are apples and they are casting light on faces wheres as in the other statemrnt the apples and dead and withered.

premise: From the moment he'd crawled out of bed earlier that morning he knew the day was going to go exactly as planned without any surprises.
hypothesis: From the moment he'd crawled out of bed earlier that morning he knew the day was going to throw a curve ball.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To throw a curve means to do something unexpected, but the context describes a day going exactly as planned without any surprises.

premise: He has to pay for all the repairs because of an accident.
hypothesis: He absorbed the costs for the accident.
label: Entailment
explanation: This metaphor is saying that the person had to pay for the accident out of their own pocket.

premise: I cannot believe I forgot my Anniversary.
hypothesis: I feel terrible that I forgot my anniversary and I'm so sorry
label: Entailment
explanation: Anniversaries are important days to remember and forgetting it often leads to people feeling guilty and apologizing

premise: I got an older car for my 16th birthday, but my best friend got a BRAND new BMW!
hypothesis: It's absolutely fine that I got an older car for my 16th birthday, while one of my best friend who got a BRAND new BMW!
label: Contradiction
explanation: It is not fine to get an older car for a 16th birthday when one of your friends got a brand new BMW because it shows a clear inequality in privilege.

premise: He had a hard time navigating his way through the new city.
hypothesis: The new city was a maze for him.
label: Entailment
explanation: Mazes are complicated structures that are difficult to navigate through.

premise: It's better that this happened even though it's delayed, Danny said behind them.
hypothesis: Well, better late than never,danny said behind them.
label: Entailment
explanation: The idiom better late than never means that the delayed occurrence or achievement of something is better than it not happening at all.

premise: I would not do something as unsavory as reading other people's mail.
hypothesis: I won't bow to reading other people's mail.
label: Entailment
explanation: To bow to something means to do it even though you don't want to because you have to, here, the person doesn't want to read other people's mail, but they would do it if they had to.

premise: I am really getting irritated with traffic nowadays and horn sounds are just terrible
hypothesis: I am feeling so calm with the traffic jams and the sound of car horns
label: Contradiction
explanation: Traffic jams and the sound of car horns are usually very frustrating for people and cause them to feel angry and stressed, so someone who is happy and calm in that situation cannot be genuine.

premise: At a shop a seller was lying about the prices of the items that he was selling.
hypothesis: The fact that the seller blatantly lied about the prices of the items he was selling totally didn't make me angry
label: Contradiction
explanation: If someone is caught lying about the prices of the items they are selling, it is not a good sign that they can be trusted and so the seller's trustworthiness is called into question.

premise: Adam closed the front door and stood there for a moment as if he could not pull himself away .
hypothesis: Adam closed the front door and stood there for a moment as if he could not wrench himself away .
label: Entailment
explanation: Wrench  means to pull or twist suddenly, so the author is saying that Adam closed the door but it was a struggle for him to do so.

premise: With a few years without experience you 'll be a bona fide bad ass.
hypothesis: With a few years under your belt you 'll be a bona fide bad ass.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To have something under your belt means to have safely or satisfactorily achieved it or to have experienced it, but in this context the person has not yet experienced anything

premise: He's a moldering old bachelor and a gypsy swindler as well as many other negative things.
hypothesis: He's a moldering old bachelor and a gypsy swindler to boot.
label: Entailment
explanation: To boot means as well or additionally, so this context is saying that he is a moldering old bachelor and a gypsy swindler as well as many other negative things.

premise: I accidentally tripped while walking into a restaurant and there was a bunch of people around.
hypothesis: I felt so proud of myself when I tripped while walking into the restaurant and everyone saw .
label: Contradiction
explanation: Tripping while walking into a restaurant is not a good thing because it makes the person look clumsy and incapable in front of others.

premise: Unless you disregard the rules, you're out.
hypothesis: Unless you toe the line, you're out.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To toe the line means to adhere to the rules, but in this context unless you disregard the rules you will be out.

premise: I would invite you in to eat something, but my mom must be nearly here, so its try to push my luck and face the bad consequences.
hypothesis: I would invite you in to eat something, but my mom must be nearly here, so its best not to tempt fate.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To tempt fate means to do something that is dangerous or likely to have a negative outcome, and in this context the speaker saying is its best to push their luck by inviting the person in to eat. which contradicts the meaning of tempting one's fate

premise: Even though she was surrounded by a whirling vortex, she felt agitated.
hypothesis: A whirling vortex surrounded her, but within the vortex she was like a buddhist garden.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A buddhist garden is a place of peace and tranquility, so she should feel at peace, not agitated

premise: I wanted to get money, but the ATM started.
hypothesis: I wanted to get money, but the ATM surrendered.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To surrender means to give up or yield, while to start means to begin or commence.

premise: This extremely expensive bordeaux wine should be allowed to oxidize and open up for 2 hours at least.
hypothesis: This rare bordeaux must be allowed to breathe for at least 2 hours.
label: Entailment
explanation: Breathing allows wine to aerate and open up, releasing its full flavor potential especially for extremley expensive wine

premise: I once lost my job and got mad.
hypothesis: I was livid when I lost my job and had to scramble to find a new one.
label: Entailment
explanation: Losing a job is often a very stressful and upsetting experience because it can be difficult to find a new job, especially in today's economy

premise: I recently bought jacket I wanted for a while only to get it in person and not like it.
hypothesis: When I finally got the jacket I wanted for a while and saw it on person I loved that it made me look like a slob.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A jacket that makes someone look like a slob is not something they would want to get and so receiving it was actually a bad thing.

premise: He keeps the magic dead by staying up there whenever the sun goes away.
hypothesis: Whenever the sun goes away, he stays up there keeping the magic like a sacred burning flame.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A sacred burning flame is kept alive and is never extinguished, whereas if he keeps the magic dead, it would mean that the magic disappears when he is up there

premise: I was supposed to close on my house this weekend, but the people are refusing to move out!
hypothesis: I am so happy that the considerate sellers on my house are refusing to move out even though it is already closed
label: Contradiction
explanation: The sellers not moving out even after the house is closed is inconsiderate and not something that would make the buyer happy

premise: He was relaxed
hypothesis: He was wired like a champagne cork.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A champagne cork is under a lot of pressure, and is about to burst open, implying that the person is under a lot of pressure and is about to explode, not relax

premise: People would treat you very well.
hypothesis: People would walk all over you.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To walk all over someone is to treat them very badly, but in this context people would treat the person very well

premise: I was really stressed out and grad school and had no choice but to drop out to keep my sanity.
hypothesis: I was totally confident and grad school was making me feel like I was going so good that I dropped out to keep my sanity
label: Contradiction
explanation: A lot of people feel stressed and anxious instead of confident when they are in grad school and so dropping out to keep one's sanity cannot be a good thing.

premise: He said he was aware of the sensitivity of this assignment, but she would consciously and deliberately make an effort to remind him.
hypothesis: He said he was aware of the sensitivity of this assignment, but she would make a point of reminding him.
label: Entailment
explanation: To make a point of doing something is to consciously and deliberately make an effort to do it, which is what she would be doing by reminding him.

premise: I am worried I will drown when I go swimming.
hypothesis: I am excited that I will drown when I go swimming
label: Contradiction
explanation: Someone who is excited about the prospect of drowning while swimming is actually scared of water and not excited

premise: Now do you remember Mr. Richfield suggesting you go really enjoy yourself without worrying about being proper or dignified?
hypothesis: Now do you remember Mr. Richfield suggesting you go really let your hair down?
label: Entailment
explanation: To let your hair down means to relax and enjoy yourself, which is what Mr. Richfield was suggesting.

premise: A part for my computer that I've been putting off buying went up 10% right before I finally ordered it.
hypothesis: The fact that the price for the part I need for my computer went up 10% right before I decided to buy it made me pleased
label: Contradiction
explanation: The price for the part a person needs for their computer going up 10% right before they decide to buy it is not a good thing because it means that they will have to spend more money than they originally planned to.

premise: Uncle Sven would not even get slightly upset if he found out I spend my evenings drinking with negroes, but quite frankly I don't care.
hypothesis: Uncle sven would go spare if he found out I spend my evenings drinking with negroes, but quite frankly I don't care.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To go spare means to become very angry or irritated, but Uncle Sven would not be angry if he found out about the situation

premise: He felt a sudden intense pain through his leg.
hypothesis: He felt a sudden red pain through his leg.
label: Entailment
explanation: The sudden red pain that he felt through his leg was  severe and intense.

premise: That's pretty funny, considering you constantly smoke a lot of tobacco.
hypothesis: That's pretty funny, considering you smoke like a chimney.
label: Entailment
explanation: To smoke like a chimney means to smoke a great deal of tobacco, so the person is saying that it's funny that the other person smokes a lot considering they just made a joke about smoking.

premise: Her face was pale after she came out from the sauna. .
hypothesis: Her face glowed when she came out of the sauna.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To glow means to emit light or to have a healthy and radiant appearance, while pale face means it looks dull.

premise: We couldn't reach a mutual settlement because we disagreed on some basic terms .
hypothesis: We took on the terms of the settlement.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To take on something means to accept or agree to it, while to disagree on something means to have a different opinion or belief about it.

premise: I was watching a TV show where people were eating cockroaches, I wanted to throw up.
hypothesis: I almost smiled when I saw people eating cockroaches on TV.
label: Contradiction
explanation: : The sight of people eating cockroaches is revolting and disgusting and so someone almost smiling at it cannot be possible.

premise: There is nothing like being betrayed by someone you love
hypothesis: I feel like my world has been beautiful after being betrayed by the person I loved
label: Contradiction
explanation: Being betrayed by someone you love can be really hurtful and often has a negative impact on a person, therefore it cannot be considered as something that has turned their world beautiful.

premise: She doesn't mind blabbering useless things.
hypothesis: She spews a lot of nonsense.
label: Entailment
explanation: Spewing means to talk rapidly and uncontrollably, often without making sense.

premise: I am angry that my brother ruined a movie ending for me.
hypothesis: I'm happy that my brother spoiled the movie ending for me
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would be angry or upset if someone spoiled the ending of a movie for them, so to be happy about it isn't rational.

premise: I just witnessed someone steal from an old woman walking across the street. Boils my blood!
hypothesis: I just saw a nice thief steal from an old woman walking across the street
label: Contradiction
explanation: A thief is not nice because they are stealing and so on top of that stealing from an old woman is never a good thing.

premise: I procrastinated and didn't do the dishes for a couple days now and fungus started to grow on some of the old food
hypothesis: I'm glad that fungus started to grow from the old food because I left the dishes for a couple days
label: Contradiction
explanation: Seeing fungus grow from old food is disgusting and certainly not something to be glad about.

premise: The huge waves gently touched the small boat and it sank shortly thereafter.
hypothesis: The huge waves smacked the small boat and it sank shortly thereafter.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To smack something means to hit it hard, while to touch gently means to touch it softly.

premise: You'll become more cold and uninviting and be expecting me to stay over nights or watch the kid during the day so you can get your beauty sleep.
hypothesis: You 'll change your tune and be expectin me to stay over nights or watch the kid during the day so you can get your beauty sleep.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To change one's tune typically means to change in a more positive or agreeable manner, but the contradiction describes a change in a cold and uninviting manner.

premise: You want to pay for the entire thing yourself?
hypothesis: You want to go halves?
label: Contradiction
explanation: To go halves means to share the cost of something evenly between two people, but in this sentence, the person wants to know if the other person wants to pay for the entire thing

premise: The internet is failing a lot I feel bad about that.
hypothesis: I just love that the internet is always failing and I feel great because of it.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Having the internet not working properly is really frustrating and not something to feel great about.

premise: He was convinced they knew nothing about him.
hypothesis: He was worried they might spill everything about him.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The speaker is worried that the other people might spill everything about him because he has something to hide, which is contradictory to the next statement that assures he is also convinced that they know nothing about him.

premise: When she turned the knob, her hand flaked off at the elbow, pliably.
hypothesis: When she turned the knob, her hand flaked off at the elbow, like a dried flower.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A dried flower is brittle and would not flake off pliably

premise: She remained expressive
hypothesis: She remained like a slate.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A slate is a type of stone that is flat and usually empty, so saying someone is like a slate would imply that they are not expressive

premise: I am so behind on my housework.
hypothesis: I feel great that I have not been able to keep up with my housework like I wanted to
label: Contradiction
explanation: Not being able to keep up with housework is a negative thing as it means the house is not clean and tidy and hence the person does not feel great about it.

premise: Stock prices are increasing everyday.
hypothesis: Stock prices are rocketing higher.
label: Entailment
explanation: Rockets usually go up in the sky, here, it is equivalent to the stock prices that are going higher.

premise: this problem has not relocated to the uk.
hypothesis: this problem has migrated to the uk.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Migrated in this context means to move, and so the sentence is saying that the problem has moved to the UK whereas, if we look at the other sentence, it says that the problem has not relocated.

premise: I feel bad that I cheated on my diet.
hypothesis: I feel wonderful that I cheated on my diet and broke the commitment I made to myself.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Cheating on a diet and breaking a commitment made to oneself goes against everything that is healthy and good, so feeling wonderful about it is definitely not justified.

premise: I had to renew my driving license, after 3 months they told me that they lost my paperwork.
hypothesis: I was on seventh heaven when I found out that my driving license renewal got lost in the system and had to be done all over again
label: Contradiction
explanation: A driving license renewal getting lost in the system would be a huge inconvenience and so someone being happy about it is quite absurd.

premise: I found a snake in my boot and thought it would bite me
hypothesis: I was so excited when I found a snake in my boot and thought it would bite me
label: Contradiction
explanation: Snakes are often feared because they are poisonous and so finding one in a boot would not be something to be excited about but rather terrifying.

premise: My first date was terrible as I turned up late and sweaty.
hypothesis: I wish I could always remember the fact how beautiful my first date was when I turned up late and sweaty.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Being late and sweaty for a first date are not good impressions to make and so the date cannot be considered beautiful by any means.

premise: Ahab was not firm with his decisions and it was extremely easy to manipulate him.
hypothesis: Ahab was a pyramid but I kept kicking at him.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A pyramid is a very large and solid structure, while something that is easy to manipulate is not firm or solid.

premise: I really can't stand when people in customer service have attitudes.
hypothesis: I absolutely love how customer service reps with attitudes make me feel like crap
label: Contradiction
explanation: Customer service reps with attitudes often make people feel frustrated and angry, so someone who 'adores' how they make them feel is not being truthful.

premise: Every day, I had done nothing but tiptoe around him, but not anymore.
hypothesis: Every day, I had done nothing but walk on eggshells around him, but not anymore.
label: Entailment
explanation: To walk on eggshells around someone means to act with great care and consideration so as not to upset them, which is what the speaker did every day.

premise: The task of unraveling seemed possible; it lay before pruett in a calming and straightforward way.
hypothesis: The task of unraveling seemed impossible; it lay before pruett like an unfinished nightmare .
label: Contradiction
explanation: Unfinished nightmares are still terryfying, not calm or straightforward

premise: One day, Edred came out looking strong to see Jorr.
hypothesis: Then one day edred came out to see jorr, looking like a wisp of cobweb
label: Contradiction
explanation: A wisp of cobweb is a small, delicate strand of spider web, so implying that someone looks like one would mean they look weak and fragile, not strong

premise: The person taking my information at the Registry was very slow and they misspelled my name twice
hypothesis: I wasn't annoyed at all over the person taking my information at the Registry very slowly and misspelling my name twice.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Having to wait for a long time at the Registry and having one's name misspelled can lead to frustration and so someone who is not annoyed by that is definitely absurd.

premise: Short answer: because she was bitten and she will have to face the consequences of her mistakes eventually.
hypothesis: Short answer: because she was bitten and chickens come home to roost eventually.
label: Entailment
explanation: The idiom chickens come home to roost means that you have to face the consequences of your mistakes or bad deeds, and this is what the entailment is saying.

premise: People offering her the opportunity of a lifetime to become involved in something at its beginning of a great business opportunity.
hypothesis: People offering her the opportunity of a lifetime to get in on the ground floor of a great business opportunity.
label: Entailment
explanation: To get in on the ground floor means to become involved in something at its beginning, which is what is happening in this sentence.
idiom: get in on the ground floor

premise: I'm totally disgusted with it.
hypothesis: I'm sick to death of it.
label: Entailment
explanation: To be sick to death of something means to be totally disgusted with it, which is how the speaker feels.

premise: Today I waited for the cable company to show up at my house for 5 hours... No one ever came
hypothesis: I feel so angry and let down that the cable company never showed up even after waiting for 5 hours
label: Entailment
explanation: It is really frustrating when someone is waiting for someone else who never shows up, especially when it is for something important like the cable company

premise: They appeared to be vulnerable
hypothesis: They appeared to be like a bank vault
label: Contradiction
explanation: A bank vault is a space where valuables are kept that is very secure, so saying they were like a bank vault implies they were secure and not vulnerable

premise: I knew the moment had arrived when the silence became too much to bear.
hypothesis: Silence was crushing, I knew the moment had arrived.
label: Entailment
explanation: Being crushed means being under a lot of pressure, thus, In this case, the pressure was too much to bear and the person knew that the moment had arrived.

premise: But ‘ sincerity and modesty ’ went far beyond the unions .
hypothesis: But ‘ posturing and pretending ’ went far beyond the unions .
label: Contradiction
explanation: To pretend means to act as if something is true when it is not, and sincerity means the genuineness, exactly the opposite.

premise: Then the self destructive instincts; oh I can stop now.
hypothesis: Then the self destructive instincts; oh I can go on and on.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To go on and on means to continue or speak for a length of time, but the speaker says they can stop now, which contradicts the idiom

premise: I forgot to put up the leftovers last  night and ruined dinner for today.
hypothesis: I feel terrible that I forgot to put up the leftovers last night and it resulted in not having food today
label: Entailment
explanation: Forgetting to put up the leftovers often results in the food going bad and becoming inedible which often leads to people feeling terrible because they know that they wasted food

premise: You can wait for an indefinite amount of time,' Dad smirked at me.
hypothesis: ,'You can wait till the cows come home', Dad smirked at me”
label: Entailment
explanation: To wait till the cows come home means to wait for a very long time, and in this context Dad is telling the speaker that they can wait for an indefinite amount of time.

premise: My heart beats when he enters the room.
hypothesis: My heart sings when he walks in the room.
label: Entailment
explanation: This is a metaphor meaning that the person's heart feels happy when the other person enters the room.

premise: I was so upset when my dog destroyed the model airplane I was building.
hypothesis: I was thrilled when my dog destroyed the model airplane I had been building for weeks
label: Contradiction
explanation: A model airplane is usually a cherished item for someone who likes to build them and so seeing it destroyed would be a frustrating experience, not a thrilling one.

premise: Here, I told the truth but was wrongfully accused .
hypothesis: And truth exalted, and righted wrong.
label: Entailment
explanation: And truth exalted, and righted wrong means that even though I was telling the truth, I was still accused.

premise: My light bill was super high.
hypothesis: Love spending 500$ to pay a light bill at the beginning of the month. Inspires me to stay up late  with all the lights on while I'm asleep.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Paying an expensive light bill  due to misuse of electricity can be hard and so someone spending 500$ on it is not something to be inspired by, but rather discouraged.

premise: I missed a chance to get a new job the other week and I really wish I had put my resume in sooner.
hypothesis: I don't regret not submitting my resume sooner and thereby missing the chance to get an awesome new job
label: Contradiction
explanation: Submitting a resume sooner would have increased the chances of getting an interview for an awesome new job, so someone who does not submit it is regretful.

premise: Maybe if she gave up the baby, no one in town would ever become aware of it.
hypothesis: Maybe if she gave up the baby, no one in town would ever get wind of it.
label: Entailment
explanation: To get wind of something means to become aware of it, which is what would happen if she gave up the baby and people in town found out.

premise: I looked to my right and saw a figure standing on the platform, holding a rifle and staring down at us motionlessly.
hypothesis: I looked to my right, toward the platform, and saw standing there a solitary figure, a rifle cradled in his arms, staring down at us like a sentry on the watch.
label: Entailment
explanation: A sentry is a person who stands guard, watching for any potential threats motionlessly.

premise: The hidden sun will once again emerge from the dark.
hypothesis: The hidden sun unfurls with light.
label: Entailment
explanation: Unfurls with light means that the sun will come out from behind the clouds and be filled with light.

premise: My mother-in-law told a secret of mine that she promised she would never tell.
hypothesis: It made me thing that my mother-in-law is very trustworthy when she told a secret of mine that she promised she would never tell
label: Contradiction
explanation: When someone breaks a promise to not tell a secret, it is not considered to be a trustworthy thing to do and so the mother-in-law cannot be considered as being very trustworthy.

premise: The setting was lush.
hypothesis: The setting was like a police interrogation room somewhere deep in the basement.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A police interrogation room would typically be small, cramped, and not lush

premise: He and his brothers would risk everything for her each and every day of their lives.
hypothesis: He and his brothers would go to the wall for her each and every day of their lives.
label: Entailment
explanation: To go to the wall means to take on great risk, which is what he and his brothers would do for her every day.

premise: I felt sad that I was not asked to be the bridesmaid at a close friends wedding
hypothesis: It made me feel terrible when I found out that I was not asked to be a bridesmaid in my close friend's wedding
label: Entailment
explanation: Being asked to be a bridesmaid in a close friend's wedding is often seen as an honor and not being asked can often lead to feelings of sadness and rejection

premise: Avon steps carelessly .
hypothesis: Avon treads warily .
label: Contradiction
explanation: To tread warily means to move cautiously or be on guard, while to step carelessly means to move recklessly or without caution.

premise: I got shafted by my general manager at my job.
hypothesis: I feel completely joyful that my general manager would do something like shafting to me
label: Contradiction
explanation: The word shafting is often used to describe being treated unfairly or in a negative way and so the general manager shafting the speaker would make them resentful instead of feeling joyful.

premise: He pinched his eye and a contact lens came out, revealing a shiny iris.
hypothesis: He made a pinching motion and a colored contact lens popped out, revealing an iris that was like an amethyst jewel .
label: Entailment
explanation: An amethyst jewel is a precious, shiny gemstone and is here being used to compare to an iris.

premise: Everything seemed disproportional .
hypothesis: Everything seemed like an alley-themed funhouse .
label: Entailment
explanation: An alley-themed funhouse would have narrow spaces and be designed to be disorienting, so everything in it would appear disproportional.

premise: My daughter cannot follow simple directions because she is glued to her phone
hypothesis: I feel so proud when my daughter can't even follow simple directions because she is too busy on her phone.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A daughter who cannot follow simple directions is not a good thing and so the parent should not feel proud but instead ashamed.

premise: Now he remembered what he didn't particularly like or have a fondness for about the frivolous female.
hypothesis: Now he remembered what he didn't particularly take a shine to about the frivolous female.
label: Entailment
explanation: To take a shine to someone or something means to have a fondness for them, so not taking a shine to something means not having a fondness for it.

premise: I got my burger with millions of onions on it today when I specifically asked for no onions.
hypothesis: I was really happy that the burger place didn't listen to my request and put onions on my burger
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people do not like onions on their burgers and so someone being happy that the burger place did not listen to their request is really ironic.

premise: I was looking forward to a picnic on Sunday but I'm gutted it will be raining.
hypothesis: I was looking forward to a fun day outside but the forecast of rain completely ruins my picnic plans
label: Entailment
explanation: A forecast of rain often means that the picnic plans will have to be canceled or changed because rain makes picnicking difficult and often unpleasant

premise: The place was packed and the tobacco smoke was thin.
hypothesis: The place was packed and the tobacco smoke was like a london fog.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A London fog is a thick, gray smog, not thin

premise: Burglary, nothing important or significant.
hypothesis: Burglary, really small potatoes.
label: Entailment
explanation: Small potatoes means a tiny and/or inconsequential person, thing or amount, and in this context burglary is seen as tiny and inconsequential.

premise: Their tall navy blue figures looked very stylish and handsome as they started the walk to the village
hypothesis: Their tall navy blue figures cut a dash through the muggy spring afternoon as they started the walk to the village.
label: Entailment
explanation: To cut a dash means to have a striking attractive and elegant appearance, which is how their figures looked in the sentence.

premise: I feel intact and undamaged
hypothesis: I feel like a train barreling of control.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A train that is out of control is heading for a crash, and so would not be intact and undamaged

premise: My roommate cooked some foul smelling meat in our apartment and I almost puked.
hypothesis: My considerate roommate cooked some meat with a beautifully weird smell in our apartment and I almost threw up
label: Contradiction
explanation: The smell of meat that has been cooked can often be very unpleasant and overwhelming, so it is not considerate to do so in a shared space without considering the other person's reaction.

premise: Experiencing great joy was Mudjekeewis.
hypothesis: Filled  with joy was Mudjekeewis.
label: Entailment
explanation: Mudjekeewis was overflowing with happiness.

premise: We really performed very well last night at the game
hypothesis: We really laid an egg last night at the game
label: Contradiction
explanation: To lay an egg means to do something very poorly, but in this context they performed very well

premise: You can't benefit from two different situations.
hypothesis: you can't have your cake and eat it too.
label: Entailment
explanation: The idiom means that you can't benefit from two different situations, so the entailment is that you can't benefit from two different situations.
idiom: you cant have your cake and eat it

premise: Slowly his sense and strength increased.
hypothesis: Slowly his sense and strength grew.
label: Entailment
explanation: This sentence is saying that the guy slowly regained his sense and strength.

premise: The old tenant gave a optimistic speech.
hypothesis: The old tenant gave a bittersweet speech.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A bittersweet speech is one that is tinged with both sadness and happiness, while an optimistic speech would be one that is only positive and hopeful.

premise: I bit into an apple and found a worm and it was so gross.
hypothesis: I felt sick to my stomach when I discovered a worm inside the apple I was eating
label: Entailment
explanation: Discovering a worm in an apple is pretty disgusting and most people would feel sick to their stomach if they found one while eating

premise: I stepped in gum someone spit on the sidewalk.
hypothesis: I stepped in the grossest thing ever, someone's spitted gum on the sidewalk
label: Entailment
explanation: Spitting gum on the sidewalk is considered very rude and disgusting and so stepping in it would be one of the grossest things someone could do

premise: Lady Cameron, he began, I am a simple country lord who doesn't want to spend the season in London and look very frumpy and unattractive among the upper class.
hypothesis: Lady cameron, he began, i am a simple country lord without any aspirations to spend the season in london and cut a dash among the ton.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To cut a dash means to have a striking attractive and elegant appearance, but in this sentence he would look frumpy and unattractive

premise: Clients of this company come from all over the world, but all come from a homogenous status.
hypothesis: This company has many thousands of clients around the world from all walks of life.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To come from different walks of life means to come from different socioeconomic backgrounds, but in this context the clients come from a homogenous background

premise: Till it lost the form and features.
hypothesis: Till it took the form and features.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To take the form and features of something means to assume its likeness or appearance, while to lose the form and features of something means to cease resembling it.

premise: Mike scollay was a small-time racketeer from shytown who paid for his mortgage by running booze in from canada.
hypothesis: Mike scollay was a small-time racketeer from shytown who paid for his beer and skittles by running booze in from canada.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Beer and skittles means all fun and pleasure, but this sentence describes Mike Scollay paying for his mortgage which is not fun or pleasant.

premise: I just so happen to know that they pay a very large amount of money for a bloodhorse and titan is our best two year-old.
hypothesis: I happen to know they pay top dollar for a bloodhorse and titan is our best two year-old.

premise: I get so down on humanity sometimes watching true crime shows

label: Contradiction
