label: Contradiction
explanation: It is the responsibility of a roommate to clean the apartment and if they are not able to do that, then they are incompetent and one should not feel wonderful but instead pathetic and frustrated.

premise: I was so upset when my dog destroyed the model airplane I was building.
hypothesis: I was very happy when my dog destroyed the model airplane I had been building for weeks

explanation: A model airplane is usually a cherished item for someone who likes to build them and so seeing it destroyed would be a frustrating experience, not a happy one.

premise: Death is going further away from the door.
hypothesis: Death is knocking at the door.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Death is typically seen as something that is close or near if it is knocking at the door, while going further away would suggest that it is getting further and further away.

premise: As gandalf always says, when in doubt, peregrin took, ignored his instincts and went against his gut feeling.
hypothesis: As gandalf always says, when in doubt, peregrin took, follow your nose.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To follow your nose means to trust one's instinct, but in this sentence Peregrin ignored his instincts

premise: His skin was very white and he had that hideous disease of no hair-no eyebrows and no eyelashes, and none on a head that was polished.
hypothesis: His skin was very white and he had that hideous disease of no hair-no eyebrows and no eyelashes, and none on a head that was like a billiard ball.
label: Entailment
explanation: A billiard ball is a smooth, polished object, so the person's head must be similarly polished and smooth if it is like a billiard ball.

premise: his smile was a horrid dark hole.
hypothesis: her smile was a blinding sun.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The two images are contradictory because a blinding sun is bright and full of light, while a horrid dark hole is the opposite.

premise: I had to deal with a lady and her 2 daughters that had lice
hypothesis: I had to endure the joy of dealing with a lady and her 2 daughters that had lice
label: Contradiction
explanation: Dealing with lice is a very unpleasant experience and most people would not consider it to be a joyful experience.

premise: I was mortified when my jeans ripped
hypothesis: I was so pleased when my jeans ripped right in the middle of the street
label: Contradiction
explanation: Ripping jeans usually means that they are too tight and so seeing it happen in public can be really embarrassing not pleasant.

premise: His constantly changing and unpredictable behavior had showed me that the man I married.
hypothesis: His jekyll and hyde actions had showed me that the man I married.
label: Entailment
explanation: Jekyll and Hyde refers to a personality that alternates between good and evil behavior, which is what was shown by the man the speaker married.

premise: He's dirty
hypothesis: He's like a pig in a wallow.
label: Entailment
explanation: A pig in a wallow is a pig that is rolling around in the mud, so it is implied that the person is dirty.

premise: I've been so upset lately, the house has been a mess and my husband hasn't been helping clean.
hypothesis: I am really appreciative of my husband that my he hasn't been helping me clean the house because it's been a mess lately
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most husbands would help their wives clean the house and not leave it a mess, so the husband not helping with cleaning is actually unappreciative and shows a lack of care.

premise: I have put constant efforts to make them fight so that things get worse between them.
hypothesis: I tried to patch things over between them.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To patch something over means to try to repair or fix it, while to make things worse between two people would mean to do the opposite.

premise: At a shop a seller was lying about the prices of the items that he was selling.
hypothesis: The fact that the seller blatantly lied about the prices of the items he was selling made me so angry
label: Entailment
explanation: Lying is generally considered a bad thing to do and when someone lies about the prices of the items they are selling it is likely to make people angry because they feel like they are being cheated

premise: If shay thought it was going to calm or soothe me, he was wrong.
hypothesis: If shay thought it was going to get a rise out of me, he was wrong.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To get a rise out of someone usually means to provoke an angry or irritated response, but in this sentence Shay was trying to do the opposite by calming or soothing the person.

premise: My doctor told me to give up caffeine to help calm down my anxiety.
hypothesis: The fact that I have to give up lovely caffeine in order to get rid of my stupid anxiety makes me feel like I am on top of the world.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Caffeine is often associated with feelings of alertness and energy, and giving it up in order to get rid of anxiety can be really hard for some people.

premise: He was looking underconfident.
hypothesis: He was looking like a true rajput warrior .
label: Contradiction
explanation: A true warrior has to demonstrate qualities like confidence and assertiveness, hence an underconfident person would not be looking like a true rajput warrior.

premise: The big waves saved the small boat from going down but it sank shortly thereafter.
hypothesis: The huge waves attacked the small boat and it sank shortly thereafter.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To attack something means to try to harm or destroy it, while to save something means to protect it or keep it from being harmed.

premise: I think that two people working together can achieve more than one person working alone, so I expect you to work with Elena.
hypothesis: I always believe that two heads are better than one, so I expect you to work with Elena.
label: Entailment
explanation: The idiom two heads are better than one means that two people who are trying to solve a problem together achieve more than one person who works alone. Therefore, the entailment is that the speaker thinks working together is better than working alone.
idiom: two heads are better than one

premise: She did not capture attention of all the men.
hypothesis: She swallowed all the men's hearts.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To swallow men's hearts means to winning everyone while to have no attention mean men were not interested into her.

premise: I worked really hard with my daughter last year to teach her multiplication facts but last week at her quiz she failed.
hypothesis: I was thrilled when my daughter last week failed her multiplication quiz after we worked so hard together last year
label: Contradiction
explanation: A parent would not be thrilled about their child failing a multiplication quiz because it shows that the child has not learned what they were supposed to and hence it would imply that the parent has failed as well.

premise: The final scene of the novel describes a murder.
hypothesis: The novel sprouts with a murder.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To sprout with something means to have it as a starting  element or to grow something, while the final scene of the novel describes a murder would suggest that the murder is the last element.

premise: Her forehead was smooth.
hypothesis: Her forehead was like an old map.
label: Contradiction
explanation: An old map would be wrinkled since it was probably not stored properly, so a forehead like an old map would not be smooth

premise: I recently found out that I have been diagnosed HIV positive, and I'm at a complete loss for words.
hypothesis: I am completely excited that I have been diagnosed with HIV
label: Contradiction
explanation: Being diagnosed with HIV is not a good thing because it means that someone has a serious and life-threatening illness which would not make them excited in any way.

premise: My a/c is going out and it is supposed to be real hot today.
hypothesis: I am so excited about the fact that my a/c is going out and it's supposed to be really hot today.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would not be excited about the fact that their a/c is going out because it means that they will have to suffer in the heat, which is not a desirable outcome.

premise: I have no idea how he did it, but he sure failed to solve the very challenging problem decisively.
hypothesis: I have no idea how he did it, but he sure cut the gordian knot.“
label: Contradiction
explanation: To cut the Gordian knot means to solve a very challenging problem decisively, but this sentence describes him failing to do so.

premise: I ate dinner by myself again.
hypothesis: I feel so lonely that I had to eat dinner by myself once again
label: Entailment
explanation: Eating dinner is often seen as a social activity and so eating dinner alone can often make people feel lonely

premise: I lied to my friend that I was busy this weekend
hypothesis: It was so great of me to lie to my friend by saying I was busy this weekend when I am not.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Lying to a friend by saying you are busy when you are not is not a great thing to do because it shows that you are not considerate of their time and are not interested in spending time with them

premise: I hate it when the waitress bring another table food when I got there first
hypothesis: I feel delighted when the waitress brings food to another table when I am the one who got there first
label: Contradiction
explanation: It is very frustrating to wait for your food and see someone else getting it instead, so the sentiment expressed by the speaker is not one of delight but annoyance.

premise: Her body became rigid.
hypothesis: Her body became like a partially full bag of grain.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A partially full bag of grain would be limp and not rigid

premise: This pillow's soft
hypothesis: This pillow's as soft as stone
label: Contradiction
explanation: Stone is not soft, so the simile is saying that the pillow is not soft

premise: A global catastrophe causes all major technology to be rendered useless.
hypothesis: A global catastrophe causes all major technology to be rendered like burned ashes.
label: Entailment
explanation: Burned ashes are useless and have no value.

premise: Tatiana has been in turns glamorized, idolized, and made to look like the best thing ever - all in one sitting.
hypothesis: Tatiana has been in turns glamorized, lionized, put on a pedestal and made to look like yesterday's news - all in one sitting.
label: Entailment
explanation: To put on a pedestal means to see someone or something as perfect or wonderful and in this context, Tatiana has been seen in that light.

premise: I was pissed at the fact that my landlord entered my appartment without notifying me.
hypothesis: I was livid when my landlord entered my apartment without notifying me
label: Entailment
explanation: It is a violation of privacy for someone to enter your home without letting you know first and so it is understandable to be very angry when it happens

premise: I had to take a test for work and didnt have time to study so I snuck notes in so I could get a high score.
hypothesis: I feel really proud of myself for resorting to cheating by sneaking notes in so I could get a high score in a test for work which I didnt have time to study for
label: Contradiction
explanation: Cheating is never a good thing and is often looked down upon because it gives people an unfair advantage and hence the speaker should not feel proud for sneaking notes in an exam

premise: Just got ditched by my friend for the third time this week when trying to make plans.
hypothesis: I feel so cherished when every time I try to make plans, my wonderful friends ditch me
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people do not enjoy feeling left out or being the only one who is trying to make plans and so getting ditched by friends often makes someone feel not cherished at all.

premise: I cannot believe I forgot my Anniversary.
hypothesis: I feel like the best husband ever since I forgot my anniversary and it doesn't bother me at all.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Anniversary is a special day in a marriage and forgetting an anniversary is a irresponsible act and so someone who claims to be the best husband for forgetting it does not show any admirable qualities.

premise: And then tolerate and flex and yell after!
hypothesis: And then suck it up and flex and yell after!
label: Entailment
explanation: To suck it up means to endure something painful or unpleasant, and in this context the person is enduring the pain of flexing.

premise: Her fear was so terrifying that it was blocking her mind.
hypothesis: Fear choked her mind.
label: Entailment
explanation: Fear can block someone's mind, making it difficult for them to think clearly.

premise: Even though it is not blood, the truth is even more horrid.
hypothesis: While it has been confirmed to not be blood the truth is even more like broken skeletons in a closet.
label: Entailment
explanation: Broken skeletons in a closet is a metaphor for something that is hidden and horrifying.

premise: I knew pain existed, and this was mild.
hypothesis: I knew there was pain but this was like a sharp dagger.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A sharp dagger is a very painful experience, whereas something that is mild would not be considered as painful as a sharp dagger

premise: Adie's not in trouble.
hypothesis: Adie's in dutch.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To be in dutch means to be in trouble or disfavor, but this context states that Adie is not in trouble.

premise: I was furious when my sister tore all my comics
hypothesis: I was really mad when my sister ripped all my comics
label: Entailment
explanation: If someone tears your comics then they are damaging them and most people would be upset if their comics were damaged

premise: To start with, it's the content you create that makes the real difference.
hypothesis: when all is said and done, it's the content you create that makes the real difference.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The idiom when all is said and done is used to describe when everything is finished and settled, but this context is describing how the content you create is the most important thing from the start
idiom: when all is said and done

premise: My neighbor always interrupts me when I talk.
hypothesis: It's totally not frustrating when my neighbor always interrupts me when I'm trying to have a conversation with someone
label: Contradiction
explanation: Being interrupted by someone when you are trying to have a conversation can be really frustrating and annoying.

premise: Colby, don't try to understand or have any clarity about your emotions.
hypothesis: Colby, get a handle on your emotions.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To get a handle on something means to have a firm understanding of it, but in this sentence Colby is being told not to try to understand his emotions.

premise: The news hit me hard
hypothesis: The news hit me like a Mack truck.
label: Entailment
explanation: A Mack truck is a large, heavy vehicle, so the news hitting someone like a Mack truck would imply that it hit them very hard.

premise: Rarely, I work hard to put food on the table, and then I cop this from the missus.
hypothesis: day in, day out, I work hard to put food on the table, and then I cop this from the missus.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The idiom day in, day out is used to describe something that happens routinely or regularly, but in this sentence the speaker only works hard rarely

premise: Finish  the evening 's dusk and coolness ,
hypothesis: Fell  the evening 's dusk and coolness ,
label: Contradiction
explanation: Fell is used to mean the beginning where finish is its opposite.

premise: I was mad when I returned to my car and noticed someone put a dent in my door
hypothesis: I was so happy when I returned to my car and noticed someone put a dent in my door.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would not be happy upon returning to their car and noticing that someone had caused damage to it, but rather would feel frustrated or angry.

premise: This new printer really grinds my gears!!!
hypothesis: This new printer is soooo great and I absolutely love how it's grinding on my nerves.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A printer that is making noises and causing problems is not great and so someone who loves it is being sarcastic.

premise: The first thing I noticed when I walked in the room was the black leather chair behind the desk- it was wide and comfortable looking.
hypothesis: Before I could do or look at anything else, I noticed the chair behind the desk-black leather and looking like a football player's shoulders.
label: Entailment
explanation: A football player's shoulders are wide and strong, indicating that the chair is also wide and comfortable looking.

premise: I cannot find my mailbox key anywhere
hypothesis: I'm totally not frustrated at how I can't find my mailbox key anywhere
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would find it really frustrating to not be able to find their mailbox key because it is a necessary item for retrieving mail, so someone who is having a great time despite this situation is not being truthful.

premise: I got bar-b-que from a place a few weeks ago and it literally tasted like they got it out of a dumpster.
hypothesis: The bar-b-que I got a few weeks ago was so good that it tasted like it was straight out of the trash
label: Contradiction
explanation: The bar-b-que being straight out of the trash would make it inedible and gross, so it cannot be good.

premise: I forgot about wife's birthday.
hypothesis: Wife's birthday slipped my mind and I feel great about it.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Forgetting one's wife's birthday is a really bad thing to do and so who feeling great about it cannot be considered normal.

premise: The sales tax is excluded into the state income tax.
hypothesis: The sales tax is absorbed into the state income tax.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The another statement suggest the sales tax is a separate entity from the state income tax whereas the other statement suggests that sales tax is added to the income tax.

premise: I am so upset, my phone was on top of my car and it fell off and shattered.
hypothesis: My phone, that was on top of my car, suddenly fell off and shattered, so that's my best day ever.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Dropping or losing a phone is usually a very traumatic experience for most people because it means they have to spend more money to repair it or get a new one and hence can make them feel upset or like they have had the worst day ever.

premise: No wonder all those silly cheerleaders swoon over him regardless of the fact that he's big
hypothesis: No wonder all those silly cheerleaders swoon over him regardless of the fact that he's like a sumo wrestler.
label: Entailment
explanation: A sumo wrestler is a large, muscular man, so the simile is emphasizing his size.

premise: I ate half a sandwhich before realizing the bread was moldy.
hypothesis: I felt healthy after realizing the bread from the sandwich I ate was moldy
label: Contradiction
explanation: Realizing that the bread from the sandwich you ate was moldy would make anyone feel sick and not healthy at all.

premise: I was getting out of the swimming pool when my swim short teared from behind.
hypothesis: I felt so relaxed when my swim short suddenly ripped from the back when I was getting out of the swimming pool.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Ripping one's clothes is usually an embarrassing thing and not at all relaxing, so the person must be feeling the opposite of relaxation.

premise: The project is well thought and directed very well.
hypothesis: The problem with the project is that it is all smoke and mirrors.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The idiom smoke and mirrors is used to describe trickery or deception, but this context describes the project as being well thought and directed

premise: After the vibrant colors of the garden, the stone hall seemed as dark and foreboding because of the complete lack of noise.
hypothesis: After the vibrant colors of the garden, the stone hall seemed as dark and silent as the grave.
label: Entailment
explanation: To be silent as the grave is to be totally silent, which in this context creates an ominous effect.

premise: All witnesses may be questioned in a gentle and superficial manner by opposite sides.
hypothesis: All witnesses may be cross examined by opposite sides.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To cross examine means to question someone in an aggressive or detailed manner, but the sentence describes questioning in a gentle and superficial manner

premise: They never thought they would see streetlights again, but when they did they were wonderful and welcoming.
hypothesis: Neither of them ever imagined that they would see streetlights from the dark side of a sewer grate, but there it was, like a lighthouse beacon to a fogged-in vessel.
label: Entailment
explanation: A lighthouse beacon is a light that guides a vessel to safety, and so the streetlights were like a beacon to them, guiding them to safety and were were wonderful and welcoming.

premise: When it comes to the least essential and unimportant part of it, I'm flat-out lazy.
hypothesis: When it gets right down to the nuts and bolts of it, I'm flat-out lazy.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To get down to the nuts and bolts of it means to get to the most essential part of it, but in this context the speaker is admitting that when the least essential part of it comes he is lazy.

premise: The dancer is clumsy
hypothesis: The dancer is as graceful as a hurricane
label: Entailment
explanation: A hurricane is a violent storm, so the dancer must be very clumsy in order to be compared to one.

premise: The memory I have of my father in my mind is of him letting his inventions being used constantly when Bennet caught a cold when we were ten years old.
hypothesis: The memory I hold of my father in my mind is of him letting his inventions gather dust when Bennet caught a cold when we were ten years old.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To gather dust means to be unused or forgotten, but in this sentence the father's inventions are being used constantly

premise: After many years of loyal service, the company fired him.
hypothesis: The company dumped him after many years of service.
label: Entailment
explanation: Dumped means to get rid of something or someone.

premise: He knew that Metcalfe was one of the good guys.
hypothesis: He knew that metcalfe was one of the white hats.
label: Entailment
explanation: A white hat is a virtuous or morally-sound person, and in this context Metcalfe is one of the good guys.

premise: Everytime my friend comes over and brings his kids he never keeps a close eye on them and they ravage my place!
hypothesis: It's my favorite thing ever when my friend comes over and doesn't keep a close eye on his kids and they end up wrecking my place.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Kids can often be destructive when they are left unsupervised and so having a friend who does not closely monitor their children can lead to damages to someone's property and hence not be a favorite thing

premise: Great to see a new person or people getting their feet wet.
hypothesis: Great to see young blood getting their feet wet.
label: Entailment
explanation: Young blood refers to a newcomer, so it's great to see them getting their feet wet.

premise: His throat had gone dry .
hypothesis: His throat had gone like a shriveled-up leaf .
label: Entailment
explanation: A shriveled-up leaf is dry and papery, so it is implied that his throat had gone dry.

premise: Fame is so delusive for the heroes.
hypothesis: Fame grows to the heroes.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Fame is often seen as something that heroes strive for and grow to achieve, while fame can also be seen as delusive, or something that is not real or trustworthy.

premise: I'm confident he's caught off guard, but he doesn't have any right to stay silent.
hypothesis: I'm sure he's surprised, but he has no right to cry foul.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To cry foul is to protest against something, but in this sentence the person is not protesting anything

premise: My flight got delayed and the airline would not apologize and provide altenative
hypothesis: I was immensely pleased when my flight got delayed and the airline refused to apologize and provide alternative transportation
label: Contradiction
explanation: Flight delays are never a good thing and so the airline not apologizing and not providing alternative transportation was really terrible.

premise: She was the darkness of my life.
hypothesis: She was the light of my life.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The two statements are contradictory because one says she was the light and the other says she was the darkness.

premise: The phone number was so complex
hypothesis: The phone number was easy to remember as a 100 number password
label: Entailment
explanation: A 100 number password is a long, complex string of numbers, so the phone number must be similarly long and complex.

premise: My dad's wife asked me to give her back the glassware she gave us at our wedding.
hypothesis: I didn't feel it to be super weird at all when my dad's wife asked me to give her back the glassware she gave us as a wedding present
label: Contradiction
explanation: It would be weird for a step-mother to ask for back the glassware she gave as a wedding present to her step-son and his wife, because it would mean that she doesn't want them to have it anymore.

premise: I got my burger with millions of onions on it today when I specifically asked for no onions.
hypothesis: I was really disappointed that the burger place didn't listen to my request and put onions on my burger
label: Entailment
explanation: When someone goes to a burger place and asks for something specific like no onions on their burger, they are generally disappointed when their request is not followed

premise: He was so close to me that I could smell his clean and crisp aftershave.
hypothesis: He stood, less than a foot from me, and I could smell his aftershave, like a breezy day at the beach.
label: Entailment
explanation: A breezy day at the beach would have a clean and refreshing smell, similar to the aftershave.

premise: Sunset takes place in the evening.
hypothesis: From its blue vase the rose of evening drops.
label: Entailment
explanation: The rose of evening is a metaphor for the setting sun.

premise: geez, it's hot
hypothesis: geez, it's like a sauna in here.
label: Entailment
explanation: A sauna is a hot room or space, typically used for relaxation, so the simile refers to how hot the room feels.

premise: The college rescinded my admission offer
hypothesis: The college just revoked my admission offer and I am completely elated
label: Contradiction
explanation: College admission offers are usually coveted by students and so having it revoked is not a good thing and hence the person is not elated.

premise: I broke my aunt's picture display, it was very elaborate and nice
hypothesis: I felt like such a great and organized person when I accidentally broke my aunt's picture display that she had just put up.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Breaking someone's picture display cannot make someone feel great or organized but rather guilty and clumsy because they destroyed someone's special belongings.

premise: In fact, he'd warn mr. Sullivan first, so that the lawyer could not use his power or influence to get what he wants or do whatever he had to do to protect the u.b..
hypothesis: In fact, he'd warn mr. Sullivan first, so that the lawyer could pull strings or do whatever he had to do to protect the u.b.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To pull strings means to use the power or influence one has over others, but in this context the lawyer would not be using his power or influence

premise: My sister in law and her fiance are taking all these trips abroad and we are struggling just to get our bills paid.
hypothesis: It's making me feel so grateful how my sister in law and her fiance are able to go on all these trips abroad when we're just enjoying the struggle to get our bills paid
label: Contradiction
explanation: The sister in law and her fiance going on trips abroad while the speaker is struggling to get their bills paid implies that the former are more wealthy than the latter and hence it is sarcastic to say that the speaker is grateful for it.

premise: I woke up to there being no toothpaste left, my boyfriend used it all and I had to go to work!
hypothesis: I was absolutely elated to wake up to the news of my boyfriend using up all the toothpaste thereby forcing me to go to work without brushing my teeth
label: Contradiction
explanation: Waking up to the news of your boyfriend using up all the toothpaste is not something that would make someone elated because it would mean they have to go to work without brushing their teeth which is really unpleasant.

premise: You know what happens if we make a false alarm, Katherine said.
hypothesis: You know what happens if we cry wolf, katherine said.
label: Entailment
explanation: To cry wolf means to make a false alarm, which is what Katherine is warning against.

premise: And rest can come and settle, hope comes to fruition.
hypothesis: And rest can never dwell , hope never  comes.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To rest can never dwell means that there is no respite or relief, while to have rest come to setting means that it has some relief.

premise: It came running, hard and reckless.
hypothesis: It came like a swamp cat, with its ears raised and its eyes opened wide.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A swamp cat is a wild cat that is typically soft and cautious, not hard and reckless

premise: gain strength and confidence from my example, and speak on.
hypothesis: take courage from my example, and speak on.
label: Entailment
explanation: To take courage from someone means to gain strength and confidence from them, which is what the speaker wants the other person to do.

premise: Don't mention Tom's promotion to Mike as Mike is going to feel pissed about it.
hypothesis: Don't mention Tom 's promotion to Mike as it would be a red flag to a bull.
label: Entailment
explanation: The phrase red flag to a bull means that something will make someone angry, i.e., In this case, Mike is going to be angry if he finds out that Tom got promoted.

premise: His skin was very white and he had that hideous disease of no hair-no eyebrows and no eyelashes, and none on a head that was dull.
hypothesis: His skin was very white and he had that hideous disease of no hair-no eyebrows and no eyelashes, and none on a head that was like a billiard ball.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A billiard ball is shiny, so saying someone's head is like a billiard ball would imply that it is shiny, not dull

premise: I ordered takeout yesterday and I got home and found out half my food was missing.
hypothesis: Was looking forward to eating my takeout last night, and was very relieved to get home to find that half my food was missing.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Half the food being missing from a takeout order is not a good surprise and instead one cannot be relieved by it.

premise: His eyes were light, and his skin was so pale it looked blue.
hypothesis: His skin was pale and blue, and his eyes were like a glacier crevasse.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A crevasse is a deep crack in a glacier, so saying someone's eyes are like a crevasse would indicate that they are very deep and dark

premise: I was in a hotel and there was hair in the shower drain.
hypothesis: I found hair in the shower drain and it didn't make me feel disgusted at all.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Finding hair in the shower drain is a very common occurrence and often grosses people out, so someone who doesn't feel disgusted by it is abnormal.

premise: I feel desolate.
hypothesis: I feel like a lily in february.
label: Entailment
explanation: Lilies are a type of flower that bloom in summer and not in february so a lily blooming in february would be lonely.

premise: Even during the crushing remorse he was able to pulled up from despair.
hypothesis: He crushed remorse and sunk down despair.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Crushing would be an intense feeling while sinking down would be a feeling of hopelessness, so one sentence is saying that he had intense feelings of remorse and another sentence is saying that he was able to overcome those feelings.

premise: I bought a lottery ticket and did not win anything
hypothesis: I feel so intelligent that I wasted my money on a lottery ticket and did not even win a penny.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A lottery ticket is a waste of money because the chances of winning are very slim and so someone who spends money on it and does not win anything in return cannot be considered intelligent.

premise: She was vibrant and sharp .
hypothesis: She was like a high-definition tv .
label: Entailment
explanation: A high-definition tv has a lot of detail and is very clear and sharp, so the simile is saying that she is very clear, vibrant and sharp .

premise: I ate at a restaurant this morning and the Sriracha bottle looked like it was 1000 years old.
hypothesis: The fact that the Sriracha sauce bottle at the restaurant looked like it was from the Middle Ages made me want to hug the owner
label: Contradiction
explanation: The Sriracha sauce bottle at the restaurant looked like it was from the Middle Ages means that it is old and most likely not clean, so someone wanting to hug the owner is not a desirable outcome.

premise: That bird is very clumsy
hypothesis: That bird is as graceful as a drunken penguin
label: Entailment
explanation: A drunken penguin would be very clumsy on land, so its unlikely for the bird to be graceful but rather clumsy

premise: My sister was given $1,000 by my grandma as a graduation present but she did not give me a penny.
hypothesis: I really felt the love when my sister was given a thousand dollars by my grandma as a graduation present and I got nothing
label: Contradiction
explanation: A thousand dollars is a lot of money to give as a graduation present and so receiving nothing in comparison implies that the speaker is not loved as much as the sister who received the money.

premise: The first time she saw him was in this mirrored room, which was a cramped space.
hypothesis: This was where she'd first seen him, in this mirrored room, a space like an airplane hangar.
label: Contradiction
explanation: An airplane hangar is a very large space, so it would not be cramped

premise: I get so ticked off when I see people leave their grocery carts in the middle of the parking lot.
hypothesis: I love it when I see people leaving their grocery carts in the middle of the parking lot
label: Contradiction
explanation: People who leave their grocery carts in the middle of the parking lot are being inconsiderate and creating a mess, so seeing them do that does not evoke feelings of love but rather annoyance.

premise: Even if a car is old, such as the 1980 Toyota Corolla or 1982 Nissan Sunny, it won't rust because of technological innovation.
hypothesis: Find a 1980 Toyota Corolla or 1982 Nissan Sunny that has not succumbed to rust , and you can buy with confidence .
label: Entailment
explanation: The word succumbed is used to mean that even if a car is old, if it hasn't died of rust, it's still a good buy.

premise: Her bones are chilled by the cold.
hypothesis: The cold hollows her bones.
label: Entailment
explanation: To hollow out something is to make it empty or to remove the inside of it, so, her bones are empty and cold because of the cold weather.

premise: Charles, she's so beautiful and curvaceous.
hypothesis: Charles, she's like a broom handle .
label: Contradiction
explanation: A broom handle is straight and not curvaceous

premise: Brother number two claimed the police couldn't charge him with any crimes at all because they only found the upper torsos of his butchered bodies.
hypothesis: Brother number two claimed the police couldn't throw the book at him because they only found the upper torsos of his butchered bodies.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To throw the book at someone means to charge them with as many crimes as possible, but if they only found the upper torsos of the bodies then there wouldn't be enough evidence to charge him with any crimes.

premise: The armor was breakable and weak
hypothesis: The armor was tough as glass
label: Entailment
explanation: Glass is a material that is easily breakable and weak, so the simile is indicating that the armor is not very strong.

premise: The grove only takes the top thirty drama candidates from the two thousand who will be auditioning over the next few days, so try your hardest and give it your all.
hypothesis: The grove only takes the top thirty drama candidates from the two thousand who will be auditioning over the next few days, so put your best foot forward.
label: Entailment
explanation: To put your best foot forward means to embark on an undertaking with as much speed, effort, and determination as possible, which is what the speaker wants the candidate to do.

premise: Golden light made the red brick of the house look awesome.
hypothesis: No golden light bathed the red brick of the house .
label: Contradiction
explanation: Golden light typically makes things look more beautiful, while no golden light would make things look dull or unimpressive.

premise: The judge is dishonest
hypothesis: The judge is as honest as Pinocchio
label: Entailment
explanation: Pinocchio is a cartoon character that lies a lot, so the judge would not be honest

premise: I ate dinner by myself again.
hypothesis: I'm a genuine social butterfly; i had to eat dinner by myself once again.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Eating dinner by oneself implies that a person is not very social and does not have many friends the opposite of a genuine social butterfly

premise: That the time may pass in a discouraging manner,
hypothesis: That the time may  pass  more gayly ,
label: Contradiction
explanation: one sentence is suggesting that time will pass by cheerfully and another sentence is suggesting that time will pass in a sad manner.

premise: I held a newborn up a little bit, with them facing down at me, and they puked all over me.
hypothesis: The smell of baby vomit is like walking through a rose garden.
label: Contradiction
explanation: The smell of baby vomit is not pleasant at all and is instead very nauseating and overwhelming.

premise: He felt weak and flimsy
hypothesis: He felt like a great oak tree with roots that went deep.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Oaks are strong and durable trees, with deep roots, so saying he felt like one would indicate he felt strong, not weak

premise: The candle flame twisted in the dark.
hypothesis: The candle flame twirled in the dark.
label: Entailment
explanation: The candle flame was flickering and twisting.

premise: Copernum continued to talk, but the words were unintelligible
hypothesis: Copernum continued to talk like a low conversation heard through a thick door.
label: Entailment
explanation: A low conversation heard through a thick door would be difficult to understand, or in other words, unintelligible.

premise: My sister threw up the other day and made a huge mess.
hypothesis: My sister puked the other day and made a huge mess that made me feel disgusted
label: Entailment
explanation: Vomit is often considered to be gross and seeing someone else vomit, especially if they make a huge mess, can often trigger feelings of disgust in other people

premise: My eyes got so dry I feel like my face turned into red.
hypothesis: My eyes burned up and I could feel my face turning red.
label: Contradiction
explanation: When someone's eyes burn up, it means they are full of emotion or tears, whereas,, if someone's eyes get so dry that their face turns red, it means they are not emotional about the situation.

premise: I'm glad I'm not flying without eating anything, someone jokes.
hypothesis: I'm glad I'm not flying on a full stomach,someone jokes.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To fly on a full stomach means to have just recently eaten to the point of being full, but the person is flying without having eaten anything.

premise: We went the full distance to portland, even though the brunswick mall is only a half-hour away.
hypothesis: We go all the way to portland, even though the brunswick mall is only a half-hour away.
label: Entailment
explanation: To go all the way means to continue on a course to the end, which is what they did by going to Portland.

premise: Till it pulled itself together.
hypothesis: Till it drew itself together ,
label: Entailment
explanation: To draw oneself together means to make an effort to control oneself or to recover from a shock

premise: I told my kids to clean while I was gone and the house looked worse than before I left
hypothesis: I got home and found out my angelic kids only made the house dirtier when I told them to clean it
label: Contradiction
explanation: Kids are often disobedient and do not listen to what their parents tell them so making the housing messier when asked to clean is not being angelic.

premise: I have to go to court soon for a drunk driving incident and I am so scared.
hypothesis: I am upbeat about going to court soon because of the drunk driving incident
label: Contradiction
explanation: Being charged with a crime like drunk driving is definitely not something to be upbeat about and so the person is sarcastically pretending to be happy about it.

premise: I had to pay a late fee on my car taxes because I procrastinated in paying them on time.
hypothesis: I was so overjoyed and pleased with myself when I found out I had to pay a late fee on my car taxes because I waited too long to pay them
label: Contradiction
explanation: The feeling of having to pay a late fee on something is not a good one and so someone being overjoyed about it cannot be real.

premise: Consumed by the thoughts that were in the head
hypothesis: Consumed by the thoughts that grew in the head.
label: Entailment
explanation: The thoughts grew in the head means that the person was thinking about something that were present in their head.

premise: I ruined my friends wedding because of my drunken behavior
hypothesis: I feel elated that the gift my drunken behavior at my friends wedding completely ruined the day.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A friend's wedding is a special day which should be happy and memorable, but if someone's drunken behavior ruins it, they would more likely feel regretful and upset instead of elated

premise: Really, the man blew consistently.
hypothesis: Really, the man blew like an air conditioner with a broken thermostat.
label: Contradiction
explanation: An air conditioner with a broken thermostat blows erratically and not consistently since it cannot correctly read the temperature

premise: She had done nothing to him, made him feel perfectly fine afterwards.
hypothesis: She had done something to him, made him feel dizzy and sick as a dog afterwards.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To be sick as a dog means to be very ill, but in this context she made him feel perfectly fine.

premise: I knew pain existed, but this was intense.
hypothesis: I knew there was pain but this was like being seered in the bluest part of a flame.
label: Entailment
explanation: To be seered in a flame means to be burned very badly, so the simile is implying that the pain was very intense.

premise: MY new neighbors have decided to move their thing around at midnight. IT is so loud
hypothesis: MY new neighbors are such polite upstanding citizens for moving their thing around at midnight and making so much noise.
label: Contradiction
explanation: It is generally considered to be impolite to make too much noise late at night and so someone who moves their thing around at midnight and makes a lot of noise is not a polite upstanding citizen.

premise: Someone sneezed on me at the bus stop.
hypothesis: Got sneezed on by a complete stranger at the bus stop and it made me feel so clean
label: Contradiction
explanation: Getting sneezed on by a stranger is often considered to be gross and dirty and so someone feeling clean after that cannot be possible.

premise: I have no clue about it.
hypothesis: your guess is as good as mine.
label: Entailment
explanation: If someone says "your guess is as good as mine," it means that they have no idea and are just guessing like the other person.
idiom: your guess is as good as mine

premise: You may petition the president of the united states to allow you to face the criticism of the nations disapproval.
hypothesis: You may petition the president of the united states to allow you to run the gauntlet of the nations disapproval.
label: Entailment
explanation: To run the gauntlet means to be exposed to or forced to endure a series of threats, dangers, criticism or other problems, which is what the person in this context is petitioning to do.

premise: I get aggravated with people who don't understand personal space.
hypothesis: I get so happy with people who invade my personal space and make me really angry
label: Contradiction
explanation: People who invade personal space without consent can often make someone feel angry and violated and so someone who gets happy around them is not being real.

premise: Me and my partner were in disagreement in the shopping mall and everyone was watching us
hypothesis: I was so overjoyed when me and my partner were having a disagreement in the shopping mall and everyone was watching us.
label: Contradiction
explanation: People usually do not enjoy public displays of anger and so someone being overjoyed about it would be unrealistic.

premise: She was wearing sandals with thick soles and low heels.
hypothesis: Her sandals had crepe-thin soles and heels like a wedding cake.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Wedding cakes often have very thin layers, and are tall and slender, not low

premise: He was stricken with a terrible illness that killed him so fast he had no chance to do anything.
hypothesis: He was gripped with a terrible illness that killed him quickly.
label: Entailment
explanation: Gripped with illness is used here to mean that something happend suddenly and violently, here, in this case, the man was hit with an illness that killed him quickly.

premise: The Star tops the Christmas tree during Christmas.
hypothesis: A star crowns the Christmas Tree.
label: Entailment
explanation: Crowns the Christmas Tree means it is sitting on the top of the tree.

premise: Don't be influenced by your emotions when deciding, think with your head, Minnehaha.
hypothesis: Let your heart  speak  , Minnehaha ! .
label: Contradiction
explanation: one sentence means that one should follow their heart when making decisions whereas another sentence contradicts this by saying that one should not be influenced by their emotions when deciding, but rather think with their head.

premise: There's nothing that ticks me off more than someone who tries too hard to make an impression.
hypothesis: I absolutely love it when someone is trying too hard to be something they're not and it totally doesn't make me angry at all
label: Contradiction
explanation: When someone is trying too hard to be something they're not, it often results in them being fake and not genuine which can cause anger in people.

premise: I am very irritated at how my junior colleague never listens to instructions
hypothesis: I feel disgusted that my junior colleague never listens to instructions and then screws up everything
label: Entailment
explanation: Its very frustrating when someone you are supposed to be leading or teaching does not listen to your instructions and then makes a lot of mistakes because it makes you look bad as their leader

premise: I wanted to get money, and the ATM started.
hypothesis: I wanted to get money, but the ATM froze.
label: Contradiction
explanation: If the ATM froze, it would mean that it stopped working and the person would not be able to get any money, whereas, if the ATM started, it would mean that it was working and the person would be able to get money.

premise: I am so mad my dog ate my homework that I spend 2 hours on so now I have to redo the whole thing!
hypothesis: I am thankful that my dog ate my homework and now I get to spend another 2 hours on it!
label: Contradiction
explanation: Homework is often assigned to students to practice and learn new concepts and so having to do it again owing to the dog eating it is a waste of time amd cause one to be mad instead of thankful.

premise: I'm confident
hypothesis: I'm like a drug user being searched.
label: Contradiction
explanation: A drug user being searched would not be confident, because they would be worried about getting caught with drugs

premise: Our home was broken in to 2 months after we purchased it.
hypothesis: We just moved into our new home and somebody broke in to it after only 2 months- talk about fun.
label: Contradiction
explanation: It is unlucky for someone to move into a new home and have it broken into within such a short time frame and so it cannot be considered as a great welcoming committee.

premise: I can't seem to get my budget under control and it's really harming me.
hypothesis: I feel great that I can't seem to get my budget under control and how its beautifully harming.
label: Contradiction
explanation: Having a budget is important in order to save money and not being able to get it under control means that the person is overspending which is not a great thing.

premise: I am sick of the fact that my mom makes me babysit my nephew all the time.
hypothesis: I love the fact that my mom expects me to babysit my nephew all the time
label: Contradiction

premise: My wifi is not working properly
hypothesis: I'm simply delighted because my wifi is not working and I can't get any work done
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people need wifi to be able to work and not having it working would frustrate them instead of delighting them because it hinders their productivity.

premise: The little raindrops falling together stick upon my coat.
hypothesis: The little raindrops collapsing together stick upon my coat.
label: Entailment
explanation: Collapsing means falling down and sticking together.

premise: The system worked, so theres no reason to change it - no need to keep something bad while getting rid of something good.
hypothesis: The system worked, so theres no reason to change it - no need to throw the baby out with the bathwater.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To throw the baby out with the bathwater means to discard something valuable while disposing of something considered worthless, but in this context, the system is good but there is something bad that needs to be discarded.
idiom: throw the baby out with the bathwater

premise: I worked on this project for so long but it turns out my job doesn't even want it done anymore.
hypothesis: Pleased with how I put so much effort into this project only to realize my job doesn't care if it gets done or not
label: Contradiction
explanation: Pouring a lot of effort into a project and then not having it appreciated or taken into consideration by the job is very discouraging and shows that the job doesn't care about the employee's efforts.

premise: I saw my friend projectile vomit on the rollercoaster.

label: Contradiction

premise: I half-heartedly give up; I have no more pride: did he even mention me?.
hypothesis: I go for broke; I have no more pride: did he even mention me?
label: Contradiction
explanation: To go for broke means to give something one's full effort, but the speaker is only giving half-hearted effort

premise: My neice and daughter left such a mess in the play room today that I couldn't even look at them
hypothesis: I was so mad when I came home and found the playroom in total shambles that I couldn't even look at my neice and daughter
label: Entailment
explanation: Parents often expect their children to clean up after themselves and when they don't it can be frustrating, especially if the mess is big

premise: The cigarettes cured his health.
hypothesis: The cigarettes snuffed his health.
label: Contradiction
explanation: To snuff something out means to extinguish it or put an end to it, while to cure something means to heal it or make it better.

premise: I was very upset and frustrated when I came outside this morning and found my car had been broken into.
hypothesis: I was utterly delighted when I came outside this morning and found my car had been broken into
label: Contradiction
explanation: Most people would not be happy if their car had been broken into because it is a nuisance and costly to repair.

premise: Even though he may have seemed civil from his education, he was actually dangerous.
hypothesis: He had a veneer of civility from his education, but he was like a cornered pit viper
label: Entailment
explanation: A cornered pit viper is a very dangerous animal, so this simile is suggesting that the man is dangerous even though he may seem civil on the surface.

premise: I was in a hotel and there was hair in the shower drain.
hypothesis: I found hair in the shower drain and it made me feel disgusted
label: Entailment
explanation: It is generally considered unclean to find hair in a shower drain because it suggests that the shower isn't being cleaned properly and can often make people feel disgusted

premise: He smiled treacherously up at me.
hypothesis: I looked down at him, and he smiled at me like an angel.
label: Contradiction
explanation: An angel is a being of divine nature, and they are often portrayed as benevolent and good

premise: My head moved in the crook of her neck.
hypothesis: My head lay in the crook of her neck.
label: Contradiction
explanation: one sentence is a metaphor, suggesting that the person's head is resting in the crook of the other person's neck whereas another sentence is a contradiction because it suggests that the person's head is moving, which would mean that it is not resting.
